Piney citrus hops on the nose.  Pours a golden orange with a solid white head.  Citrus hops upfront with bitter grapefruit notes and grassy flavors.  Not bad at all.

Bottle @ home. Aroma is huge hops, earthy, flowery and a touch of blue cheese, nutmeg and other spices. Flavour is a great balance of medium bitter hops, light sweet malt with a touch of caramel and an everlasting finish. Highly drinkable, great stuff!

great american pale similar to zombie dust but imo not as floral and hoppy.
cooper in color medium white head had this in sampler so maybe a little under rating
Pours copper, moderate head. Damn fine APA, albeit bordering on IPA. Solid pale and caramel malt base, lots of bitter pine in a very good balance.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2011 Copper reddish shine. Medium head. Flowery hop aroma, malts, citrus. Taste
Is hoppy mild and well balanced. Malts ans some taste of earl grey  tea are also
Well presnt. Hoppy finish but mild. Overall well balanced and very smooth beer.

Orange amber coloured beer with a nice head that sticks good. Nice caramel, fruity sweetness. Bitter floral hops with a good citrus touch. Decent and well balanced brew for sure. A bit dry earthy at the finish.

(Courtoisie de JulienHuxley)  Le liquide a une robe cuivr√©e.  La t√™te blanche est petite mais durable.  Une dentelle s¬í√©parpille.  Le nez se construit autour de houblons fruit√©s, r√©sineux et floraux.  La base malt√©e se manifeste avec √©l√©gance : la r√©ponse est grill√©e et dos√©e de main de ma√Ætre.  Les saveurs sont incroyablement bonnes : les cultivars apportent des saveurs parfum√©es et fra√Æches, remplis de notes am√®res justes.  Le sucr√© des malts, qui se d√©pose sur les papilles, se manifeste avec une certaine assurance.  En bouche, le liquide est moyennement rond avec une effervescence douce et une texture huileuse.  La finale se fait sur des notes am√®res et douces, une fabuleuse conclusion pour les sens.

Bouteille gracieuset√© de JulienHuxley et Slovak. Cette pale ale est un classique du monde brassicole am√©ricain. Le liquide est cuivr√©. Le nez est fort agr√©able, les ar√¥mes de citron c√¥toient les effluves fruit√©s. Une touche de levure fruit√© est aussi perceptible. La bouche a une bonne consistance, la texture est incroyable pour une simple pale ale. Les saveurs de caramel sont digestes. Un cot√© fruit√© et celui de houblon agr√©mente le tout.

Pours amber/ruby with a medium tan head...lively...grreat lacing and retention.  Aroma has pinepple and orange blossom...hint of bready or biscuity smell.  Flavor is more earthy than expected...lightly roasted malts, spice, grapefruit...bitter!  Mouthfeel is lively and the finish is earthy/spicy bitter and dry.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2011 35,5 cl bottle @ Craft Heads, Tokyo. 6% on the list, no info on bottle, no BBE info
Aroma is hoppy with sweetish toffee. Flavour is rather hoppy too, with toffee. Some fruity sweetness typical to the style. A bit metallic finish with hops. Very good and refreshing APA!

Hazy amber/orange color; Medium slight creamy body; Aroma of floral hops, pine, malt, & citrus; Flavor of slight sweet malt, pine hops, some floral, caramel, and citrus; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, full bodied and delicious - exceptional APA.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2012 Rerate using notes from our Pale Ale tasting: Pours orange with some head. Aroma has fruit and hoppy citrus. Taste brings sour grapes and citrus with sweetness back. Finished 3rd of the 13 in the tasting behind Moon Man and Daisy. Amazing to me was that I graded the same way as my first rating of it!  Original rating: Bottle from Brews.  (I cannot believe I have not rated this before ...)  Pours a lovely reddish orange with a foamy head.  Good lacing.  Aroma is flowery and citrus hops.  Pine.  Resin.  Very hoppy nose.  Taste is smooth sweet malts with bitter citrus fruit.  Well blended mix.  Finishes bittersweet and somewhat long.  Still surprised this is a pale ale and one of the best ever, if not the "king".  Eminently drinkable. A great example of FFF¬ís extreme-ness!

Glass, 5-ounce, on the premise, savoured on July 7 2011; eye: copper, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head; nose: resinous hops, grapefruit, orange, malt, caramel; mouth: resinous hops, malt, caramel, astringency, grapefruit, orange, alcohol warmth, finale in malt with good presence of resinous hops, medium-full body, average carbonation, quite bitter, mildly sweet, lightly alcoholic texture; overall: quite fine

FRAN√áAIS 

Verre, 5 onces, √† la brasserie, savour√©e le 7 juillet 2011; ¬úil : cuivr√©e, limpide, pas d¬íeffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige; nez : houblon r√©sineux, pamplemousse, orange, malt, caramel; bouche : houblon r√©sineux, malt, caramel, astringence, pamplemousse, orange, chaleur d¬íalcool, finale en malt avec bonne pr√©sence de houblon r√©sineux, corps moyen-cors√©, carbonatation moyenne, assez am√®re, moyennement sucr√©e, texture l√©g√®rement alcoolique; en r√©sum√© : bien bon
Lots of citrus and hops in the aroma.  Flavor is bittersweet grapefruit and some maltiness.  Reminds me a lot of a slightly watered down IPA, but in a good way.

12 oz bottle got in trade with an non-Ratebeerian.  Used a lager glass. Pours a light amber color with a white head and some lace. Aroma is hoppy, citrus and pine.  Taste starts with a malty background, and then the big hop profile.  Big blend of hops, grapefruit, citrus and a bit of resin.  Taste very much like it smells.  Mouthfeel is smooth and a little dry.  I think it should be listed an IPA, well made just not really what I was wanting to drink when I opened it. Still good.

Great beer.  Aroma is hops hops and more hops.  Taste is citrus, sweet fruits, light sweetness and a crisp dry finish.  Great drinkability and wonderfully executed pale ale.  Would be the best pale ale Ive ever had if I didnt also have a Zombie dust at the brew pub.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark copper, thin off-white head... decent lacing.

S: Grapefruit and citrus hops up front. Some floral notes and some caramel malt sweetness. No alcohol in the nose.

T: Deliciously balance between citrus hop bitterness and caramel malt sweetness. The finish is a blend of caramel lingering and a slightly bitter bite. Up front is mostly citrus hop notes.

M: Smooth, light-medium body. Semi-dry finish. Crisp and clean.

O: Great session brew for sure. Shame this isn¬ít in my neck of the woods.

A - Pours a fairly clear copper-orange color with a finger of frothy slightly off-white head atop. The head fades slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma has a nice kick of fresh citrus hops. There is also a nice balance provided by the sweet caramel malts in the background. Really excellent nose.

T - Starts off with a nice punch of citrus hops and some bitterness. Not far behind is the sweet caramel malts playing catchup to provide a good balance. Through the middle, the caramel malts get a bit deeper and richer and the hop flavor stays balanced alongside. The finish is a mix of some citrus hops and bitterness with some sweet caramel malts that linger.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. The beer is super smooth and extremely well balanced from start to end.

D - Super drinkable. Pretty much every aspect of this beer is excellently balanced. The hop profile is really fantastic from start to end and everything else just falls into place around that.

Very strong hoppy aroma, a kick in the teeth for an APA.  It does have a juiciness to it but offset by a lot of dry pine.  The only detraction from this score comes because its in between an APA and an IPA, both are good in their own right but its very slightly off if you can¬ít tell the difference between the two.
When I had this in the 22oz bottle, it had some off flavors, mainly oxodized.  I don¬ít think the store took proper care of it, but I stil looked passed that and it was pretty taste.

Goddamn what a brute of a pale ale lies in the glass before me.  Easily an IPA, Alpha King smacks you around with relentless hopping and a wicked ABV for a normal "pale ale."  Bitter, piney, with an almost medicinal finish, Alpha King is a enormous a hop-bomb as I¬íve come across with a pale ale label.  Not my favorite, but still a bitter joy.

Bottle pours deep amber with a khaki head. Aroma shows lots of grapefruit, orange zest, and light florals sitting on top of caramel. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of berry and pine. Overall body 
is moderate and finishes dry with moderate to heavy bitterness. Now i know why they call it ALPHA king.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2011 I¬íve had this in bottles and on tap at Three Floyds in Munster, IN. Pours a dark amber with an off-white head.  Amazing hop bouquet on the nose with pungent notes of pine and citrus and a hint of booze. Taste is very hoppy, citrus, grapefruit with strong hop bitterness on the finish. Really closer to an IPA than an APA.  I love this beer.  A must-try for hop-heads.

355 ml bottle, from √òlbutikken, Copenhagen. ABV is not mentioned on the label. Cloudy orange-brown colour, large off-white head. Lovely aroma of American hops, notes of citrus and tropical fruits, hints of pine forest. The hoppy flavour has notes of pine and grapefruit, and is fairly dry. Bitter aftertaste. Quite good.

Bottle @ Sorbon, Bromma July 30 2011. Red, amber colored beer with a slightly off-white head. Smell sweet, fruit, hops and grapefruit. Really nice taste of hops, fruits and a little sweetness with a bitter finish. Very balanced. Soft carbonation and medium to full body.

Pale ale con gran carga de l√∫pulo,sabor de "s√∫per alpha hops",muy equilibrada.En botella.
Explosion l√∫pulosa,muy bebible,muy buena para maridar.una buena obra.
en tirador excelente!
Otro gran tributo al l√∫pulo!!

Bottle. Nice amber pour, white foam. Aroma of piney hops, lots of fresh centennial hop juice. Taste is bitter, not too powerful, but it has a good hop kick. Pretty dry palate, very well done here, no residual sweetness. Much more of an IPA than a standard pale ale, "it¬ís not normal" as three floyd¬ís admit it themselves. Very tasty, and certainly a perfect example of how the US does IPA.

Bottle.  Pours a murky light brown into the paper cup at my hotel room.  The head is large and cream colored.  Powerful aroma of grass and juniper.  The beer is assertively bitter, but balanced by light sweetness.  Finish is dry and complex, with some bready notes.  More of an IPA than a pale ale, but whatever.  It¬ís phenomenal.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2014 Bottle @ home, courtesy of HandsomeBrew. Awesome extra, thanks again Ben. Transparent, copper appearance with a fairly sizable ivory head. Grapefruit, orange, earthy, sweet hoppy nose that¬ís very inviting. Soft mouth feel. Moderately hoppy, moderately pale malty flavor with lots of grapefruit, light pine, light earth, and citrus fruits. Lightly bitter but fairly grapefruit hoppy aftertaste. What an excellent brew!

Draft at Dexters.  Somehow managed not to rate this one yet.  Filtered amber-brown.  Thin patchy head.  Soapy astringent aroma.  Well done, solid hop forward APA.  Smooth toffee malt backbone.  Zesty and drinkable.  A great APA.

Sampled from bottle with my good friend raveskdr. Poured an amber color, white head. Aroma was almost perfect. Hoppy grapefruit citrus notes, pine, floral notes. Flavor is hoppy fruits, and citrus. I don¬ít know why it took so long to finally have this.

A nice amber colored pour with a medium off-white head. Nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is floral with citrusy hops and malt. Nice malt flavor with citrus hops and pine; nice bitter finish. A good balanced beer.

12oz bottle - thanks Matt! Amber with an off white head. Great hop profile but light, sweet, nice citrus, Good bitterness, very well balanced, grapefruit, no alcohol, very smooth and delicious. Wish this was available as a regular beer here.
Thanks theTomG.  Handily the best IPA I¬íve had to date. (Excluding I/DIPA¬ís)  I¬ím not a huge hop guy but this beer belonged in my mouth.

look: 4  smell: 4.5  taste: 4.5  feel: 4   overall: 4.5

A- Pours a beautiful amber color with nice white head

S- Has a nice ipa aroma to it with some citrus and sweet smells 

T- has a very nice citrus hops flavor throughout. Hints you with some sweet malts and goes down crisp and clean

M- Medium bodied with nice carbonation

D-Over this is an exceptional APA. almost an IPA for me. love the flavors and balance. If you havent had this beer try it. its super tasty

12oz bottle, unknown date.  Big thanks to my boss for picking some up on his recent visit to Chicago.  Served at around 45F.
Pours clear copper amber with a large off white head that leaves tons of rings of sticky lacing and holds a thick cap.  Beautiful to behold.

Aroma is strong on citrus and floral hops with underlying layers of pine and earth.  Some caramel malt and toasted bread as well.  Good to very good strength.

Flavor is again strong on the citrus hops, some tropical fruit, a bit resinous with a good caramel and bready malt backbone with mild sweetness that finishes with good bitterness for a Pale Ale.  Little to no alcohol detected.  Very tasty and immensely drinkable. 

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy, with soft to medium carbonation.

Is this the best Pale Ale I¬íve had?  Yes, yes I think it just may well be.  Damned tasty, aromatic and beautiful to look at and it¬ís going down oh so fast.  Will do my best to savor the rest of the 6-pack since it may be some time before I can try this again.
Pooours a hazyborange with hints of cittrus and pine.  Foamy white head thaat dissaptes quicklyy.  Tastes lke the aroma with hops, a good ale.

Slightly hazy, copper coloured with a medium-sized off-white head. Immensely hoppy flavour with citrus, pine and overripe exotic fruits and some underlying malty notes of toasted bread and caramel. Finish is dry and bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2012 Pours a hazy coppery color with a thick off-white head with lots of lacing.   Aromas of citrus, particularly grapefruit, and pine.   Taste is light sour on the front end and medium bitter on the back end.  To me, this beer has the perfect carbonation as it dances on the tongue and it goes down very smooth with a long, dry finish, as is typical in IPA¬ís.   Overall, this is just a great session beer to drink.  It has everything and IPA lover would want.

From a bottle at a pub-poured out a cloudy amber color.  Nice fizzy bite hits the tongue.  This beer is really hoppy and bitter and leaves a wonderful lingering grapefruit taste.  Outstanding beer-think it will be one of my favorites.

Tap (and cask) @ Three Floyds. Hazy light orange-amber pour with a white head leaving a soapy lace. Pine hop nose, medium body with caramel, toast, spruce, grapefruit and umami - nicely balanced and quite smooth. Finish is short and dry.
Cloudy dark orange with a big off-white head. Aroma is caramel and very hoppy - grapefruit and pine. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 010611

A:  Pours a nice amber color with a thick, creamy beige head.

S:  Some citrus hops with some caramel and malt.

T:  The sweetness is well balanced with the bitterness of the citrus hops.  Notes of caramel malts.  

M:  Smooth, drinkable, clean finish.

O:  For a style I usually do not enjoy, this was one of the better beers I have had in this style.  A great summer beer.  I could see myself drinking a few of these at a session.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2012 70 years ago in the middle of a song Fats Waller exclaimed "¬íTain¬ít nothin¬í wrong with that ... nothing ¬ítall".  I like this beer almost as much as I love Fats Waller.  Normally I prefer darker, more complicated beers and jazz (Russian Imperial Stout, Thelonious Monk, Bitches Brew, Porter or King Porter Stomp)  but I can¬ít find anything negative at all about this pale ale.  Yes, it¬ís pure hoppiness but very refreshing and not at all skunky.  I drove to Hammond, IN to pick up a six pack of this for the weekend and will definitely make that drive again, since it¬ís nowhere to be found on the South Side of Chicago.

Edited 12/11/12
This was one of the first beers that wowed me when I was new to this site and gave it a gushing review.  SInce then, it has become more available, and I have found a few worthy competitors.  Alpha King is still as good as ever, and is the flagship beer of FFF. and is still one of my all time favorites and my favorite APA.  This lower revision only puts it in the perspective of over 500 beers I¬íve reviewed since my initial 4.9
The king of hops.  This stuff will knock you out with hop flavor, but being the hop-head I am, this stuff does the trick.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2015 I remember the first time I had this beer, I was utterly blown away like never before. It¬ís very crisp, very balanced, very assertive, and very American. The hop character is dominant but not overwhelming, since the malt backbone is strong enough to sustain it, besides providing a nutty touch that perfectly complements the piney aroma from the hops. The body is medium and perfectly carbonated, making for an extremely refreshing drink. This might be the perfect marriage between flavor and drinkability. Amazing APA and amazing beer overall. It is the perfect for a spring or summer afternoon. God I wish we had it here in Texas.

Great beer with amazing aroma, lacing, and EXPLOSIVE hoppy flavor. Although the hop presence is very well done, it is also exceedingly cloying. I enjoyed one. . .  then another . . . and then I had heartburn . . .

Bottle... Deep golden pour , mid sized white head , excellent lace .  Huge citrus and pine hop aroma . Sweet caramel malt flavor with peach/grapefruit and pine hop notes . Medium bodied .  Dry , lasting bitter finish . Simple but delicious .

12 oz botte, pours pours a clean amber w/ creamy off-white head, aroma is excellent and assertive balance of citric hops and caramel malt, clean nutty malt and strong hops throughoutwith lingering bitterness, as close to a perfect APA as I¬íve had

On tap at DLD. Pours translucent dark yellow with a finger wide white head. Aroma is filled with citrus and light fruit notes. Taste is a tad bitter throughout but with sweet caramel and orange/lemon zest thrown in. Medium bodied, well carbonated, good mouth-feel.

Muffig hopfig, gleichsam auch malziger Antrunk. Der Hopfen wird zwar st√§rker, bleibet aber muffig, das malz wird dagegen schw√§cher. Das Bier insgesamt ist in Ordnung, wirkt aber auch wegen der Trockenheit eint√∂nig. Erdig zum Ende, eine leichte Whiskeynuance ist vorhanden. Geht in Ordnnung. 7/9/8/9/10/8

Apr 23, tap @ 3F brewbar. Pours clear dark golden with small off white head leaving nice lace. Soapy, floral, hoppy and malty aroma. Citric medium mouthfeel. Citric, piny, malty, slightly sweet and floral flavor. Nice acidy bitter palate. Finishes dry and bitter; very nice.
On tap at Dark Lord Day. Very fruity/citrusy with plenty of hop backbone. Absolutely fantastic APA. I would have liked to take a 6 pack home with me.

Tried at DLD ¬í11 for the first time thanks to scott for getting this one. It smelt very fruity. it was a nice citrus fruit, really quite good. Nice hopiness to it. I could see myself drinking this all day in fact.

Deep amber, sweet toffee and interesting hops in the aroma.  Way too sweet, crystally and caramelly taste, lots of rose petals and citrus, cloying and sticky - not very drinkable - but saved by a moderate bitterness and some interesting oily, zesty hops at the end.  Cut out most of the crystal and it¬íd be great.
UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 Hands down one of the best APA¬ís around. Has everything an APA should have. The added hops is balanced perfectly with the malts in it. Fantastically citric. Awesome beer
POurs deep amber with citrus notes right off the bat.  The medium to heavy beer rolls right into a blast of citrus and spiced hops.  It packs a wollop!

Bottle thanks to the guys in Amon Amarth!Sampled on April 22, 2011. Golden to amber color, white head. Hoppy citrus scent and taste. Smooth mouthfeel and fairly high bitterness. Very drinkable, even to me that don¬ít like too bitter beers. The alcohol kicks in though, felt more than 6.5% ABV.

Call me biased because I grew up drinking the Floyds, but if I honestly had to pick just one beer to drink for the rest of my life, this is it. Hands down.  Huge citrus hop aroma, rich amber color, and full-bodied satisfying mouthfeel with a huge caramel backbone to balance the massive amount of hops.  This beer defines the American Pale Ale style.

12 oz  bottle from Antioch Wines...pours beautiful amber; thin head and nice lacing.  Great hoppy nose; citrus taste and after taste.  Both great look and greater taste....can¬ít believe I¬íve been drinking this all this time and never rated it....happy there are more in the ¬ífrig....

12 oz. bottle, split with manuchampions, pours dark golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is much like an IPA, with citrus hops, strong floral notes and caramel. Flavour is again, on the fence of being an APA and a lighter IPA, with floral notes jumping out, followed by bold citrus hops (for the style) and caramel malt backing. Nothing revolutionary, but for the style, it¬ís hard to find better ones out there.

Draft at The Map Room, Chicago. Dark ruby-orange, beautiful pour. Smooth hoppy-citrus nose. So well balanced - big hops, a bit juicy but full, not cloying, complete malting. Great example of mid-west IPA. Really terrific.
Good beer. Very hoppy slightly bitter. This is a staple beer round here. Just don¬ít quite love it.

Copper amber with very little head and no lacing. A bit of sweet maltiness in the aroma as well as some tropical fruit and pine. Taste is a nice balance of mildly sweet malts and floral hops. Low carbonation and body. Quite drinkable, but nothing exceptional.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2014 Pours a lustrous orange with a shiny white cap.  Good lacing.

The aroma is dominated by hops with bright orange-tangerine and freshly cut grass notes taking the forefront.  However, there¬ís a nicely doughy caramel malt backbone holding up that hoppiness.  This beer definitely straddles the line between APA and IPA.

The taste is also much bigger than your average APA.  It has marvelous balance, starting with malt sweetness and smoothly transitioning to hop bitterness in the finish.  It¬ís very, very easy to drink.

The beer has a round, full feel that never gets too heavy.  Flavor fills your mouth with each sip, but it finishes clean, light and in need of another quaff.

Pour deep orange/amber nice off white head terrific lacing. Aroma citrus, peaches, pineapple, mango, caramel, pine. Taste nice big bitterness but well balanced by caramel and sweetness, pine, citrus, mango, grapefruit, honey, tangerine. MF medium sticky body nice carb. Hands down one of the best APA¬ís available.

12 oz bottle from Downer Wine and Spirits.  Pours a light amber color with a white head and some lacing.  Aroma is hoppy, citrus.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is a perfect balance of malt and hops.  The best pale ale, period.

Big thanks to Brad for this one. Very dark pour for a pale ale - a ruddy honey-amber, with a mid-size tan head that dissipates fairly quickly. Slightly hop-forward, though it¬ís really just more well balanced than anything. Pine resin and mandarin rind are balanced by honey and a bit of butterscotch. Brilliantly big and thick for something that¬ís less than 7%, with a strong hop presence throughout, especially on the lovely bitter aftertaste. This is one I¬íd be buying sixers of *very* regularly if we could only find them out west...

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2011 12 oz  Bottle.  Appearance is dark orange, almost amber color with light head.  Aroma is heavily citrus, especially peach and orange, but also with some resin and pine hints.  Taste is dominated by the citrus with peach and a bitter grapefruit come out on top.  There is also a subtle sweetness and hay malt flavor that gives this beer a nice complexity.  The hop bitterness is particularly prevalent making this beer, in my opinion, more like an IPA than a mere Pale Ale.  The palate is light to medium bodied, rather dry, and easy bitter aftertaste.  Although the bitter and dry character of the beer is heavy, it is a very drinkable brew.

Poured into a snifter. Alpha King pours a reddish amber color, with an off-white head that drops quickly. Really nice lacing. Great hop aroma..very floral, citrusy and piney. Taste starts with an iced tea, malty background, with a very nice hoppy twang that reminds me of centennial and cascade. Mouthfeel is smooth and a little dry. Light mouthfeel as well. I could drink a ton of these if only Three Floyds was in Florida. Very nice American Pale Ale.
Smells a  big like a cross between a lime and a mango. Has an almost amber look to it. Very good flavor, easy to drink. Medium body with a smooth sweet finish. This really is a high quality beer.

12oz bottle. Dark amber color with a thin bubbly head. Slight spotty lacing. Aroma is hoppy and little citrusy. Flavor has hints of hops with a nice malt backing. Nothing super heavy, but a good balance of flavors.

Aroma: floral and citrus hop aromas dominate, but a big malt note follows.  Toasty with some caramel aromas.
Appearance: amber-copper color, mostly clear.  Thick white head with good retention and lots of lacing.
Flavor: very good balance between malt and hops; nice citrus flavors and hop bitterness, bitterness is very pleasant and not overwhelming.  Great malt backbone to balance the bitterness; caramel, bread, and toasty notes.
Palate: medium body and carbonation, very smooth and silky mouthfeel, slight stickiness with a mildly sweet finish.
Overall: great pale ale, somewhat hop-forward, but the balance is outstanding; really tasty malt profile, highly recommended beer.

Pours a nice orangeish-copper with little to no head (quickly dissipates). Floral, citrus aromas and a nice, bitter grapefruity flavor. I¬íve had worse, but I¬íve also had better. Not a bad beer by any means.
Pours a light amber color, had a pleasant hop smell. Had an alright bitterness to it.

Bottle. Pours a copper color with a frothy beige head. Aroma is very grapefruity with citrus, tropical fruit and caramel malts. Flavor is again fairly hoppy with grapefruit, citrus, honey, but also some sweet and caramelly malts. The body is light to medium with a dry, yet smooth mouthfeel. Overall a good APA, but not as good as its hyped up to be. (maybe I got a slightly old bottle).

Bottle at Brewdog Bar, Aberdeen. It pours mahogany with a thin off-white head and low-moderate carbonation. The nose is wood, polish, resin, peach and pineapple. The taste is varnish, resin, grapefruit, lemon, lime, orange peel, watermelon, wood and some caramel with a moderate bitter finish. I found it a bit too thin and a bit rough around the edges. I am left feeling a little bit disappointed...

355mL bottle.  Pours clear amber-gold with no head.  Aroma of caramel, honey, citrus and wood.  Flavours of toast, a little smoke, sweet fruit, some citrus, slightly woody, mild sweetness and bitterness.  Medium bodied, very soft carbonation, fairly slick with a drying finish.

Pours dark amber but you can see through the beer still (not cloudy).  Aroma is heavy with tropical fruits of mango and pineapple--real nice.  Taste has a real bite of hops to it.  This is bitter--it¬ís more of an ipa.   Lasting and developing citrus bitter grapefruit finish that has an focus on the hops, finishes bitter with sweetness of tropical fruit syrup..  The first time I had this it gave me the offical ¬íhopburp¬í which is enjoyable from this brew, and hence my user name.  I likey
Yes this is a good beer. I¬ím a big fan of IPAs and this one has it all there. Very hoppy lots of citrus in it which is what I like about these beers. Worth buying a few of these.

355ml bottle bought at √òlbutikken in Copenhagen and stored in my cellar for about nine months. Deep amber with ruby shades. Persistent, rocky off-white head. Perfumed fruity hops to the nose. Spicy and succulent fruits in flavour, a fine blend of oranges and grapefruits, and a touch of sweet malts beneath. Lingering, smooth bitter finish. Medium bodied. Well made pale ale with perfect drinkability (joy on a Friday eve at home in Troms√∏, 18.02.2011).

Some bar in Evanston: Pours a very nice light copper color with a white head. Aroma of citrusy hops kind of explodes your face. How this beer is different from an IPA is sort of hard to say (as there are beers that are labeled IPAs that taste pretty similar), but in any case, there is a lot of bitterness, yet the bitterness does not overkill and linger for too long, instead it leaves an impact and then kind of goes its own way. The real beauty of this beer is in the balance. The body is light enough to enjoy these at length and the flavors all work together quite perfectly. The hops are blended in such a way that basically makes this a superior APA. A lot has been said about this beer, but let me just reiterate: it¬ís good.
One of the best IPAs. Very smooth and keeps you curious, kind of ruins you from enjoying the sea of mediocre IPA out there. HIghyl recommended

Bottle. Also my first FFF beer. Pours deep but clear amber. The head is almost tan and laces very nice on the glass. The aroma is citrus and just smells awesome. The taste is very balanced as far as the malt and hops. Make no mistake, this is hoppy beer, but not overly done to be too bitter. Great beer.

My first 3 floyds beer didnt disappoint! Pours a reddish amber with a thick off white head. Nice lacing. The smells detected are piny hops, citrus, and small doses of sweet malts. Taste is the some very hoppy and citrusy. Great hop profile for a standard pale ale!  Medium bodied easy drinker with lots of flavor. A+ on this one!

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2014 Pours a beautiful amber with a deep beige head. Aroma of pine, nice sharp hops, citrus, grapefruit and floral/earthy notes. Taste is hoppy with nice fresh fruits, citrus, grapefruit, lime peel and with some grassy notes in the background.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2012 For the style this is one of the best. I have had it in the bottle and on tap. It isn¬ít super-hoppy, but for being a mere pale ale it is packed with fresh hops and a medium bitterness.
I¬íve had some in Bloomington, Chicago, at home and at 3 Floyds tasting.  one of my favorite pale ales, with very strong hop character.  If I see it, I buy it.

From notes:

Pours a hazy, dark golden orange/amber color with a two finger frothy, pillowy off-white head that has excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap. Large chunks of soapy lacing are left coating the glass.

Sweet citrus hop aroma with hints of earthy pine and tropical fruit. Subtle malt backbone but the nose of this beer is all about the hops with lots of grapefruit, citrus peel, mango and pineapple.

Medium bodied and very hop forward for the style with a blast of bitter, earthy hops that are countered by sweet citrus presence and a subtle malt backbone. Hints of pine needle, grapefruit, citrus peel, mango and pineapple as well as a subtle biscuit/graham cracker flavor that provides nice balance. This beer is much closer to an IPA than a pale ale with lots of oily, resinous hop flavor and a nice dry finish. Complex, well balanced and extremely quaffable. Recommended.
A beer that deserves a taste. For sure one of the better pale ales I have had. It has a not quite amber color, but just a little darker. A beer that everyone should love.
Very good pale ale, with a very bitter kick that stays on the palate. While pale ales are known to be bitter, this was a bit too much.
Copper color in the glass. Bright citrus hop aroma. Body on the lighter side, nice caramel malt and hops. Great pale ale.

Bottle. bought from Brewdog.com 

Appearance s red-bronze-copper, lacing simmered down really quickly so can¬ít really comment there, aroma is sweet marzepan, rye bread, candi sugar, pine amongst some big hops. Taste is grapefruit, marzepan, Swedish rye bread, wood, oak, some lemon-tart, apricots, plums and sweet dried fruits. 

Combination is very interesting and not aggressive. The mix is excellent and the balance is very good, interesting bitterness. Can¬ít think of another other than Victory for a bitterness of comparison.

I love this method of a APA and this is certainly much more complex and less fruit heavy than I had imagined. I can see why this gets high praise. Certainly interesting and very very refreshing, I can ride out the storm with this.
355ml bottle. Tanx to Micke!! Pours cloudy copper. Nose is from exotic fruits and hops. Flavor is well balanced between the hops and malt. A very enjoyable beer!

Got a sixer of this in a trade with slater1313. Poured into a pint glass.

4.5 A: Clear orange amber. Two fingers of dense head with good retention and plenty of lacing.

4.5 S: Lots of raw hop aroma. Citrus and floral in nature, the hops block out most of the malt character, but there still is a bit of fruitiness to it.

4.0 T: Lots of hop flavor now. It actually tastes like I¬ím drinking liquified hops (though not mindblowingly intense). I guess what distinguishes this from an IPA is that, for as much hop content there is, there is relatively little bitterness compared to the total amount of hops used. Anyway, this beer is mildly bitter with citric and mild piney hop flavor. Malt character takes a background seat to the hop flavor. This beer is pretty damn good, but it lacks some complexity from the malt perspective. Malts lend a pinch of fruitiness and there is definitely some crystal malt present.

3.5 M: Medium body and a little lighter than I think it should be. Very smooth, but slightly undercarbonated.

4.5 D: I can deal without the complexity in the malts because the hops taste so damn good. Therefore, this beer is extremely drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-09-2009 23:30:11

Pours a cloudy orange-amber with <1/2 finger head. Smell is hoppy¬ñ pine and citrus, with caramel and biscuit malts. Taste is the same but kicked up a bit and more enjoyable; very well balanced. Smooth mouthfeel, medium body and carbonation.
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2011 Tried it first in Chicago.  Made an immediete impression.  When I drove to WI to buy Dogfishhead and saw it i was thrilled.  Wonderful caramel colored pale ale.

Toasty hay aroma. Lots of floral and citrus notes as well. Medium sweetness, with heavy bitter flavor balanced well with a nice sour character and a great smooth finish that balances all the flavors. Great great IPA!!!
Cask at fountainhead. Aroma is citrus. Flavor is citrus and pine. Hop bitterness is balanced nicely with a malty caramel base. Nice beer. Wouldn¬ít call it a "pale ale" though.

Dark amber color and clear, wispy but thin head.  Very hoppy smell.  Citrus like grapefruit. Pear. Also some piney notes.  Caramel malt. Good amount of sweetness. Nice hop bitterness. More citrus flavor and Pear. Very balanced.  Light body. Some carbonation and some dryness.

Bottle. Deep amber with brown hints, off-white head, slight lacing. Nose is orange and slight pine, with big floral and dirt notes. Big hops on the tongue, followed by citrus, pine, and an evasive nuttiness. Dry, spicy finish.

Pours deep reddish amber with thick white head. Tons of lacing and slow to dissipate. Aroma is oranges, lemon, lime, floral, and maybe some cherry. The first sip is moderately sweet with an almost full body. Any malt flavor is quickly eradicated by bitter, palate busting hops. Grapefruit flows down the throat and lingers for what feels like forever.
Any alcohol is hidden.

Bottle at the Crazy Horse in Bloomington. Pours a medium amber color with a slight haze, decent sized white head that lingers around till the end. Big citrus hops in the nose, candied pineapple, sweet caramel malt. Medium bodied, good carbonation, and a lasting finish. Big hop flavor - lot¬ís of fruitiness - of grapefruit and pineapple. A generous amount of caramel malt to sweeten and check an assertive bitterness. As much as this beer is hopped, I¬íd expect it to be an IPA rather than an APA. The style doesn¬ít seem quite right. It certainly is a beer for hop lovers, though.

Bottle from Ericandersnavy, thanks! Amber color. Grapefruit, lemon, melon and oily hops in the aroma. Oily hops, plastic, melon, lemon and pineapple in the flavor. Long oily hoppy aftertaste. Well made!

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a small white head leaving lots of small specks of  lacing all over the glass.  Aroma is strong with grapefruit hops, light pine, orange, and caramel malt.  Initial taste is grapefruit hops, pine, and orange.  Finish is mostly caramel malt with decent bitterness.  Medium body.  Medium carbonation.  Great beer.
UPDATED: JUL 11, 2012 Comes through with amazing aroma and blows other Pales out of the water with overall balance and taste. Delicious.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with Sean. Pours a bright, glowing orange with a small, tightly-bubbled off-white head. Nice lacing throughout. Aroma of pine, honey, grapefruit, and some subtle caramel notes. Medium bodied with a smooth, soft, almost creamy palate. Finishes with a crisp, tight, dryness. Great brew. Really amazing stuff. I wish I could drink a six pack of this.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a hazy amber with a 1 finger head that disappears after a few moments. Leaves a fair amount of lacing on the glass.

The smell is full of citrus hops. Very pleasant. I also pick up faint smell of a caramel type of malt.

This beer tastes like a beefed up version of the Pride and Joy. Hint of a caramel type sweetness in the malts with a very nice kick of hops with a slight piney-ness and and citrus. Think grapefruit.

Feels light and is very drinkable.

Overall, this beer is great! Highly recommended. As mentioned, it tastes like a beefed up Pride and Joy. A little more hop presence which is great. I definitely would choose this over the Pride and Joy if both are available.
Nose is fresh, bitter hops, red grape, late grass, feel is mediumbroad, carb is medium lively, taste is fresh bitter hops, menthol, weak late Grass and heavy chalk.

Cask. Coppery orange brown color, and a bit darker than expected with little to no head.  Completely still.  Citrusy and dank hops in the aroma and carry onto the flavor in the same fashion.  Oily and medium body with barely any carbonation...cask of course.  Citrusy and piney dry finish, with some tea-like qualities as well.  Delicious on cask, and better than the bottled version.

From bottle. Pours ruby amber with medium sized soapy tan head.  Slightly astringent, long, bitter finish. Almost an IPA to me.  Outstanding for a pale ale, with some caramel malt backbone evident.  Delicious flavor.  A great go-to repeater if you are in a place that sells it.

Pours a dark color for its style, color is somewhat of a caramel amber. The scent is initially some clear hops followed up by a pretty decent malt backbone. The taste increases on both of these, with quite a bit of hops coming through for the style. The mouthfeel is that of a medium body and moderate carbonation--fairly full-bodied for the style. Drinkability is supreme--my go to all-night beer back when I lived in Chicago.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2010 12 oz bottle purchased at a liquor store whose name I can¬ít remember near my hotel in Indianapolis. This was the quarry that got me the most excited about my trip to the Hoosier State, and - while the bottles I found are rather forlorn and probably none too fresh - they live up to the brewer¬ís reputation. This poured a deep amber, as best I could tell in the opaque paper cups at the Super 8 (more money for beer!), and managed to lace even this meager, disposable excuse for glassware. The aroma of fresh, almost wet hops pervaded my nose even before I poured the beer, though, and carried on into the flavor where it interacted nicely with a strong, toasty malt profile. At various points, this tasted like a standard APA, an IPA, and an Oktoberfest, which is to say that it was surprisingly complex for such a sessionable apa. Its reputation appears both well-deserved and assured of continuation. UPDATE: I had a couple of more from the 6 pack tonight and - though still disappointingly stale - they are certainly richer and more complex than I credited last night. This rating puts them in line with reasonable peers.

Thanks to Pellinore1 for sending me this bottle. I had been wanting to try this for quite some time. 

The beer pours an amber color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the citrus hops with some bready malt and sugar notes. 

The flavor is bread and oranges. The orange is both juicy and pithy and is very well done. Low bitterness. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
I love this beer its my go to IPA great all around flavor smell and appearance.Dont miss out if you havent tried it yet!
Bottle - Pours medium red with a 2 finger tan head.  Floral and citrus aroma is abundant.  Taste is phenomenal, very balanced huge flavor.  Very smooth and complex.  Highly recommended.
36cl, American brew, thx to Wimenels!, complex bitter brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, small head, good brew

12 oz bottle courtesy of BeerandIT. Poured a dark rich amber with two fingers¬í worth of foam, which did not last too long. Aroma is heavy on the citrus and a bit of spice. Taste is certainly hoppy, particularly very much concentrated on resin and citrus. A fair amount of malts keep this beeer from being too bitter, and make it a bit more balanced. The citrus lingers heavily on the aftertaste. This is an extremely well balanced APA. Probably one of the best out there.

12 oz. bottle from Woodman¬ís in Madison, WI.  Pours amber with a thin off-white head.  The aroma is grapefruit rind, pineapple, peach syrup, and fresh cut grass.  The flavor is agressively bitter yet very well balanced and drinkable.  If this were the typical pale ale there would be a very blurry line between APA and IPA.  Top of its class.

Wow this is the most pure balanced beautiful example of what an American Pale Ale should be.  From the beautiful darker golden brown color to the mouth feel with slight carbonation this beer has it all.  Nice amount of head just over a quarter of an inch.  I can taste nice bread notes with just the right amount of hops mixing in.  I could drink this beer all night it is just that good.  Leaves your palate feeling renewed and awakened the hops and malt blending together perfectly.  Honestly there are no words really for this pale ale as it is epic.  You must try this one.

On tap at Hop Leaf Chicago. Surprisingly dark copper. Soft fruity hop and caramel aroma, not as in-your-face as Emmitt¬ís or even Daisy Cutter. I thought this beer would blow them away, but it isn¬ít in the aroma category. Flavours are sweet caramel with soft tropical fruit and dried leaves. I¬ím not sure about the stellar reviews Three Floyd¬ís receives for some of their brews. This one, along with Gumball Head, just didn¬ít thrill me.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Red amber pour with a minimal white head.

Aroma is caramel, dates, figs, dried apricots and pine. Fruity and leafy with lots of aroma hops.

Taste has a balanced sweetness that works perfectly with the other flavours like resin, grapefruit, earthyness, and floral notes. Quite complex hoppiness.

It¬¥s medium bodied and has a  long aftertaste. The best pale ale I¬¥ve had by far.

Had this in a blind tasting with The delightful Drbayern, Brian the Beer Pimp, Uncle Ste3ve and Uncle Tom!  Abd Barrister Bob was there too!  Poured with a good floral aroma, provided a good lace on the edge.  Really loved the hop taste, loved teh mouthfeel too!  Aftertaste left me wanting more!  My highest scoring beer of the night, just ahead of Uncle Tom¬ís Home Brew, Who Farted barlywine!

On the beer engine at the Map Room in Chicago.  Very solid beer. Strong hops, but not overpowering, well balanced by caramel and malt flavors. Bitter and dry on the finish.  Enjoyed the cask treatment of it, a little more mellow and flavorful than the regular keg (sampled side by side).

Bottle.  Pours a hazy copper-orange color. Thin white head that dissipates to a thin white ring. Aroma is lots of piney hops up front, with some sweet caramel and grassy notes. Flavor is lots of grassy and citrusy hops, with mild caramel sweetness. Medium, slightly fizzy mouthfeel.  Some lingering bitterness in the finish. Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2011 Smells citrusy, Centennial really comes through, as well as some caramel notes. Off-white frothy head, incredible lacing. Deep amber. Full of flavor, lasting hop presence. Great carbonation, medium bodied. One of my favorite beers of all time, a pleasant experience every time. Just enough of a malt backbone to provide rich flavor and body but with enough of a hop flavor to balance it and create a wonderful finish. Hops give a big, juicy tangerine flavor. Too tasty.

Pours an attractive copper color with a full thick creamy head.  Thick sheets of lacing are left behind clinging to the sides of the glass.  Smells of glorious hops giving off aromas of piney citrus fruits and a nice earthiness.  A slight bitter, the finish is a little bitter.  A nice malt backbone.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to the Cad.Dark amber with a thin white head. Straight forward big malt and hops, rather thin in the flavour. Some cardboard and sweetness. Lots of bitterness but it¬ís all killed rather quickly by the epic sweetness. Some fruit, sticky hops. My god this is over rated. A good beer, no doubt. Far from a great one.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2017 This is good, however (and I may be in the minority here) but Three Floyds sometimes has a tendency to go a bit mental with the hops. Very hoppy, I don¬ít mind hops but this can be unbalanced. However once your through the first pint it gets much better. Now that being said I still think this is very good.  Serving: Tap, bottle and cask
On tap at Mikkeller bar. Red/orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is hop, grapefruit, peaches. Flavour is sweet, hop, malt, berries, spices,  peaches. Nice beer.

One of my favorites, no matter the category.  Pours a dark amber.  Great but subdued hop flavor.  Not "in your face" like some hoppy beers.  Too easy to drink, which means I alway feel like another one after it¬ís done :)
An incredible beer wish that they serviced the Metro Detroit area. Got it on tap at the brewery. This beer is a most have for anyone who enjoys American IPA¬ís.

A hoppy floral hits you first as you first take in this amber and slightly hazy brew.  It has a minimal head with a slightly tan foam that doesn¬ít build too high.  For such a highly hopped beer it has only a medium bitterness and medium body.  The taste has a slick feel and a long hoppy finish.  Overall a wonderful beer.  I wish we could buy in our market.  Fortunately my son is in Chicago and I can pick it up there.
One of my favorites. Appearance is dark amber/red. creamy head.  taste is caramel, sugars, some hoppy fruits, and citrus.  Bitter and medium bodied for the style.  Great beer.

Poured 12oz bottle into tulip glass.  Nice amber color, with a thin off white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is hops and citrus...very appealing.  The mouthfeel is good, not too thick or too thin.  Very nice.  Taste is hops up front, and lingering bitterness in the finish.  This is a solid beer that delivers right from the start.  A little heavy for a session, but tasty enough you wish you could have 4-5.  Very good beer...worth the hype.  Wish it had a better distribution.

The aroma is hops, citrus. The color is a golden brown clear, almost amber. The head is off white mostly diminishing and excellent lacing. The taste is bitter. The body is medium to full, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish bitter. a very good beer.
Aroma of pine, color of muddy brown. Hecent head, lots of hops (expected), a slight cereal aftertaste. Will be buying again, very tasty, goes good with a burger and fries.
12 ounce bottle .A dark orange-brown pour-beige head. Aroma and taste of caramel ,citrus,slightly roasty, -Dry bitter hoppy finish
Bottled. Amber reddish colour. Huge bitterness with awesome malt backing. Great head retention and overall balance for the style.

great aroma, very complex fruitiness with citrus piney hop notes.  I can¬ít figure out exactly what fruits are in the aroma and taste but i¬íd ballpark it with orange/mango/apricot/nectarine and maybe grapefruit.  There is also a nice roasted malt flavor and a satisfying dry hop bite.  I also tasted coffee in the aftertaste.  pours beautifully, looks amazing.  clean refreshing palate.  A very nice beer.  I would call it crazy for being a pale ale, but it¬ís also amazing so who cares?
Poured from 12oz bottle, aroma is much more hoppy than I was expecting with a little spice to it, overall this is a very good pale ale!

On Draft at FFF:  Amber pour, with a mild white head. Smells of Piney hops, with flavors of piney hops, grapefruit, orange, and caramel? Taste is light, and bitter for sure. Admittedly I have an affinity it seems for hopped up brews, but this brew is incredible, bitterness aside.

12 oz. bottle from Three Cellars. Wow, i finally get to try this. Transparent brown appearance that carries a thin and wispy head. Nothing special to look at, but decent. There is a decent balance between the malts and hops, but honestly, the malts seem to be dominating a bit here. It seems to me as though this is turning into an aged version of the beer i.e. it¬ís starting to carry some barley wine-like qualities. It¬ís quite pungent, but it lacks the crazy hop aroma I was expecting, albeit, it is quite malty. A bit of malt sweetness and light hops provide a great balance. A bit of pine hops coming through. Meh...this beer is decent, but it doesn¬ít deserve it¬ís spot, in terms of rating. It¬ís not bad, and I¬ím not trying to be hard on this, but it¬ís rating(s) are a bit inflated. It has a nice malt flavor, but the balance is skewed.
Overall this is a very solid beer. Pours a slightly hazy amber and smells hoppy and spicy. Nothing about it is over powering. Also solid session beer and very easy to drink.

12 oz. bott.e.  Pours a clear red amber.  Aroma of piney hops mainly with a touch of citrus and floral hops.  Tastes of hops balanced nicely with some sweet caramel malt.  Did I say well balanced?  Great.

Bottle: Pours a clear copper with a small ivory head. The aroma is not as intense as I expected. The taste is slightly bitter but about perfect for the style. I get some citrus and a little pine from the hops and a slightly sweeter taste than some west coast APA/IPAs. This has a light to medium mouth feel which feels just right. Overall this is a very good beer but my palate favors a slightly different combination of ingredients.
Well balanced aroma.  Golden-copper color.  Well done American Pale Ale moderation/balanced hop/malt are key.
Amazing, deep citrus and bright melon aroma, totally inviting. Perfect flavor match with an intense but smooth dry finish.

Bottle courtesy of wavers1, thanks buddy!  This pours a dark orange/copper with a decent white head, faded quickly.  Head was sticky and left some lace.  Aroma is beautiful, big citrus, a bit of sweetness and and some resin.  The first sip let loose some super clean hop flavors, citrusy and piney.  This stuff drinks super smooth with a perfect subtle bitterness in the finish.  Slick oily mouthfeel, medium body.  Wow, this stuff is close to perfection when it comes to an APA.  Nothing overpowering here, just a perfect use of hop flavors.  Balanced is an understatement.  My first from FFF.

Pours dark amber with a nice white head and good lacing.  Sweet hoppy aroma.   beautifully balanced, wet and long lasting taste.  Hops provide much character nicely played against caramel.  Finish is pleasant but not terribly powerful.  The best APA I¬íve ever had.

Bottle.  Pours a clear light brown with a short-lived white head.  Nose is citrusy, some caramel malt, sweet.  Medium body, lots of citrusy hoppy bitterness, some nice caramel and toffee notes, well-balanced with the malts.  Finishes with the bitterness of an ipa, stronger malts.  A great example of what a pale ale can be.
One of my favorite pale ales.  Dark amber with a nice head.  Big hop aroma.  Nice bitterness balanced with a nice sweet malt.  Excellent
Not too much head or lacing, Hoppy, smooth balance, almost like an IPA, the very essence of excellence, medium orange color. 4 of my Chicago 10 trip July 2010.  96%
pours reddish with a medium head.  quite flavorful and strong for only 6% abv.  a bit citrusy and sweet with good hops.  very good.

Not bad for a pale ale, if your into that sorta thing.  Pours a deep amber color with a decent head.  The aroma is sweet malt and citrus.  A robust flavor which is well balanced with sweet malt.  The taste is hops and citrus with a hint of grapefruit.  Would like to try a pint or two at the brewery..

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho. Huge hop aroma, medium body, a little dark and big for a pale ale, but still amazing. body had lots of depth, toffee, caramel, bitterness was perfect in conjunction. great beer.

Citrus and sweet malt aroma. Pours with a decently thick head that dissipates. Taste of citrus and sweet malt begin the sip, which is later finished by a hoppy bitterness...possibly even a note of dried corn kernel. Very solid choice for a pale ale, but finishes a bit more bitter than I expected.

I can see why this beer is at the top of the Pale Ale world, though I would take Dale¬ís Pale Ale over this offering, the Alpha King is nearly in a league of its own. A hazy ruby red, medium body supports a decent tan head that disappears quickly. Like the best pale ales, Alpha King has an excellent citrus, sweet grapefruit taste that is detectable through a perfectly balanced malty caramel background. This beer is super refreshing, and a six pack could be gone after a session for sure!
Bottle (Beers of Summer at OTH). Pours light brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma is a good amount of pine and citrus fruits. Flavor is same as aroma. Medium bodied. Really good IPA.

tasted this excellent brew at the Beer of Summer event at oldsmar tap house. Pours a burnt orange with a light white head. Rich aroma with citrus, grapefruit, piney notes. Taste is pretty awesome with citrus sugary grapefruit, caramel malts. Palate is good with a medium mouthfeel, alcohol warms you up a bit. This is how a pale ale should be. Awesome beer.
Bottle from Cavie and Sprinkle.  Reddish pour with a white head.  Aroma is fruit hops, sweet, and a little toffee.  Taste is bitter, pine, and a little citrus.

Bottle courtesy of Sprinkle! Clear reddish orange color.  Quite hoppy aroma. Smells of citrus, pine, earth and wonder. Fruit on the flavor. Dry bitter fruit with hops that just keep going. Very nice most certainly.
Courtesy of Cavie.  Smells of hops, has a reddish/brown color.  Strong hops taste, but not overbearing.
Draft. Brown,gold,red color. White lacing.  Carmel, citrus, slight pepper spice. Pine citrus nose with carmel malts.  Sticky.  Medium carbonation.

21-jun-2010,  bottle @home, from "√òlbutikken".
Brownish orange with white head.
Lovely hoppy nose, loads of citrus with a flowery side as well.
Very long aftertaste, quite a bit of malt - this is more like an IPA, and in the malty style that I like.I can understand why this can be the best APA - simply put it is an IPA:)

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2013 Pours a light brown with a good head. Very smooth hoppy aroma. Good flavor. Good IPA. (From June 19, 2010) One of the first beers I rated, I thought it deserved a 2013 refresh. Clear amber on tap at the grafton. No head. Hoppy delicious aroma and bitter hoppy flavor. I wish it had some head though. Leaves a dry hoppy aftertaste that is delightful.

phaleslu is my best friend that I¬íve never actually met.  I¬íll look up the style ratings when I¬ím done with this, and if Alpha King isn¬ít the highest rated Pale Ale, I¬íll be shocked.  Copper with strong lace.  Nose caramel and vanilla and a bit of funkiness/skunkiness.  Resin?   Light sweet fruitiness.  Taste has a nice yeasty hoppy sharpness in the front.  Light and sweet in the mouth.  Sharp gooey finish.  Long lingering bitterness. Damn nice beer.

Great pale ale.  Manages to have great flavor without being overwhelming or buising.  Pours red gold and clear.  Great hop nose.  Sweet and strong (was served warm, guessing it would be less sweet cold) with bright hop flavors.  It¬ís well balanced and sweet, extremely drinkable.

This one pours a hazy, burnt orange color body topped by a thick, off-white head of foam that slowly receds and leaves a nice sudsy wash of lace behind. The aroma shows a nice mix between bitter grapefruit and floral hops, pine resin, and a the caramel malt base. The flavor follows and shows fresh orange and bitter grapefruit up front along with hints of lemon zest, spices, and plenty of hop bitterness on the back. The caramel malt adds nice balance and smooths things out. The hop are the star here though adding plenty of flavor and complexity. Medium bodied with lively carbonation and very easy to drink with a lingering bitter finish from the hops. This is a great, hoppy pale ale.

Copper gold in the glass.  Healthy head.  Medium sharp hops and a lot of malt character.  Some citrus and pine notes.  Very good beer - amazing how they pull so much malt character into the taste without ruining the hop character.  Love this beer.  Would love it even more fresh on tap.
Draft. Pours amber with a dark head. Flavor is pine and citrus. Very basic, very excellent IPA.

Bottle from √òlbutikken, CPH. Pours deep golden with a inch creamy tanned head. Nice hoppy aroma, pine.Taste is light sweet malts, but the hops make this an outstanding beer, lots of spices, some spearmint. Lingering dry piney finish.

Poured form bottle into my favorite tulip glass. A: Poured a nice reddish brown color with offwhite tan head. About a finger of head.
Hops right off the bat with some sweet undertones
smooth upfront transitioning to the bitter hops afterward. Not as balanced as I would have thought.
Good mouthfeel
A very drinkable APA that goes well on a nice warm day...or any day for that matter!

12oz bottle thanks to Ughsmash 
Appearance: Pours a slightly hazy amber with a nice off-white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Flowery, citrus, caramel and sweet malts 
Taste: Citrus, sweet malts, caramel, pine and some hop bitterness in the finish 
A nice APA.

If I could have one beer for the rest of my life, it would be this one!! Awesome malt and hop characters that are perfectly balanced. I pair this beer with so many foods as well. Call it what you want, and IPA or an APA, this beer is a must have!

From a bottle.  Pours amber with a small white head.  Aroma is malty caramel with grassy hops.  Flavor is similar.  Dominated by caramel with some grassy hops.  Slight citrus and bitterness in the finish, but otherwise this beer is very lacking.  If this is an old bottle then i will have to re-rate it at some point, but if not, then i was thoroughly disappointed with it.

Bottle from √∏lbutikken.
Lovely aroma - malt and hops. Pine forest, dark fruit. Spices and herbs. All the above before the first sip. Lovely complex, yet very drinkabld. Long piney finish. Mint, white pepper.

12oz. Bottle (thanks to trade with phaleslu):  Aroma of crystal malt, hops, pine, and light tropical fruit.  Poured amber in color with a large, creamy, dense, rocky, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Many small particles throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of crystal malt, hops, light pine, slight citrus, slight rye, and hints of Earth and toasting.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Crystal malt, hops, and pine finish is dry.  More of an IPA than an APA.

Bottled. Clear amber color, short head. Aroma of grassy hops, citrus, caramel malt, toffee. Big malty backbone. Quite harsh bitterness. It¬ís ok, but I¬ím very disappointed in the fact this should be the nr1 APA.

Pours an astonishingly clear, only slightly hazy, dark red/copper colour, with a lasting white collar of head that leaves some lacing. Sharp hoppy aroma with notes of caramel, lime, lemon, a little grapefruit, pine, grass and one hell of a floral hop-profile. Taste of some malts, fruits, lime, grapefruit, pine resin, sugar, caramel and a heavy-duty hop finish that is not as bitter as one might anticipate, but rather quite fruity and refreshing. Delicious all-american pale ale!

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2010 Pour is a gorgeous dark orange with all sorts of pretty colors all around the glass.  Beautiful white foam that sticks all over the glass and leaves arguably the nicest lacing I¬íve ever seen.  Nose is a melange of fruits from peaches to mangoes, melons, even some light pineapple notes.  The taste follows up on these fruity flavors but still has a nice slightly sweet malt component of caramel that really helps cut some of the bitterness in the finish.  This beer is full of crazy, delicious flavors and feels wonderful in the mouth.  Incredibly drinkable, with booze that is restrained and a bitterness that doesn¬ít distract from the terrific hop flavors.  This easily rates as one of my favorite beers ever made, and I cannot believe it took me so long to get a bottle and drink it.

Thanks to JMRSN on BA!

Bottled. The aroma has grapefruit, mango, caramel. Clear, amber coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is bitter, sweet, bit sugary, has caramel grapefruit, orange, pine. Bit sticky and sirupy palate. I was expecting something a bit more refreshing. Good beer, but nothing to get overexcited about.

Appearance: Rusty copper orange with little head or lacing.

Smell: Refreshing and delicious! More hop presence than I was expecting from a Pale Ale. Some grapefruit and a slight pine/floral hop smell.

Taste: Amazingly crisp and refreshing with a wonderful hop presence. Not overpowering, but the hops do grab your attention.

Mouthfeel: low carbonation but still an easy drinker.

Drinkability: doesn¬ít get any easier to drink than this. This would go in my permanent rotation if it was readily available on the east coast.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-02-2008
Hazy orange colored brew. Aroma is hopped, peachy and citrus. Flavor is  hoppy, peach, pine and malty. A bit syrupy.

12 oz bottle from the brewery, served in an English pint. Pours clear copper with 5 mm of rocky, tan head. Head fades quickly but leaves some lace. Wow, the aroma is amazing! Big beautiful American hop bouquet--extremely floral with pine and grapefruit--on a background of caramel malts. On the tongue, begins slightly sweet and acidic and gradually becomes moderately bitter. The finish is also long and bitter. On the palate, medium in body with a dry texture and moderate carbonation. Overall, an excellent aromatic pale ale. A very sessionable hoppy beer that shows a good deal of hop complexity without the bitterness of an IPA. One of my favourites, for sure. I just wish that head would stick around a bit longer. 2010-05-14

Hazy orange, tanned head, excellent lacing. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, grapefruit but also allows some of the caramel from the malts through.. Taste is grassy and grainy with light, malty sweetness and bitterness in the finish. Medium to full body. Thumbs up.
