Copper color... Looks like a penny.  Aroma is subtler than expected... I guess all those pnw hops were used for flavor, which I can¬ít complain about one bit.  Anyone who thinks they are an ipa person should try a beer like this... Extemely hoppy and delicious... Grapefruit, tangerine, and a bit of minty pine... But super well balanced and not overdone on the bitterness.  A great hoppy beer that doesn¬ít pucker... Well done three floyds...  So far, I¬ím really impressed... Can¬ít wait to try another offering of yours.

This is not your typical pale ale.  Pours a deep amber--much darker than one typically expects of the style--without much of a head to speak of.  Nose isn¬ít particularly strong; mostly piney hops.  Nice, full flavor: primarily piney hops, a bit of citrus, and a really sturdy malt backbone.  Crisp, but the hops aren¬ít too biting.  Flavor reminds me a bit of the Green Flash West Coast IPA.  Very good beer.  As far as the style goes, I prefer the Hair of the Dog Ruth, which, although it is a pale ale, is remarkably different.  Nevertheless, Chicagoans should be glad they have access to this stuff, given how ubiquitous it is in 6-pack form, and how affordable it is.  Great combination of craft beer quality and value.
355 ml Bottle at MikkellerBar. Amber body with off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, hops, pine and citrus.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2010 Not much to add here, just one of the best brews we¬íve all ever tasted. Deep amber pour, moderate head, glorious body and nice hop bite makes a classic. Kind of like what Sierra Pale Ale must have been like 20 years back - sets the standard.
One of the best pales I¬íve had. Distinct citrus flavor. Very floral and delicious. Rated 2/6/03

Tab @ Mikkeller Bar. Amber pour with light tanned head. Aroma has pine, pineapple, lime, very delicious hop concentration. Light malt sweetness in an aroma that is dominated by nice, fruity hops. Taste is, (surprise?) very hoppy as well with pine, citrus, lime. Modest, but soothing, caramel malts here as well, but very hoppy indeed. Medium body, long duration, medium to high carbonation. Very good indeed.

trade via cheezdawg.
Finally found the holy grail of APA style beer.
Pours reddish/amber, off-white head.
Aroma, hard to describe but the nose on this one is quite possibly the best I have gotten to experience for this style of beer. amazing spiced  nose, hops and pale malts, possible hints of brown sugar, caramel, bready.
Flavors, silky smooth nutty, cocoa malts, grainy and cereal, mild chocolate. The hop profile seemed rather absent at first but quickly added an amazing citrus/hoppy touch to this beer. Mild bitterness with some citrus along with a bready malty balance.

Bottle from Crown Liquors #6 - Pour a clear dark amber with a thin tan head. Lots of citrus on the nose with some pine and dough. Taste is resin, grapefruit, and grass with tea on the finish. Mouthfeel is light and with nice carbonation.

On tap @ Mikkeller Bar.
Clear, dark amber with small  but neat head. Grapefruit is dominant in the nose. A lot of depth.  The taste is very well balanced. citrus, grass and grapefruit. Not particularly flovorfull - maybe expectations were too high. Seems it is too old. lacks freshness.

12 oz bottle into a Duvel tulip.
Pours a small one-finger head that dissaptes quickly. Color is a dark, hazy amber. Nose has some pine but prevalent bready malts and caramel. This beer is unique - nothing else I can compare it to. The hops and bitterness are forward. There is citrus in there and sweet malts that kick in part way through. By that or whatever means, the bitterness goes and is only faint in the finish. Refreshing. It has a light mouthfeel and good carbonation. At 6% and a warm day, could delve into this more, if I had the chance. Nice.

This one is an all time beauty and I have had the pleasure to ennjoy it several times.. and hopefully many times in the future. The pour is redish clear golden anmber with a thick frothy head with a light orange glow. The nose is so dilicious with fresh hops blating out along with sweet malty notes and apricots and maybe some light cloves. The taste is hopping fresh fresh fresh with a light but still with a huge taste. The palate is medium creamy and holds a nice backing profile for the malty creamy body There is  some spicy and roasty notes that leaves a mature impression. The finish is long with a malty sweetness combined with the hoppy bitterness. Yummy
Outstanding deep honey color, cloudy with strong hop fragrance.  Nice head and lacingGreat aromatic hops packed in there with plenty of malts for balance

Can¬ít believe I¬íve waited until now to review this one seeing as its my de-facto go-to everyday pair with anything beer.  Alpha King is that good.

Aroma: caramel, roasty, floral, grass, citrus

Appearance: hazy, amber

Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness

Palate: medium body, a bit sticky but not too thick, average carbonation, long and mild bitterness in the finish

Overall:  Truly outstanding.  I can drink this one ANYTIME.  Based upon its near constant availability (in my area at least), amazing aroma, and delicious flavors this is my  favorite beer  on the planet.

Had on tap at Floyds / Growler and bottle. WOW! Enough cannot be said about this gem.  Definitely one of the best pale ales Ive ever tasted.  So balanced and wonderful. Aroma contains some fruit hints and hop character. Appearance beautiful golden brown/red. Taste amazingly balanced, the hops and malt are mated in the smoothest fashion. On the palate it is almost medium bodied with sweetness and hop covering your tongue. Overall I must say Three Floyds is an amazing craft brewer who has hit the mark with this and all their amazing beers. Definitely one of the best!

Pours a nice amber color with a thin white head.  Aroma was citrus and a bit of nice malt.  some grapefruit notes.  The hop character was not as apparent in the nose as I thought it would be.  Flavor was nice.  Citrus, grapefruit, but still the hops seemed a bit subdued.  Wondering if I got an old bottle?  Would love to try this fresh.

Bottle from Stfun, thanks Josh! Pours a reddish amber color. Aroma is strongly caramel and molasses with some hop pine. The flavor starts out with these caramel notes hinting that it will end sweet, but instead transitions to a perfectly balanced dry finish with some nice hop flavor. Fantastic beer.

12 oz bottle from Casanova.  Medium caramel color with a fluffy white head that leaves great lacing.  Malty, citrus hoppy aromas.  Flavor is also very hoppy, bitter and citrus.  Finish is more bitter hops.
From bottle at Craftheads, Shibuya. Cloudy, shiny copper with a smallish head. Solid hoppy nose, followed by punchy pine and citrus hop flavours. Very bitter. No compromise beer.
hay, citrus, spruce, barnyard, basement aromas, golden, hazy, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, light body, sticky, average carbonation, bitter,

Predominantly bitter flavor balanced by hints of citrus and malty sweetness. Very nice blend of subtle sweetness with the bitter flavor of the hops. Golden pour. Very hoppy and slightly flowery aromas. Low head. Light body. Very fine and highly recommended beer.
Golden orange pour. Small head. Aroma of pine and citrus, finishing slighlty sweet with hints of honey. Flavor of citrus, grass, resin, light honey, and some sugar. Good, but pretty standard imho

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 My favorite beer, but first pour in a year and a half.  Great amber color.  Moderate head with decent lacing.  Complex, with just the right balance of citrus, bitter, and bready maltiness. Sweet [honey?] and piney, with a great hop profile.  A better IPA than most IPAs, and it isn¬ít even considered an IPA
Draught. Poured  orange, nice aroma moderate head.  Well balanced with the hops being flavorful and noticeable but not overpowering.  A very nice nice american pale.

Its a great hoppy beer. What I love most though about this beer is that the citrusy hop notes are lime, lemon and orange as opposed to the grapefruit I usually get. Obviously that has everything to do with the hops they use and in what balance. Fantastic bitterness in the finish too. If you fancy yourself a hoip head, then you probably have an Alpha King shrine in your basement.

Bottle tasting at home from a mix-and-match 6 pack out of my store.  This is bottle three of six. Been waiting a long time with this bad boy to see what the hype was all about, and surprisingly, it lived up to the hype!
  I have to admit, it wasn¬ít along the lines of my kind of beer, but the quality and profile of this FFF product makes it easy to see why its their flagship.  One of the best flavor profiles from a true pale ale that I may have ever had.  For one, it didn¬ít just lie down and die like most PA¬ís.  Great hop character, citrus notes and even a malt finish with just enough bitterness to keep you in check.  Still a session like a good PA should be, but one you¬íd love to keep going back to.  I¬ím impressed!

Bottle courtesy of Spence.  Thanks, buddy.  Pours copper with fluffy beige head.  Really an attractive beer, especially for the style.  Nose is lots of citrusy hops with just enough malt backbone (think notes of honey) to back it up. A little thin on the palate, but overall excellent.
Very nice hoppy, citrus, floral aroma.  Taste does not disappoint...all the aromas come through.  This beer deserves it¬ís lofty reputation.  A classic representation of the category.

Thanks to Overml01 for this one.  Pours opaque amber with a khaki head.  Nose is malt, honey, sugar, caramel, orange, and citrus.  Flavor is malt, caramel, tart citrus, and prickly/ piney hops.  Finish is sweet and piney.  Nice APA overall.
A clear tangarine pour with a small head.  Great hoppy aroma with notes of orange. The flavor is sweet with slight caramel and loads of hops.  Finishes dry and easy.

Bottle. Aroma is lovely, running the full spectrum of hop character from musk y pine to sweet citrus. A light spiciness runs through it. Hazy bright amber with unbelievable carbonation up to a nicely lacing thin white head. Great balance, with a very mild bitterness allowing caramel malt notes and orange peel, musk, and pine from the hops to show. Finish is dry, bitter enough to keep it in the category but far from over-the-top. Delicious and immensely drinkable.
Amazing Pale Ale. In fact this is how APAs should be. Just the right balance between malty and hoppy, and nicely bitter after taste. I love this beer, if I could I¬íd pour myself one everyday.

Oh so good!  I¬íll call this an AIPA ("ALMOST IPA") because it¬ís flavor profile is so reminiscent, but has a little twist that pulls you back into APA land.

12oz pours a glowing orange-amber with a tiny white head that quickly dissipates.  Great aroma of pine, nuts, and fresh earth.  Flavor is hoppy at the front and the back, but dances through a great balance of sweet and tart fruit, bready malt, and a deep, hearty savory flavor I haven¬ít quite put my finger on.

Very palatable, not oily or slick at all.  Hop presence isn¬ít overwhelming, but definitely recognizable.  Balanced carbonation.
Bottle. Clear amber body with a small white head. Aroma is hops, fruit, grapefruit and citrus. Flavor is hops grapefruit and citrus. It has a lovely long and bitter aftertaste.

One of the best Pale Ales on the market. Not necessarily an IPA, but about as close to one as you¬íll get. Not only tremendous hop flavor, but enough malts to balance this out and make it one of the best beers at under $10 /6 pack.

One of the best.  I¬ím not sure why they opt to call it an APA instead of an IPA, but this is a really drinkable beer that still has nice hop notes.  Not much different than 3F pride and joy in my book--just a little more hoppy.  Everything about this beer is nice.  Nice nose, nice little head, beautiful amber color, nice hop on the front to mid palate that doesn¬ít linger like most IPAs that are a bit bigger.  This is right in the sweet spot.

12oz bottle into Sam Adams perfect pint glass. Pours a crystal clear copper color with a medium white head. Aroma is of cascades with a hint of caramel malts. Medium mouth-feel, excellent carbonation. Caramel malt flavors with a bitter end (warriors). Excellent pale ale, one of 3F¬ís finest.

Dark orange with a small white-orange head. Aroma is cirtus and extremely hoppy. Taste also very happy but also sweet with a lot of citrus, mostly grapefruit. Body is medium light. One of my favorite beers I can get at the liquor store by my apartment.

Tasted from a twelve ounce bottle.  Pours clear amber with a one finger beige head.  The aromas are lightly roasted malts, hops, and prune juice.  On the palate, the flavors are lemongrass, and then hoppy bitterness.  There is a hint of the malt on the mid-palate, but the bitterness is the main flavor.  On the palate, everything is fairly medium.  The body, carbonation, and finish are all in the middle.  Overall, this is a very high quality beer, perfect for sessions.  I could drink this one all night long.
The greatest pale ale on the planet! Citrus heaven. Way better than eating a grapefruit.

Pours a deep orange like an Oktoberfest! Light foamy head that collapses.  Thick caramel notes in the aroma as well as grapefruit hoppiness (not overpowering).  Toasted malt comes through first, followed by a well rounded hop bitterness.  Some malt sweetness. Dry hop aftertaste. Medium body.  Really different, but enjoyable.  A very layered beer.
Pours a clear orangish amber with thin white head. Aroma is a lot of floral and spruce. Flavor is a toasted nut with bread notes and spruce undertones. Body is light with quite a bit of carbonation.

My go-to beer.  For a pale ale there is literally nothing bad you can say about this beer.  With the belgian malts and a hop-profile that is bigger than some IPAs, this beer will always stay in my Top Ten.  Pours an amber brownish orange with a beautiful fluffly head that sticks around.  Smell is the same unique experience you get from all Three Floyds beers, a very pleasant caramel, belgian malt, sweet hoppy aroma that correlates with the taste.  For an American pale ale I say this is the best I¬íve ever had.

A: A 12 oz bottle poured into my Firestone Walker pint glass. The beer is a hazy, amber color with little to no head.

S: A great citrus (grapefruit and orange) aroma fills the nose and a mild pine is present as well. There is also a bit of sweet, caramel malt smell coming through.

T: Exceptional flavor for a pale ale! Wonderful bitterness up front and on the finish. There is also quite a bit of citrus in there, but not much in the way of the malt.

M: A fairly light beer on the tongue, but certainly not a bad thing. Good carbonation and a bit of a lingering bitterness.

D: Pale ales are known for their high level of drinkability, and this one is no exception. A very nice beer by Three Floyds.
citrus hoppiness bounces around the nose.   Has a balanced finish for a beer so loaded with hops.   deep pale ale traditional coloring.   all that aside, YUMMY!

Bottle to snifter. Aroma has faint floral malt scents. Appearance is copper with a nice thin tight head that deminishes to a ring on top. Taste is grapefruit malt and citrus dry finish. Palate is thin dry and chaulky. This is a very drinkable beer I enjoyed it very much.

12oz bottle shared with glouglou and bro.
Appearance :Hazy peach with a small head.

Aroma : Sweet and hoppy resinous with hints of passion fruit.

Taste : Fruity (dry peaches or something). Some hops, quite sweet and quite resinous. Some malt

Finish : Quite resinous

Overall : Very nice beer. Could have been as bit less sweet I think.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deeper copper with orange hues. NIce generous off white head which laced nicely during the session. Great citrusy aroma with hops prevalent. Citrus and grapefruit taste, balanced nicely with slightly sweet malt. Smooth, if not, slightly bitter finish. Yet another nice one from three floyds.

Bottle. Pours beautiful amber with a lasting beige head. A lovely bouquet aroma of grapefruit, citrus, pine and flowers. The flavour is grapefruit, citrus and pine hops. A dry hoppy finish that lingers. This is one (hop) souped up APA - the result is delicious! Thanks volcanicbeat!

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2011 Just a huge hop vehicle. Nose is Citrus, rind and pine. In the mouth it¬ís a tad thin and may not have been so sharp. Lots of citrus - definitely not balanced. Will rerate If I ever get to try it fresh, because i imagine it would be a 4 plus. Not subtle, but for those wanting a huge hop fix with a medium alcohol potency this is the brew for you. Big thanks to volcanicbeat for this via japan!

12oz bottle. Pours dark amber, topped with a medium sized off white head. Beautiful citrus hop aroma with just a hint of caramel in the background. Caramel hits the palate for an instant, and is quickly overpowered by grapefruit, orange, and resiny hops. Grapefruity and earthy hops stick around for a lengthy finish. tasty pale ale.

Coppery, orangey hue, fairly clear, decent head formation. Fairly mellow grapefruit aroma, fresh rose petals, pretty sweetish suggestions. Palate is predominantly hoppy grapefruit but it¬ís pretty well balanced, tea, mild orange and biscuity caramel. Pretty strong bitter finish. The hops are there in abundance but are well balanced.

Bottle pours a golden orange, barely able to see through glass, with a nice white head.  Aroma is heavy of citrus hops, specifically orange notes prevalent with a hint of flowers and caramel.  Taste is incredibly well balanced between the caramel malt, orange and spiciness from the hops, along with the wave of bitterness in the finish.  Medium mouthfeel in body and carbonation.  Excellent IPA.

Pours a nice deep sunburst orange,with a creamy head with aromas of hay, citrus and a hint of carmel. taste medium sweetness, with  citrus notes   def some lemongrass  and floral hops with a great balance of bitterness! Hey it¬ís alpha King for a reason

Pours deep orange with white head, aroma is citrusy with orange, taste up front is citrusy sweet orange, lemon, and grapefruit leading into a caramel sweetness and gets nice and bitter.  Hopped up APA, very nice brew!

Think us Chicagoans kind of take a fresh Alpha King for granted every now and then. Great brew. Period. Tons of juicy citrus. Hop bitter. Malt back. Super drinkable. Cold OR mild, it offers a palate full of flavor. I won¬ít even AAFPO this one. Great hops, malt, bitter, alcohol, drinkability, mouth. It is light and crisp. Citrusy, hoppy, yet non-offensive to the macro crowd as a borderline IPA. Nothing bad to say about this brew. Gumballhead is a close second here. This will familiarize you with the "flagship" hops. God damn, i could drink them BOTH all day.

Pours cloudy amber with a thin beige head. Aroma of pine resin, rich molasses and dark fruit. taste is slightly bitter up front with a good floral sweetness also. This bottle has a little too much age on it but I can imagine the fresh hops. Very flavorful pale ale. Finishes with more bitterness. Overall great balance of thick burnt tasting malt with bitter and floral hops.

Thanks to Santa for this one.  This one is pretty much a perfect beer for me.  Pours a hazy copper-orange with a lingering white foamy head.  Aroma is hop, citrus/orange and somewhat floral.  Taste is at first a bombardment of hop bitterness.  Once this fades you are hit with a number of flavours of orange/citrus, floral and bready finish.  Very awesome.  Thank goodness Santa left two of these under the tree!

I have been waiting to try this for a while. I broke down and ordered a sixer from Archer Liquors in Chicago. Very cool looking bottle with the king himself featured on the front. The beer poured a dark orange with a very good head. The smell was so amazing. fresh hops permeated my nose and reminded me of grass, herbs, and flowers. The taste matched up very nicely with hops really shining through. Wow, believe the hype! I think this was better than dreadnaught. This probably ties with Deschutes Hop Trip for my favorite Pale Ale. Outstanding.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-04-2007 15:51:22

Appearance is a great orange hue with plenty of effervescent bubbles. Smell is nice and sweet with almost tangerine notes. Taste is sweet with a nice orange rind bitterness that pulls together the beer nicely.

12oz bottle.  pours a nice copper color with a small off white head.  A floral aroma with a caramel ending.  Huge hope taste with a perfect soft carbonation.  This a brew that is very tasty and the 6% ABV makes it great to enjoy all night long.
Poured nice golden with a fluffy white head smelled like hops and hay tasted about the same very good ipa three floyds has yet to dissapoint

Bottle - Pours amber and hazy, like apple juice, with a nice foamy white head. Aroma is citrusy hops with a nice malt backbone--real inviting. Taste is biscuity malt with tons of citrusy, grassy hops, hints of chocolate and toffee, and a bit of baking spice. There¬ís enough balance to make this pretty sessionable, but enough complexity to make it interesting. Harsh carbonation detracts a bit, and there¬ís a bit of a sour, funky aftertaste. Minor knocks on a beer that is consistently fantastic.

Poured from the Bottle into a pint glass. Very dark amber color with minimal white head that quickly evaporated. Very hoppy and dense flavor with citrus hints and a smooth slightly bitter finish. Much better than I initially thought this beer would be. Not an overbearing punch of alcohol but nicely present when drinking. Very balanced and well crafted. Overall a very nice surprise of an American Pale Ale.

Bottle.

Amber-like with a nice and large white head that left some lacings. 

The aroma was very hoppy. Tropical fruits, strawberries, grapefruit, some chocolate and pineapple.

The taste reminded much of an IPA, the bitterness was high but well balanced. Caramel, grass, citrus. Medium-bodied with a nice crispiness, easy to drink. 

Yeah one six-pack on a Saturday evening for a game or something else would not be a bad idea.

Reddish amber color, slightly hazy. A rather big off-white head dissipates quite fast and leaves some chunky lacings.

Big hop character in the nose - grapefruit, mango, lemon peel. Grass, pine-needles and hop resins. Plenty of malt as well. Some fudge, chocolate and rye bread. Very nice smell.

Despite massive hop flavors, the taste seems balanced. Exotic fruits (grapefruits, mango), solid backbone of sweet, caramel-like and nutty malts. Some bready notes. Floral hop flavors, resins and grass. A very fresh hop character overall, great! Perhaps a gentle note of chocolate. The bitterness in the finish is quite big, but manageable. Lingering notes of juicy malts and more hop resins.

M: Medium body, very crisp, slightly dry in the finish.

D: A quite astonishing APA. Considering the amount of hop aromas and flavors in this one, it could easily go head to head with an IPA. And despite all of the hops, it still feels well balanced.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Bottle. [ Courtesy of elgaucho ] Pours hazy medium orange red color with an average creamy lacy beige head. Aroma is resinous grass with some citrus grapefruit and some slight raisin. Flavor is moderately sweet and perfectly bitter with a long to average duration. Perfectly balanced. You get the malt first with the hops kicking in hard towards the end. Body is gorgeously smooth and oily, carbonation is soft. This is a wonderful APA!

This is a placeholder of a rating.  I¬íve had this on several occasions - at the brewery and in various places in ohio.  I came across an old note with just a score, but have had this as my favorite APA for a while.  Surprised I didn¬ít have a rating in for it.  Details to follow next time I can track it down.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 On tap at the Three Floyds brewpub on 7/21/09.  Pours dark gold with a touch of amber and nice white head.  Solid pine aroma with just a touch of vanilla and caramel.  Mild sweetness and then bam!  The hops hit hard.  Great hoppy pale ale.

The best pale ale out there, hands down.  Consistent with the typical Three Floyd¬ís penchant for overtly hoppy brews, goes down smooth and is highly enjoyable.  I¬íve had many pints of this ale and it¬ís always best on draft.  Highly recommended!
draft: reddish with a thin white head, grassy hop aroma with a hoppy and citrus taste

Solid pale ale. Pours a hazy amber with a decent off white head. Lots of citrusy hops on the nose. Nice hops presence in the beer, not overly bitter but definte bite to it. Finishes crisp with the citrusy hops flavor lingering. Pretty good brew.

Pours a very cloudy amber color with a medium off-white head which leaves plenty of sticky lacing.  Aroma is resinous hops, earth, tangerine, grapfruit, and light caramel malts.  Taste is very earthy, plenty of citrus, and balanced out with the caramel malts.  I expected it to be much more bitter or thick but the mouthfeel and bitterness is near perfect.
Just a great beer in a style I enjoy.  Nicely hopped, not overwhelming.  Touch of leather on the taste, but very smooth.  Love the pale ales and this is a near-perfect example.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2013 Dark amber hazy pour light off white thick frothy head and lots of sticky lacing .... aroma of citrus hops and piney hops  ....taste is of chewy caramel malt, bitter piney hops and a nice grapefruity citrusy hop ..... very balanced beer with a nice bittering hop aftertaste ..... finish is dry hopped and has a long lingering bitter hop bite  ..... drinks like a great ipa

Bottle. Nice amber/copper color with a huge fluffy light tan head. Good lacing, too. Great aroma - sweet caramel, spicy citrusy hops. Flavor is the same - the citrusy, lightly grassy hops are balanced exquisitely to smooth caramelly malt. I can definitely see why this is the top rated APA - it¬ís an extremely well-constructed beer.

pours golden red brown with mild off-white head.  nose is sweet with grapefruit and brown sugar with a hint of raisens.  taste is sweet, like gumballs soaked in grapefruit juice.  makes me happy to drink this and wish three floyds was sold in ice cold MN.

A: A lovely rusty amber color with a nice 2 finger head that disappers to nearly nothing. Left lacing all the way down the glass; Beautiful. 

S: Hops are yelling at me from the bottom of this glass. Grass, Pine, and citrus come wafting from this pint. 

T: This brew is dominated by hops and pine. It has a slight citrus finish that makes it very refreshing. 

M: This baby is pretty hoppy for a regular IPA. The mouthfeel is medium but the finish is oh so refreshing.

this is a great beer. pours a bit hazy, citrus notes dominate the aroma, and a nice 2 finger head tops this excellent brew. flavor is profound, with one of the best balances of bitterness i¬íve had. a nice strong finish...

Bottle from a trade with StFun. Pours hazy copper color with off white head. Citrus aromas of lemon and grapefruit with some bready malts. Nice hop bitterness with a mild malt backbone. Medium body with lively carbonation. An excellent, easy drinking pale ale. Thanks Josh.
nice dark orange color. very slight fruity aroma. flavor is grapefruit hops, but light grainy maltiness. kind of dusty tasting overall.

From 12 oz. into tulip.  Wow!  Thank you my Indiana native friend T Jay! What can I say - this is THE BEST APA or IPA I have ever tasted - simply awesome!  From the flavorful, citrus and flowery aroma, to the uncanny deep, cloudy amber color to the well-balanced taste which simply leaves the palate pining for more!  My first FFF beer, and I am not disappointed in the least.  I believe this may be the highest rating I have given, definitely within its category.  Writing this as I poured my 3rd one of the night - and boy am I looking forward to drinking this one! SALUDE Baby!

Pours a slightly hazy copper color with a decent, but not overlarge, head. Aroma of grapefruit and pine, not as strong as some but not weak either. Definitely stronger hops than most APA¬ís, and stronger than a few IPA¬ís I¬íve tasted. Kind of like getting the flavor of an IPA with a bit lower alcohol, which makes for a pretty drinkable combination. Overall a very pleasing beer.

Picked up a sixer at a place called Hi-way liquor about 35 miles outside Indianapolis (looking for any Three Floyds products, especially Dark Lord). Coppery amber brown pour into foamy tan head that dissipates into sticky melting lacing as carbonated bubbles rise into a swirling pool of bubbly foam. Thick aroma of piney hops and ripened citrus with hints of sweet caramel malt. Initial flavor of sweet citrus that quicly fades to a spicy hoppy bite with hints of pepper in the finish.

Pours a golden brown with an off-orange colored head.  Thick head with nice lacing.  Aroma is mostly pine hops with hints of citrus and malt.  Taste is hoppy and bitter but not too much.  After tast is sweet up front and bitter around the edges.  Very good brew!

Bottle shared @ the HotD dock sale [thanks guyinchicago for the trade!]...  Poured amber with an off-white head.  Hoppy nose.  Light, well carbonated palate.  Hops and grains all around.  Thin, slightly bitter finish.

Pours a copper/brown with a thin tanish head. Aroma consists of grapefruit, citrus, and pine. Tastes of citrus and pine, but you also get a bitter bite at the end. I get more of an IPA than a pale ale, but either way this is a terrific beer. Nice work FFF!
An absolutley solid pale ale bordering on ipa given its hop squeeze.  May be low score by me, but only because of the dizzing array of stellar beers they make to compare it against. Good work TTT

Brewed in the USA.... On tap at the Brass Rail. Pours copper in color with a small off white head. Aroma of citrus, pine, malts and hops. Taste of grapefruit, oranges, caramel and malts. Mouthfeel is medium in body with some lingering bitterness at the finish. Overall, very easy to drink and is worth seeking out. :)

On tap at The Brass Rail. Poured a clear burnished copper color with a small off-white head. Huge gusts of hops waft up from the glass. Grapefruit, pine, grass, and toast were all present in the nose and flavor. The palate was very crisp and inviting with a notable amount of bitterness. More of an IPA in every sense except the alcohol level. Lovely.

Pours a hazy copper with one finger head that leaves a little a lacing - A blast of hops in the aroma - Very bitter on the palate yet goes down very smooth - Aroma and taste resemble more of a DIPA than an APA yet at 6% abv you can drink this all night - overall this probably my favorite beer - Congrats and thank you to the brewer on excellent brew!

355 mL courtesy of tjthresh. Pours a clear reddish amber with a two-finger tan, rocky head that leaves okay lacing. Aroma is huge caramel, butterscotch candy, strawberry cheesecake, honey, blueberries. Taste is not what I was expecting at all. Instead of a hop bomb or citrus, juicy body, this is more like rich blackberry and cranberry pie. The hops here are spicy, sweet, and balancing rather than the primary character of the beer. As it warms the 6% starts to show through. Nice chewy, syrupy mouthfeel. This is very yummy, novel, but not the ultimate APA I was expecting.

bottle, pours deep carmel color with a medium light tan head.  Really nice hop aroma of grapefruit, lime skins, and pine needles.  Flavor is just awesome.  This is what a pale ale should be.  Dry, hoppy, just enough malt character to balance the bitterness.  Almost bittersweet in the finish.  Slightly toasty in nature.  All around good, and the finish is so nice that it¬ís really hard not to gulp this stuff.

12oz single from Capone¬ís Bottle Shop, Norristown, PA...pours DEEP amber, off white head...piney resin aroma with orange, apricot and hops...all of this carries over into the flavor, citrusy...oily mouthfeel...how is this only an APA...this is a BIG APA...not big on alcohol, but big on favor, body, and character...awesome.
Bottle.  Pours dark amber with a white head that clings to the glass.  Citrus hop aroma.  Strong grapefruit and hops flavor.  Clean finish.  Nice beer that goes down easy.

Citrusy aroma that makes you ask, "Is this really beer?" The body is just a shade above water. When I first tasted it I asked, "Is this really beer? Or is this grapefruit juice?" Very very grapefruity which is by no means my cup of tea. Or beer for this matter...

Bottle courtesy of DA from Fever.  Thanks!  Surprisingly cloudy brown pour.  Looks like apple cider.  I want to say that there¬ís a bit of honey in the scent, along with some definite hoppiness.  Smells like an IPA without the hop bitterness.
Man, I wish this was available locally.  Dark, reddish pour from bottle.  Citrus, lemon zest nose.  Big taste of grapefruit and smoked wood.  Smooth finish.  Super!

(Cask at Chelsea Cask Festival) Deep amber colour and and almost clear. Small white head. Hops, fruitiness and malts in aroma. Medium bodied palte with little carbonation. Malts, hops, fruitiness, citricness, sea water and bitterness in taste. Hops and bitterness in aftertaste. Very good one.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2009 Bottle courtesy of Davinci. Pour is deeper red than expected for an APA. Really nice, clean nose of grapefruit and orange peel with a little wild berry. Flavor is very clean: first the woody, resiny hops, that fade to a citrus rind bitterness, then all enveloped in a heavy caramel maltiness that spreads all that delicious hop character all over the mouth. Bottle #1 lasted about 4 minutes. Bottle #2 lasted barely longer than that. If this was readily available, I¬íd be purchasing it a case at a time. Thanks, beejay.

Pours out a hazy reddish copper. Smells of malt with a touch of hops. Older bottle. Flavors of malt with a touch of spice. Nice smooth clean mouth feel. Wish the hops weren¬ít missing or this would truly be an outstanding beer. Still purty darn good.
Pours a light tan head with an amber body.  Malty with old, mellow pine hops and caramelized malt sweetness.  Resinous, bitter finish.

Bottle from a dude in the Ramada/Knights Inn- Denver lobby in exchange for a bottle of Divine Reserve #8.  Thanks, random dude in the hotel lobby!Pours a dense, rich amber with a nice head of off-white and thick lacing that clings to the glass like John of "John and Kate" clinging to the last shred of dignity he has left.  Aroma is straight-up grapefruit and pine/orange resin with a nutty strawberry butter note in the background.  Flavor is a grassy grapefruit note that gives way to a lemony tart finish, complete with lemon peel and a dash or orange peel.  Lingering finish that leaves the palate massaged and ready for more.  The best APA by far.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
Cleary and glassy amber/orange color. Nice but brief foamy white head. Looks like triaminic.

Serious pine-oil hop aroma. Bitter but also flowery sweet. Really perfect. West Coast hops are sweet smelling and inviting. Perfect sweet-bitter balance.

Major blast of bitter, woody hops and a splash of alcohol. A little burn on the way down. Very strong. Hop flavor is sweet at first, then bitter. Slaps with the bitter, but mellows out at the end.

Remains on the tongue after the swallow. Thick and a tiny bit fizzy but goes down smooth. It¬ís a superior beer.
bottle. Heavy hop aroma, very nice. the flavor was hoppy, grapefruity, plenty of bitter, orange in the finish. very tasty
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 RERATE. Courtesy of Pat. Pours a dark, hazy orange body with small white head and great lacing. Nice hop aroma with bursts of grapefruit, and delicious hop flavor.

Chelsea Cask Festival: Had no idea I was in the presence of royalty when ordering this brew.  Pours a slight hazy, deep amber.  Nose is full of bitters, sugars, florals... exactly what you¬íd expect a king¬ís royal court to stink of.  The texture was full and very oily, helping to stick the deep flavors to your tongue.  Very well balanced, spicy, bitter, sweet, crisp and bright yet dark and complex.  F*cking awesome on cask!
UPDATED: OCT 11, 2009 On tap at Chelsea brewing company during the cask ale festival.  Beautifully floral spices with so much oils.  Absolutely delicious and spicy
This yellow to orange pour looks and full mouth as it feels. Nose is all pine and grapefruit. A rich hoppy flavor with a hint of sweetness in the form of caramel.  A satisfying beer.
Pours amber with an off-white head. Aroma is malt, light caramel, hoppy, citrus, grapefruit and peach. Flavour is caramel, hoppy, citrus, grapefruit and peach. Long lasting aftertaste.

Pitcher pour at 2009 GABF. Pours a thin head, with minimal lacing over a clear yellow gold (SRM 6) body.......nose is loads of pine and grapefruit.......taste initially is sweet malts then the hops arrive and pine and grapefruit bitterness balance out the malt and linger......mouth feel and carbonation are nicely balanced in to create a grand sensation. This is another in the myriad of excellent  APA¬ís available to us, the fortunate tasters. Tasting of 9/26/09.
A super beer. Amber coloured and hazy. Head is off-white and mostly lasting. Aroma is very hoppy, harsh. Crisp notes too. Flavor is lightly sweet and harsh bitter, long. Dry, dry texture.
Bottle. Pours a very dark, cloudy, ruby amber. Very hoppy for a pale ale, but its not normal as the bottle says! Very tasty and easy to drink. Excellent beverage.

bottle courtesy of coyotehunter, thank you! pours a very complex orange/coppery burnt sienna ruby with a minimal khaki colored head that leaves some lacing. aroma is very nice and light, very floral with delicate notes of grapefruit blanded with sweeter notes of green pine, with a lil buttery yeast underneath. some very light caramel malt notes as well. taste is very nice, very light, crisp, pungent yet refreshing. nice hop profile, both sweet and bitter, but both very light and nicely balanced. body is nice medium fullness, with a light effervescent feeling to set off the somewhat viscous oils of it. i really wish i could easily get this in summer, it would be one of my go to¬ís for a hot summer day when in need of quenching.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a lasting light brown head that laced nicely. Aroma is full of hops giving both a pine forest note as well as citrus rinds. Flavor begins with citrus bang and finishes with a light piney note. Goes down amazingly smooth. My favorite APA.
(draft). Clear copper color. Medium off white head. Citrus hop aroma. Grass and citrus flavors. Avg duration. Light bitter finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Good lacing.

Great, complex blend of hops - pine, citrus, and earthiness. This is the best pale ale I¬íve ever had. So smooth, but flavorful and full-bodied. I could - and would - drink this all day if I could get my hands on it more often.
Bottle, 12 fl. oz. Pours a clear golden beer, The aroma and the flavor is nice and hoppy. This also leaves a bitter palate. Overall this beer is balanced and simple and testes fantastic.

Tasting at GABF . Orange/amber with little orange/white head. Clear. Very hoppy aroma of citrus. Flavor is sweet malt backed by very bitter finish with citrus and grass hop. Dry and average length finish with medium body. Oily feel goes dry at end.

12oz bottle. Clear amber pour with a big beige head. Lots of malt in the nose, a bit cerealy. Good amount of hops in there too. Caramel malt up front before a piney hop explosion that lasts until the finish and beyond. Very good APA.
Draught at Hopleaf, Chicago. Hazy amber pour with small head. Good hoppy, malty aroma. Hoppy, malty, quite bitter, no sweetness at all, dry tasting. Pretty good APA.

Pours an amber-brown with a small ivory head. Aroma is nicely hoppy with a good floral bouquet. Malts come through too in the aroma. Yes, this flavor is delicious! Much citrusy, crisp hops throughout. Citric acid and floral flavors as well, with a solid malt backdrop. Creamy mouthfeel, crisp finish sets you up for the next sip. I never thought it would be possible to give a pale ale this high a rating, but this is easily the best APA I¬íve ever had. Overall, world class. Thanks, 3 Floyds.

355 ml bottle. Hazy, dark orange body with a thin beige head. Nice hoppy aroma of grapefruit and peaches. Flavor is malt, caramel and a fine balanced bitterness. Medium body. Well brewed, actually pretty straightforward but very drinkable.

A murky copper brown color with a dense, small off-white head. Aroma has a strong resin, leafy bitterness with a very strong orange citrus hops note. Hops are pretty dominate in the aroma but a small sweet caramel malt note does come through. Flavor is very full and strong of resin, leafy bitterness bites hard up front but trickles away leaving a very sweet orange citrus and some caramel malt sweetness. Very heavy brew overall with a nice, fine carbonation feel. So dense it feels slightly sugary but not cloying. The hops is very well balanced between being sweeter and being extraordinarily bitter. Overall a very solid brew and one well deserving of its ranking and praise.

I just moved to Indiana and was quick to look for Three Floyds offerings. I had this on tap at Scotty¬ís in West Lafayette, and bought some bottles from a local store as well. Pours deep amber with a thin head and minimal lacing. Great aroma of hops, citrus and malt. Aroma is consistent with flavor. Nice hops and great malt present. The solid malty flavor is great in a pale ale. Medium bodied and a little bit of lingering bitterness finishes it off. It¬ís low on carbonation and has a simple, solid feel to it. This is definitely one of the best pale ales I¬íve had. This has all the elements of a great pale ale.

Bottle. Pours a clear orange color with a small white head. Has a malty bitter hoppy grapefruit and citrus aroma. Malty hoppy and very bitter flavor with grapefruit and citrus hints. Has a fruity malty bitter hoppy finish with a long bitter aftertaste with hints of grapefruit.
12 oz bottle pours coppery with an off white head. Aroma is lots of hops, fruit, and a bit of caramely malt. Flavor is big hop bitterness, grass, and a bit of toasted malt.

Bottle, bought at the brewpub and brought home. Nobody makes beers that have quite the powerful and heady aromas of Three Floyds. Through the classic newly cut carpet smell of strong hops there¬ís chocolate, lime, peaches, and melon skins. The flavor is singular - although the smells are IPA-ish, the flavor is a delicious and I think right on the balance between PA and IPA. No beer is so great a combination of smell and flavor and the aroma just doesn¬ít quit.

Bottle. Good caramelly hop aroma. Cloudy red amber colour. Very small off-white head. Good bitterness. Not so sweet, but sweet enough. Grassy hop note, quite caramelly and nice. A bit dry for my tastes, but good.
Bottle. Clear Amber color with okay head. Strong nice hoppy aroma. Very well balanced beer. Just the rigt amount of bitter hops.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops, malt, flowers, caramel and fruits.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Powerfull hoppy and moderate malty aroma. Fantastic powerfull bitter flavor. Strong flower and herbal notes. Long great finish.  Excellent creamy palate.
Wonderfull beer.
Bottle. Clear red orange colour with a medium off white head. Rich aroma and taste of malts, caramel off fruits. Well balanced and lasting taste.

From [email¬†protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */¬ís.  A thin greyish head over a slightly hazed, deep orangey-brown body. Intense hoppy fruit aroma; sweet lemon, yellow grapefruit and apricot. Also a scent of refined caramel/toffee - in perfect interplay with fruity hops. 
Taste has a fine, rounded caramellish malt body. Quite sweet in flavor, but the sweetness is restrained and delicate.  Fruity, lemony hops is there to balance. A distinct bitterness throughout.  Smooth and filling. Perfectly balanced with a dangerously high drinkability.  A treat!

Bottle at Monks Cafe, Wallingatan Stockholm.

Pours mahogny with a beige head.
Aroma of sweet hops and cookies.

Very barley wine like but without alcohol taste and shorter lasting taste.

But overall its a great beer and a worthy rating 400 for me!

Bottle thanks to StFun.  Dark copper-orange, thin off white cover.  Aroma is fantastic, fruity, caramels, toffee, with a good citrus hoppiness.  Taste is again malty, caramels, spicy, floral, citrus hops, light but lasting bitter finish.

Bottle. Ap: Almost clear amber colour, creamy white head. Ar: Sweet. Citrus cookies. Fla: Bitter hops at first, sweet citrus hops in finish. Pal: Medium bodied. Oily texture. Ov: Very drinkable pale ale. May be the best ever... ?

Pours a murky red with active carbonation and a nice bubbly head that turns into a frothy crown.

Smells very citrusy, grapefruit mostly. Similar to the smell of the fantastic Nugget Nectar. Other fruity smells are in the background, but there is no doubt the balance is tilted to hops here.

Taste is also similar to Nugget Nectar (heads up to the guy that was looking for a similar beer), but not QUITE as powerful. Grapefruit and other citrus hops out front with a light malt background. Very good.

Mouth is near perfect where it is at, med/high carbonation and thin/med body.

Drinkabiliity: Three Floyd¬ís with another hit. Here¬ís hoping they expand into Western PA.

On Tap at MacNiven¬ís. Big fresh hop nose and taste. Lots of citrus and some pine. A little on the dry side versus juicy, making the palate and finish a little odd/rough. Nowhere near the d-naught, but almost knocking on the door. Very excellent for an APA!
Right on the bottle it says "bold citrus hop character," and they weren¬ít kidding! Pretty solid brew that is good but not perrrrfectly balanced.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy dark orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is smooth citrusy and slight peachy hops aroma. Dry, pinewood and peachy to citrusy hops flavoured. Bitter and bone dry. Smooth and fruity hops bitter flavoured finish.

Draft from Scotty¬ís Brewhouse in downtown Indianapolis.  Pours amber with medium off-white head.  Great aroma of citrus, hops, earth, floral notes, pinch of spice.  Flavor is hops and grapefruit, with some earthiness to it as well.  Medium body, great balance, perfect amount of carbonation, slightly bitter finish.  Outstanding from start to finish.  I disagree that this could be an IPA and I¬íll take the Three Floyds¬í word that it¬ís an APA.  That being the case, it¬ís the best APA I¬íve ever had.

Is this an IPA masquerading as an APA?     Who cares.   Good brew and I don¬ít have alot to add to what¬ís already been said.   Hoppy for an APA, but not overly so.   Lacing is somewhat limited, but the aroma of hops, grapefruit and other things citrus make this an enjoyable brew.     This is the beer I want swill-lovers to sample.  I tihnk this one will convert many a-heathen from the uninformed to the wonderful world of microbrews.

A home run from Three Floyds.

(12oz bottle) pours dark amber with nice oily bubbles that last a good while and lacing is nice and creamy. Nose is so good, grapefruit oils, sweet malts, tropical fruits, and bready. Taste is nice and hoppy and so well balanced with the malt. This is the quintessential example of a pale ale. Nothing is out of place. Pineapple, pine, grapefruit, sweet malts and just delicious. Oily palette and perfect weight. Could drink this all night.

Amber/copper color with a small just off white head. Aroma of big citricy piney flowery hops. Mouthfeel is good with malts to start with lingering bitterness in the finish. Taste of citris, pine, grass, to grapefruit bitter which lingers well after. Even better on a second tasting. Re-Rate: I just love everything about this beer.

Basic amber color, generous head with good retention. 

Ample pine needles on the nose. Very piny. Almost all hops on the nose, maybe a tad of candied malty notes. 

Flavor is predominatly of the hop flavors, especially up front. Only later on the palate do you detect the malt. Huge hoppy peak and aftertaste. This beer is all about the hops. 

IPA fans will find this very drinkable (compared to other IPA¬ís, in my view) however I find it slightly challenging. Likely I¬íll only drink one at a time and then move on to a different beer.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2009 Reddish amber body with an off-white head.  Citrus hop aroma is subtle, the taste is all hops.  Bitter grapefruit taste with an average finish.  This should really be an IPA.

While this ale may not seem like a APA, I¬ím not sure I agree with it being categorized as an IPA either.  What it is, in my opinion, is the best beer I have tasted that is not in an imperial category.  A fine balance of hop bitterness, flavor, and aroma with a perfect malt backbone.

I picked up some Alpha King in Chicago last weekend to try it for the first time.  This is hardly a Pale Ale, yet it ranks among the best IPA¬ís I have ever had, so even better.  While I feel like the aroma hops could be stepped up , the bitterness is just right to suit me; very balanced and without an overpowering aftertaste.  I really enjoyed drinking this beer and hope to get more soon.

Finally, I wanted to find the 3 Floyds, and I have.  Let¬ís first say this beer is really testing the boundaries and definitions of a pale ale, honestly it¬ís more like an IPA.  With that said, it would probaly be one of the best IPA¬ís as well.  The aroma is full to the max.  Very much full of very oily super hops, presumably classic Oregon/Washington styles - hops ranging from Cascade to the extreme Warrior hops.  Citrus and alcohol is also present.  Alcohol aromas are definitively dominant with bourbon oakiness.  The appearance is a very deep coppery color, with a somewhat dissappointing head, white collar is all that is present.  The flavor is full of intense Pacific Northwest hops, that are very well balanced by complimentary malts with an alcohol burn.  I¬ím sure its going to give me some stomach flutters  its oily to be sure with a lingering sassafrass alcohol like burn.

tap - Poured amber color with medium off white head.
Aroma - fresh hops, citrus and some spice.
Flavor - WOW!!, nice smooth balance of hops and malt. More like an IPA with awesome hop flavor.
Palate - light/medium mouhfeel with good carbonation. Finish is bitter and has no aftertaste.
Overall - Probably the best Pale ale I have had!!! I could drink this all night, tastes great on hot summer day!!

12 oz. Bottle courtesy of Naka. Pours a clear amber with a medium off-white head that lasts throughout and leaves fair lacing on the glass. Excellent grapefruity-citrus hop aroma with a slight spiciness and a subtle malt character in the background. Flavor is nicely balanced sweet malt combined with the citrusy hops and a mild peppery kick in the finish. Medium bodied. Great Pale Ale.

Bottle. Aroma of earth, citrus, pine, spice. Flavor quite bitter and overflowing with juicy citrus along with a light biscuit/doughy malt, though clearly the hops are the focus here, and they are quite lovely. Clearly an IPA, but still a very good one.

Bottle thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum.  I¬íve been waiting to try this one for quite some time now.  Pours a semi-cloudy orange-brown with a small white head.  Aroma of caramel malt, brown sugar, citrus hops, and grapefruit.  Flavor is initially rather tangy with hop oils and citrus and then mellows with a maltier finish.  This is pretty tasty.  I¬íd love to have this as a session beer, if only it was distributed in NY.  Good stuff.
8/4/8/4/16 (4.0/5)

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2009 I am not surprised to see that this is by a good amount the highest rated APA on earth - it deserves to be.  Wacky drawing of a king on the label that appears to symbolize something, but it is unclear what.  Brown pour and light head.  Very full honey malt and floral hop aroma, with not a whiff of skank.  A robust, hoppy APA - solidly bittered with touches of freshly picked basil and mint.  There was clearly no skimping on the high quality hops.  Alpha King is not at all nasty tho, not like some hop bombs can become.  I don¬ít taste much malt (what with all the hops) but it does not seem unbalanced.  This is as full and fine a pale ale as I can think of, and It goes to the top of my APA charts.  It is generously priced too, for the quality of the product.  Thanks, Three Floyds!

12 oz bottle.  Pours slightly red amber with a small off-white head.  Lots of hop aromas, with spice and grapefruit, backed up by biscuit and caramel aromas.  Flavors include a lot of spicy, grapefruit, and grassy hops, and a solid hoppy bitterness on top of a toasty biscuit malt profile and a touch of caramel.  Very dry.  Really very nice and hop-forward.
12oz bottle, thanks to Allstar for this one. Pours cloudy amber in color with white head. Aorma citrus hops with a malty backbone. Taste citrus hops and roasted malt with bitter finish.

On draft at FFF. Pours a hazy dark orange colour with a medium sized white head that laces the glass. Pleasant aroma of floral hops, citrus, lemon, grapefruit, caramel and malts. Bitter, dry flavour that is similar to the aroma.

Bottle @ √ñlbutikken. Pours golden amber color with white head. Hoppy citrus aroma sweet apricots peaches citrus. Taste hops hops more hops citrus sweet peaches apricots. Perfect balance. Perfect Pale Ale
Draft. Rich amber beer with a whitish head. Light grapefruit aroma. Grapefruit and caramel flavor with light pine. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and light malt lingers with a light woodsiness.

I drank this from the bottle into a chalice.

The beer poured amber in color with a weak small white head and poor lacing.  

It smells hoppy with citrus and spice, but the hops are a sweer smelling hops.

This is an IPA at its core but incedibly drinkable.  Its sweet but hoppy and bitter.

In short: A sharp and intensely bitter IPA with a sugary malt backbone.  Excellent.
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed very fresh a few days after I received it from shawnm213.  Thanks a lot Shawn.
The look: Clear golden-copper body topped by a medium beige head
In long: The very aromatic nose blends pine-tree and citrus fruits.  A solid malt base with sugary caramel.  Sweetness is not bothersome but I found it a little sugary instead of being round and rich.  Hops are the main attraction.  The line between an APA and an american IPA is often a big gray zone but this one is definitely bigger, more intense and more bitter than 80% of the American IPAs.  APA¬Ö ok if you say so.  A sharp and very bitter dry finish that contrasts with the sweet sugary malt backbone.  This is not a refreshing highly drinkable APA.  This is an intense, sweet and very bitter IPA calling itself an APA.  This is truly an excellent beer.  The Alpha King of beer, this Dreadnaught¬ís for you.  Wasssssup?
Its silly to add much to what has already said.  Practically an IPA, just more drinkable.  Fantastic beer that well deserves its reputation.

Bottle, 12oz. It pours a creamy, fingerthic, beige head over a well-carbonated, slightly hazy orange-golden body. Citrusy, resiny nose with a touch of tropical fruits. Lovely sugary, caramel-like maltyness to give it balance. Full-bodied, creamy mouthfeel with a delicious bitterness. There¬ís sugary, caramel-like, almost beef-stock like malty flavors to cope with the citrusy, resiny flavors from the hops. Lasting finish with good bitterness. A lovely beer, and maybe it deserves a higher rating from me, but I find it a bit on the sweet side for a pale ale. (090718)
This was a great beer, strong citrus smell to it. Light carmel taste as well as a fruit after-taste. Overall a great beer. I poured it from the bottle.

Pours a hazy orange. Small head that dissipates quickly. Delicious aroma of grapefruit and malts. Lemony citrus flavors with a good hop bitterness at the end. This one is approaching a light IPA. Smooth and dry. Medium mouth feel with high carbonation to help round out the bitterness. Fantastic beer!

On tap from PP C-Bad. Copper rust in color. White head. Light caramel malt aromas. Very smooth in your mouth. Solid hop bitterness with quite yummy sweet malt balance. Fairly dry bitter finish. Great beer for the style and one of the best Pales I have tasted !

From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007
Floral and hop aromas. White head. Golden coloured very hoppy and fruity with a crisp and dry bitter finish.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2009 Bottle thanks to Capones. Well not usually a big fan of pales ales but this one is real nice. Dark amber pour. Didn¬ít even need to try to sniff if before i got a hint of the aroma, nice and citrusy. Great flavor very drinkable wish i could session with this beer.

12 oz bottle thanks to Vince. Orange/amber with an off white head. Big citrus hop aroma, also some pine and caramel. Flavor is a sweet malt base with a smooth bitterness that balances the sweetness out. Medium body, average carbonation and a soft creamy mouth feel. This beer lives up the hype, a perfectly balanced flavorful Pale. Thanks again Vince, cheers!

Cask at Clark Street Ale House in Chicago.  Surprisingly dark amber pour with a cream colored head.  Piney hops dominate the aroma of coarse, but some malt also.  Taste has some nice caramel covered apple, citrus and the hops.  Smooth mouthfeel, just enough carbonation, hand pull helps this of coarse.  Finish is not overly bitter.  Not a frequenter of pales, but this is the best American pale I¬íve had.  Three Floyds hop heavy style obviously works well with this.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Brand new bottle with its glossy label.  Pours a mahogany body with a yellow white head.  Dry dingy malt character, a bit soapy with some floral hoppiness and caramel malt bill.  This was better fresher. oh well.

12 oz bottle acquired via trade. A much darker amber pour than I expected, with a thin white head. Aroma is citrus hop with sweet caramel malt. Flavor is initially some light caramel malt, then a hop explosion of citrus, floral and pine, and it¬ís very bitter at the end, but in a pleasant way. The mouthfeel is very full, this almost resembles an ESB in some ways honestly. Incredibly tasty brew, and I can¬ít wait to have more from 3F.

on tap at the fff brewpub.  pours a amber color with a thin white head.  The smell is hoppy and citrusy.  flavor is nice and sweet with a smooth mouth feel it finishes with a nice bitter hop ending.  Very nicely banlanced.

Bottle.  Poured a deep amber color with a small off-white head.  Nose is dominated by hoppy grapefruit and pine notes.  Medium bodied, slightly oily with soft carbonation.  Flavor is sweet caramel malt with grassy hop notes with almost a cider feel.  Finishes sweet and slightly bitter.  Big thanks to cexshun and bulldogp04 for sending these!

Aroma: mild, slightly sweet malts, flowers. butter, caramel.  Appearance: translucent, light golden amber, thin white head. Flavor: light malt, minimal bitterness, creamy, light caramel.  Palate: smooth, soft, creamy, slow fade finish.  Overall: a nice creamy, soft beer with a nice balance of subtle malts and slight bitterness.  Used to much heavier styles (I¬ím a huge barleywine fan) so the subtleties of this beer may have been lost on me....

Botlle. Clear deep amber with a dense and lacing off white head. Aromas of caramel, flowers, grass and lots of fruit. Flavour of malt, grapefruit, pine, caramel, chewy toffee and a lovely bitter hoppy backbone. Well balanced.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2012 Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Amber beer with a thin, off white head. Aroma of flora hops, citrus, malt. Extremely well balanced and lively flavor with malt, citrus, and hops all prominent. Refreshing mouthfeel. A very good pale ale.

Bottle, bought @ √òlbutikken, Cph.
Pours clear redish copper with a fine, small, creamy, off-white head. Nice duration. Lovely hoppy aroma. Grassy, grapefruit, lemons, melons, apple and pine.  slight caramel malty base. Low carbonation, dry and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is extremely well-balanced between malty sweetness and fruity hops. Pine, grass, hay, grapefruit, apricot. Lovely, long, lingering fruity bitterness.
Reddish copper color, thick creamy head.  Floral-perfume aroma and flavor.  Moderate malt flavor, low malt aroma.  I don¬ít see this as a hop lovers pale ale, but it is nicely done.

Slightly cloudy with a lasting off-white head, leaving some lacing. Citrus and pine hops in the nose, with caramel malty sweetness and a hint of green tobacco. Dry hoppy flavour with some malt, and intense bitterness.
Bottle @ Olbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours amber with a creamy white foam and lacings. Nose is hoppy and sweet malty. Lots of peach, citrus and caramel. Full and smooth body. Dry hoppy end. Good!

Dark amber, medium-fine head with some retention.

 Fruity, caramel/ strong orange, hop.

 medium body, not fizzy. Not resh - more like a winter warmer.

 The aroma is fantastic, and the orange translates into a great aftertaste. Not too bitter - a symphony.

 A joy to drink.

 Purchased in √òlbutikken.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Deep clear copper color with virtually no head.  Aroma of citrus and grassy hops, balanced with caramel malts and a biscuity scent.  Taste of sweet malt and citrus hops.  Smooth and crisp mouthfeel, medium.  Very nice pale ale, I could drink a few of these!

Beautiful aroma of citrus hops, grapefruit, pine.  The Appearance is a gorgeous red/brown, white head.  The flavor is citrus/grapefruit, with caramel malts in the background.  The finish detours into a citrus hoppy bitterness.   Simple and beautiful, one of the best of its style.
Clear golden with a medium white head. Aroma had lovely hops, pine and peaches. Flavour had plenty of hops, pine and malty notes. Finished bitter. Lovely balance.
This brown pour has a hoppy nose.  It has a nice amount of sweetness to it that cuts the floral flavor.  Bitter and smooth finish.
This is a solid pale ale.  Not as over-hopped as some IPAs, but still has some great flavor and a pretty good hop kick (especially for a pale ale).  Very drinkable on a summer day on the deck.

12 oz bottle from a trade with dmschefke. pours orange with a mid sized white head. aroma of citrus hops and caramel malt. the flavours are the same as the aroma. really balanced and solid apa. one id have anytime. thanks dave!

bottle from √∏lbutikken.
amber, small thick orange head.
aroma is fresh and stael hops, pine, caramel, flowers, malt sweetness.
palate is a bit watery.

Botella, courtesy of Pinball. Golden amber clear colour with a creamish steady beige head. Sweet very hoppy caramel aroma with pine and some fruit. Good mouthfeel. Soft malt, hoppy sweet, flowery, somewhat piney, caramel flavour. Surprisingly mild bitterness. Dry hoppy sweetish finish.

This is supposed to be one of the best apa¬ís out there. Let¬ís see if it can stand up to the hype.

Apperance: Amber colored with a creamy head and quite alot of lacing.

Aroma: Caramel, Pine, Grass, Exotic fruit. Very fresh!

Flavor: Exotic fruit, Pine, Caramel, Bitter hops, Caramel, Hint of bread.

Palate: Solid malt base with a kick-ass bitterness at the end. Feel very refreshing and quite balanced even tho the ibu¬ís must be quite high!

This is a very good APA. Probably one of the best i¬íve ever tried.

I waited a long time for this beer. Got it on tap in Chicago. Pours cloudy amber with small dense lasting head. This is complex huge citrussy hop and malt mix. Thick almost oily on the palate, wow. The hops wins! Not to be taken lightly.

Clear orange look with a nice big white head. Aroma holds loads of grapefruit along with some creamy notes and grain. Rock solid flavor with a relativly oily palate. Again mostly grape moutaroma with a wellbalanced hop bitter malty sweet flavor.

Bottle pours a deep cloudy reddish brown.  Nice hop aroma: citrus mostly with a bit of a pine backbone.  Very crisp aroma.  Malt is only slightly detectable.  Flavor is bit more muttled than the aroma had me believe.  Malt is more evident up front and pine hops take over after that.  Citrus flavor is more evident in finish, but is lighter than expected.  Aroma was near perfect for stlye (IMO) but flavor seemed a bit disjointed to me.

Wow.  This is clearly a beer that¬ís heavy on the late hop additions.  SO much aroma coming off of it, with little to no discernible bitterness, and a ridiculous amount of hoppy goodness in the flavor.  They¬íre not kidding around here!
12 oz. bottle from Lone Hill Liquor, compliments of Stan The MAN. Citrus and hoppy aroma, good carbonation. Hints of caramel with minimal head. Very well balanced pale ale. Poured a brownish color.
Great pale ale.  The best.  On draft at ESPNZone in Chicago.  Watched while the Wings beat the Ducks in game 7.  Great night.
12oz bottle courtesy of shawnm213, thanks Shawn. Kind of dark copper with a slight orange tint on the edges. Light hop aroma, a little piney. Light hoppiness, slight citrus. Pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 13, 2015 Had this many times over the years, but today¬ís rate is from a 12 oz. bottle dated 12/1/15. This is now available at my nearest Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons). Aroma: Nice strong Cascade/Centennial bouquet, but also a rather old-school caramel malt balance. Appearance: Rich, copper pour with soft carbonation holding up a solid light tan cap that settles into a thick skin. Flavor: Balanced initially, but citrus comes out a bit more midway through, leading to a bitter, citrusy finish which still carries some malt sweetness. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish. Overall: There was a time when I considered this a "desert island" beer, one that I¬íd always want to have close at hand. In 2015, it¬ís epoch has passed. That being said, it¬ís one of the most noteworthy, and extant, examples of APA from it¬ís time... a bit of a time machine in a bottle.  I¬íll probably still give Alpha King a go on occasion, but I no longer consider it a modern, top-flight APA.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Sahara Mart (Bloomington, IN), 5/15/09
 Part of the totally and completely made up"The Geororodanda Beer Sampling Party"


Aroma: Really nice citrus hops aroma

Appearance: Great dark red/orange color

Flavor: Really hoppy, nice flavor

Palate: Great mouthfeel

Overall Impression:
Really nice beer, loved this one, the true champ of the totally and completely made up beer night (see above).  A true hops champion.
It¬ís really that good.  Yep...haven¬ít had it for a minute now, but it¬ís really that good.  Promise.

pours dark amber with full white head. aroma is really hoppy with pine and citrus bursting forth and a hint of malt. drinks the same, way hoppy for a pale. very IPA style with lots of citurs and earthy pine. great brew

Bottle. 
Pours an amber colour with a foamy off white head. 
It has a nice hoppy and fruity aroma with peach, pine and citrus notes. 
Flavour is extremely well balanced with notes of citrus, pine, fresh fruit and a long pleasant aftertaste.

First off, no way this is a pale ale.  Whatever it is it¬ís awesome.  Smell is like hop infused vanilla cake icing.  Less of the sweetness in the flavor with a nice floral twinge to accompany the piney hops.  Great feel in the mouth and the lips will be sticky with this facial forefather.  Reminiscent of a DIPA.  Thank You Three Floyds.  2009 12oz.
Delicious - not sweet - hoppiness is spicy without much of sourness that sometimes comes in other pale ales - nicely bitter aftertaste

Bottle.  Mostly clear reddish-copper color with a big frothy off white head.  Hoppy aroma dominated by citrus and pine.  Has a nice crisp hoppy taste.  Grapefruit and malt initially before finishing more on the dry and piney side.  Medium body with a dry, syrupy texture.  Lively carbonated and leaves nice lacing throughout.  One of the hoppiest APA¬ís I¬íve ever had.  Great beer for my 100th review!

Bottled. Pours clear amber with a nice, creamy off-white head. Good lacinng. Hoppy nose with citrus. Flavour with malt, hops, caramel and fruit. Medium bodied. Crisp and bitter finish. Very enjoyable.

Flaske: Superl√¶kker duft af citrus og en smule mango sl√•r en i m√∏de fra denne karamelbrune √∏l. Smagen er fantastisk balanceret med sm√• bobler i mundfylden. Fin bitterhed til at bakke en karamels√∏d maltbase op. Og en god del citrus ogs√• i smagen. Fantastisk √∏l, is√¶r for 6%.
Bottle.Dark orange colour with medium lasting head.Strong hoppy and bitter fruity flavor.Note of greapsfruits and pine,nice well balanced and powerful mouthfeels.
Map room  Pre DLD day ... Ok may not have been at my best but YEAUCH ... copper ... thin white lacing ... over fizzy ... syrupy pine nose ... HUGE HUGE BITTERNESS ... pine and pale ale hop

my favourite american pale ale (not sure how it differs from an ipa but whatever)  It would be amoungst my favourite ipa¬ís also.  Great nose of citrus and flowery hops.  The same can be said of the flavour.  Nice finish, not too dry.  Easy drinking and great tasting.

Great pale ale, fantastic fresh hoppy yet sweet aroma of green fresh hops. Nice rather full-bodied for the style with a big bunch of sweet caramell, sweet fruity hops and a fresh biting bitterness. The beer finishes with a lovely lingering sweetness and a fresh, green hop bite. Extremely drinkable, extremely flavourfull, extremely yummy.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2009 Always enjoyable. A solid Pale. Nice balanced flavors with the malt sweetness and the right amount of hops. Light fruity hops and no bad flavors linger at all. Pine and grapefruit are noticable.

Bottle Thanks to ksurkin!  I had one last year which I think had a little age on it as I wasn¬ít too impressed.  Kenny was kind enough to bring me one from DLD.  Fresh makes a difference!  This is wonderful.  Nice hop aromas and excellent hop and malt flavors.  Hoppy enough for the hophead and balanced enough to please everyone else.

Aroma is of a fresh picked hop. Absolutely wonderful. Pours a ruby/orange with a decent head. Great flavors of citrus and pine, mixed in with maybe some apple..Overall has a nice complexity that seems to keep me guessing. Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours a nice clear orange color with a great mediumsized head. Looks really good in the glass! Aroma is freshhoppy with some caramell in there aswell. Taste is at first a bit caramellsweet but the finish is hopbitter with a lingering nice bitter feeling. Great hints of citrus and grapefruit to!

Bottle thanks to StFun.  Pours a lightly hazed crimson amber with a large beige head that falls off to a medium size rather quickly, leaving ample lace on the sides.  Large pine and citrus hop notes, nice malt background.  Medium bodied, lightly sweet, but balanced.  Finishes with a nice light bitterness.  Really well balanced, and quite tasty.
On tap at Osteria via Stato.  Dark amber- small head.  Aroma is hoppy.  First, middle, and last taste is hoppy.  Very sharp bite and bitter.
Pours ruby with a nice head bitter hoops with citrus and pine very nice apa

bottle.  Pours ruby with a creamy, brown-tinted head.  Aroma is bright pine and citrus.  Flavor starts with toffee and red fruit, then transitions to cherry and grapefruit . . . so complex for a pale ale! Finishes malty and bitter, everything in balance.  Overall, this is a very solid, flavorful brew, definitely the best pale ale I¬íve tried.

12 oz bottle courtesy of daknole. Pours a copper color with a big beige head that slowly dissipated. The aroma is biter hops, rye bread, citrus and pine. The taste is hops forward with a nice bitering that is never harsh. The main body is caramel and toffee. The mouthfeel is light, smooth and malty. The finish is short with some lingering caramel. Overall: A very good APA.

Pours a slightly hazy amber orange with a medium white head.  Aroma is citrus and floral hops, pine, and spices.  Taste is very similar to an IPA, with a bit of sweetness, caramel, and pepper.  Overall a pretty decent drink.
Bottle bonus from StFun.  Dark amber brown pour, a little carbonation and a nice citrusy hop aroma.  Flavor was orange citrus, a little pine and nice and bitter on the aftertaste.  Very good!
UPDATED: MAY 8, 2009   pours amber.  citrus bitterness against some sweet malts.  caramel.  medium body.
12 oz bottle. A deep red/amber color with a white head that lingers.  Wonderful hop character, much like an IPA.  Very smooth and fresh.  Simply a magnificent APA!!!

Golden amber pour wuth a wispy white head. Hoppy aroma with a little floral and pepper to it. Semi-sweet tasting with hops closing it out. The flavor of the beer clings to my tongue and cheeks. Very light citrus flavor comes through after the drink.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2012 Re-rate 10/27/10.  Picked up a bottle while visiting Louisville.  Copper color, pours with a good white head.  Frothy lacing.  The aroma is both citrusy as well as showing pine needles and quite a bit if resin.  Caramel and light toasted grains add depth to the nose.  Well balanced flavors.  I can see why many view this as one of the best Pale Ales around.  The malts are a bit doughy, with a strong dose of caramel lurking.  An aggressive hop flavor that again shows both pine and citrus.  Fairly sharp bitterness for a less than 7% abv.  Solid stuff.  Original Rating 3/12/09.  Bottle from Archer Liquors. Pours an amber color with a moderate off-white head with some decent staying power. Fresh citrusy hoppy aroma with some caramel malts. Strong sweet caramel malty backbone here, some citrus, pine resin, with a sharp bitter edge. Very well balanced mix of malts and hops. One of the better Pale Ales I?ve ever had but not the slam dunk top 10 I thought it might be. Would love to have access to this one on a regular basis.

On tap at Rich O¬ís in New Albany. By far the best APA I¬íve ever tasted. Good hop bitterness but with a sweet overtone that lingers on the palate. Very refreshing, I feel like I could run a marathon after having a few of these.

Dark ruby amber in color with little head. Very nice aroma of citrus and tropical fruit. I¬ím a sucker for these beers with tropical fruitiness. Good hoppiness in the aroma provides some zing. Wonderfully balanced taste of lush fruit, papaya, mango, with moderate bitterness and a strong caramel malt backbone. Medium bodied. I thought this was an IPA, but turns out its a APA. Probably the tastiest pale ale I¬íve had.

Aroma is sugary malt with enticing floral hops with a citrus zing. Pours a nice copper, reddish color with a small, off white head. Flavor is sweet up front, followed by caramel malt with a blast of pine tasting hops and a citrus lingering on the tongue. Nicely flavored APA. A little thin on the palate but very smooth. Excellent beer for the hop lover or someone that wants some zing after warming up with sweet, malty beers.

From StFun via trade.  The pour was dark copper in color and clear.  The head was off-white, creamy and dense and created nice rings of lacing.  The aroma was citrus up front with a super nice compliment of sugar cookie malts and some light floral hops, grass and pine resin.  The flavor was on the sweet side, with plenty of sweet caramel malt, light citrus and grassy hops on the backside.  The mouthfeel was above average.  I wish it had more of a citrus bite to balance against the caramel malt sweetness and grassy finish but overall it was well ahead of just about any other APA out there.

reddish pour with a nice frothy head.  Hop aroma is resinous and piney, reminds me of the hop profile of an IPa. Mouth is bitter, malty, although it finishes in a nice smoothness.  excellently hopped APA with a great ballance.

400th rating. Pours a reddish copper with copious carbonation. Aroma is reminiscent of an IPA- powerful piney resinous hops with grapefruit and citrus notes as well. Flavor is sweet fruity hops with a hard hitting resin bomb of a hop character. Malt character provides excellent balance- caramel makes its way in there, but hops are dominating. Excellent balance. Palate is smooth and full for the style. Excellent specimen.

pours a reddish brown with a small head. Aroma is exquisite- smells like an IPA, piney and citrusy hops, along with a definite caramel and fruity sweetness. Flavor has definite malt character balancing out with the hops nicely, but there is a definite bitter stage with a smooth finish. Palate is very nice- somewhat thin, but not in a negative way, and the citrusy bitterness sticks pleasantly long after the sip. Excellent pale ale.

[Bottle] Pours a hazy amber with a medium beige head. Aroma is crystal malt with tons of floral and citric hops. Much thicker aroma than I was expecting, and a lot darker beer too. Mouthfeel is more what I would expect from a pale ale though. Plenty of citrus and caramel flavors, with a touch of florals. Thinner in the mouth, but the caramel flavor is pervasive. Very nice, drinkable beer. Not too bitter, and a dry finish.

bottle poured a glowing amber color with a one finger off white head that clings to the glass well. aroma has fruity hops, citrus peel, pines, and sweetness. all about this one. mouth feel is fairly hefty for such low carbonation. flavor has grassy hops, caramel sweetness, and lighter bitterness than expected. the pale malt starts to hit, and this starts to male better sense. plenty of citrus goodness but it keeps restrained.

Amber color with pale head.  Aroma of mild roasted malt.  Somewhat bitter, but just right hop content.  Very mild citrus, with just a slight hint of caramel.  I did not care for the dry aftertaste, though.

Pours a hazy orange-brown with a thin white head. Citrus , piney hop nose. Lots of caramel up front with a strong hop finish. Not as hoppy as I remember it used to be years ago, but still a great American IPA.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2009 Bottle from Jamvin23. Pours orange amber with an off white head. Floral hop aroma with caramel malt and a touch of citrus. The flavor had caramel malt up front, which yields to a nice floral and citric hop bitterness. An outstanding session ale. Something I could easily drink all night.
Bottle.  Hazy orange, almost red. Aroma: Pine, Citrus Flavor: Nice hops flavor with a citrus hint.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2009 12oz bottle at Birreria Paradiso.   Amber-brown color with a thin head.   Aroma of light caramel, and citric hops.   Flavors of brown sugar, caramel, and some grapefruit and orange hops.   Moderate bitterness and a bit on the sweet side.   Medium-light bodied and a bit lifeless.   Not really what I was expecting; lots of darker malt flavors and not as assertively hoppy as I had hoped. (3.1)
Rerate: 12oz bottle.   Apparently much fresher this time.   Awesome peach, orange, and mango aroma.   The flavor has the caramel that was there before, but backs it up with a ton of tropical fruity hops.   Great balance and drinkability.   So much better than last time, and a truly beautiful pale ale.
