Some light caramel malts try to stand up to the intense hops, but didn¬ít have quite enough backbone to stand up; flavor was enjoyable nevertheless.  Bitterness lasts long after the drink is over.  This beer was incredible on the palate...unlike any other Pale Ale I¬íve ever consumed.  I would consider this a very good drink, but not excellent (but I¬ím not really a true hophead).  As a side note, the hop bitterness loses a bit of its edginess with a bit of warming...

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2009 I have the honor of entering the 1000th rating of this highly regarded American pale. Bottle purchased at Crown #15 in Fishers, IN. It pours a deep copper with a few floaties and a thin, creamy, beige head that leaves behind patchy lacing. The nose is sublime: a perfect balance of big citrus, light pine and earthy hops along with a solid, sweet malt backing that smells of candy sugar. Quite nice. The mouthfeel is medium-full bodied and slick with a controlled bitter hop finish. The flavor is big piny, citric and resinous hops along with a solid, moderately sweet malt backing. While lingeringly bitter at the finish, the malt backing is such a perfect match that the balance of flavors is seamless. This is an amazingly flavorful beer for one so quaffable. Each sip compels you to take another. I can see myself drinking these one after another until I go blind, pass out, or see God. If I lived in Indiana or the Chicagoland area, this would be, without question, my staple beer.
stong hoppy intese nose of beautiful cascade flowers. nice citrus grapefruit cut grass feel on the pallate.  smooth and silky.  a solid pale ale probably almost more of an american ipa.

The second or third time I¬íve had this and, boy, have I changed my mind. The super-aggressive hops are pretty unpleasant. The citrus in palate is more like bitter pith. I¬íd have to be in the right mood for this one to go down.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2009 Bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  Poured a deep amber color with a nice off-white head.  Aroma of grapefruit and hops.  The balance on this beer is spot on.  A nice, spicey malt backbone greets you and leads you into a fruity hop hit that tingles your tongue.  Very smooth beer.  My first Three Floyds beer, and hopefully not my last.  Very good.

[Bottle] Pours dark amber with a long-lasting, light tan head.  Surprisingly thick with a medium-long finish.  Excellent. Malt and fruity (grapefruit and something else) hops blend nicely in the aroma. Also, a small amount of spice appears as it warms. Fruitiness was more pronounced when cold, but as it warmed the caramel malt took control up front yielding to the grapefruit hops towards the end.  The finish is citrusy and bitter. My first Three Floyds product, and it was very well done, especially the mouthfeel which is amazingly thick.

(bottle) Pours a dark copper with a lingering white head, that leaves a nice lacing on the glass, just a great appearance.  Aroma is wonderful, very fruity with grapefruit and lychee with some slight floral notes too.  As it warms however, a spice-like character develops and complements the fruity aroma.  The taste is amazing, very fruity initially, somewhat like an ambrosia salad, with a lot of pineapple in the forefront with lingering hop bitterness that lasts forever.  Upon warming caramel is thrown into the mix, and perfectly complements the fruity flavors.  The mouthfeel on this beer is great, thick and chewy, by far the thickest APA I¬íve ever had.  This beer is the perfect example of an APA.

Damn I like this beer. Sampled at the Map Room in Chicago. Fresh, citrus hops attack the nose luring you into the first blissful sip. Splendid malty backbone over which a blanket of hops has been scattered. Many IPA/APA¬ís are more bitter. None impress me as much as this.

From jcr, 12 oz. bottle, thanks John! Pours a hazy orange amber color with a big beautiful off white rocky head that stays around for awhile. Has really nice spidery lacing along the glass.  Nose is citrus hops and some floral hops with hints of mint.  Palate is medium with a bitter bite on the end of the tongue but very smooth the rest of the way down.  Flavor is hops, with lemon and i keep getting a little hint of chocolate towards the end.  Phenominal beer, great bonus beer from jcr.

Rating #100

Hazy, dark burnt orange body.  Large, rocky off-white head with excellent retention.  Leaves thick patches of lacing on the glass.  The aroma shows a near even split between grapefruit and grassy hop varieties, with a touch of pine resin.  A few drops of honey and lemon add complexity to the nose, as does a slight hint of cooling mint. The aroma is very unique and inviting.  The flavor has a very light caramel base.  Fresh orange juice and hops of seemingly every variety add pleasing contrasts and depth.  Honey and cream add smoothing elements.  Its not overly hoppy, but well balanced, complex and subtle.  Bright, clean finish.  Medium bodied and very smooth.  Very nice, unique brew.

Bottle/trade. The over the top aroma of hops has an interesting contrast in the underlying malt taste. I liked the great head the beer produced when poured and the flavor flowed with a heavy character to it.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 Bottle from the local Jewel grocery store.  Pours orange with a nice, citrussy head.  Smells of citrus, hops, and pine cones.  Heavy mouthfeel for what looks like a hardcore pale ale.  Actually so hoppy it gave me acid reflux.  I like it, but it doesn¬ít like me.

Nov 2005 - Beer poured with little head, deep brownish red color. The aroma of pine was really noticeable, even just after removing the cap. This beer had a really nice, thick mouthfeel. The taste was overwhelmingly piney hops but with some nice sticky malts in there, too.

9-24-07 bottle.  Beautiful head atop a beautiful thick amber color.  Head is long lasting and thick and perfect. Amazing hoppy apricot aroma.  Great flavor with a tiny hint of sweet orange in it.  Such a great beer.  Amazing mouth feel!
Bottle. Wow, not a pale ale but amazing. Pours reddish orange with a lingering head (great lacing). Bright grassy citrusy hoppy aroma. Flavor is strong hops. Long bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2014 Big thanks to DrBayern for this amazing pale!
  Pours a rich, cloudy honey/amber color, with a big lasting, and lasting, and lasting beige head.  Never seen anything less than a rich stout hold onto a head the way this did. Smell is huge bold hops, citrusy, and fruity sweet caramel and is just mouthwatering.  Taste is very nicely hopped, but not overdone at all.  A great flavorful sweetness really rounds this beer out, and a nice satisfying bitterness, and full mouthfeel make this one of my all time favorites.  A must try if you like American Pales. 

Rebate of fresh bottle 2014.  Still good but didn¬ít wow me.

dark amber almost ruby nice frothy carmel head the faded quickly leaving some nice sticky lacing. big piney hop aromas. nice flavor. flowery and piney with a hint of malt.smooth and coating on the mouthfeel with a zinger of a finish. nice and tingly bitterness. killer ipa.

I told my beer mentor that I was not crazy about pale ales, and he assured me that this beer would likely change my mind.  Well, it did.  The color is a gorgeous, hazy medium amber.  The aroma wafting upwards is one of resinous, grassy, slightly herbaceous hops, perhaps a touch of citrus thrown in for good measure.  Flavor is a slighted toasted malt, with some of that citric quality coming through.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2009 Rating #99! From mreusch, (thanks Matt!) Pours a nice mohagony with light head. Hoppy, slight pine, touch of caramel aroma that carries through to the flavor. Very smooth. Has to be the best pale I¬íve had, taste more of an IPA. Would have again if they sold it around here!

12 oz. bottle. Aroma dominated by soapy yeast and herbal hops smells. Piney, dry aroma with a hint of lime, reminiscent of a gin and tonic. Cookie character develops in the aroma as I sip. Pleasant smell but not as strong as I expected. Pours a hazy amber/light brown with a gold hue and small amount of bubbling. Moderate to large amount of thick, cream-colored head. Produces nice lacing. Dry hops dominate the taste at first. The malts are surprisingly sweet though hard to notice at first because they are overwhelmed by the hops. Initially, I found this beer very poorly balanced, but as I continued to sip, I got past the hops shock, and the underlying biscuity malt qualities emerged, with welcome flavors reminiscent of peanut brittle and peanut butter cookies. My flavor rating on the early sips would have been a 5 or 6, while my rating on the later sips would have been 8 or 9. I¬íll compromise with a 7. Long, strong, bitter aftertaste. Medium to full body. Creamy and a little oily in the palate. Easy to drink. I used to love this beer when I drank it in college. This is the first time I¬íve had it in about three years. It doesn¬ít blow me away like it used to, but I still consider it a good beer. While far too strong to qualify as a session beer, this is the sort of brew that stands up very well to multiple sips. If I had three of these in a row and rated only the third, I¬ím sure I¬íd rate it higher than a 3.7.

Seems like a twin brother of Dogfish 120 but with more hops (!) Thin, delicious, juicy, spicy. Almost like smelling salts the way this smacks you right in the face. Amazing. God in a glass, basically.

Strawberry citrus aroma. Hazy gold/brown with mottled beige lacing on top.  Sticky bitterness with spreading hoppiness...coats your mouth completely with hop acids. Lots of grapefruit and buttered biscuits in aftertaste. It¬ís a shame 3F will be scaling distribution out of Wisconsin.

Pours a hazed golden amber. Nose seems to have apricots on it. Flavor is heavy with hops with the apricot present on the palate as well. Just as with other hop happy brews, you get that taste of hops lodged in the back of your mouth and it lingers. Feel is great. I get a silky smooth texture that slides over my tongue. Oh so drinkable. A hop lover and a craft brew lovers dream. Awesome beer.

12oz bottle from north belt west liquor. good looking caramel nut brown color. pours with a tall fluffy white head, that leaves behind thick sticky lacing. loads of citric hop on the nose. tropical fruits and nutty grains are also apparent. starts sweetish, with a full malt profile and plenty of fresh citric american hops. great amereican pale ale.

12 oz. bottle.  Amber pour, thick foamy off-white head.  Pine, hops, slight citrus on the nose.  Probably the best balanced beer I¬íve had.  Fantastic.  Malt, hops, and more pine and citrus in the flavor.  This beer kick¬ís ass!  Pale Ale dream.  Smooth mouthfeel with sweet slightly bitter finish.  Thank You Nick, may I have another.
My favorite beer as of 9/2/2007. Deliciously hoppy. Almost over hopped, as the malt is somewhat lacking. Still, for those of us who enjoy drinking pine cones, this is grade A
Beer was fantastic. After experiencing new types of craft beers, I really happened to admire the taste of Alpha King and other Three Floyd Ales.

Mode: Firkin
Source: Brewfest, Real Ale Festival

hazy amber, frothy head, thick lace, grassy hop aroma, medium body, lots of hop flavor and lingering bitterness, tounge scraper required, out of balance

still brutal, still over the top

same as always but these days a big hoppy pale ale is common

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

One of my old favorites.  I always thought this was really an IPA.  At the Pale Ale level, there really is no comparison, this one is the best.  Huge hoppy bite with a great malty backbone.  Very hoppy/citrusy but oh so drinkable.  I remember getting these around 5 years ago for 6.99 a sixer at my old hometown store.  They just quit shipping this to Ohio, so I stocked up....
wow was I suprised when i had this beer for the first time. So damn good, lots of flavor of fruits and citus. great smell and malty taste. super tasty! Try it!

350 ml bottle mailorder from archerliquors.  Hazy copper brown with a fizzy white head.  Citrus and pine aroma.  Sweet malty taste followed by a  fruit and pine taste with a slightly bitter finish.  Decent.

Yikes, this surely is a tasty treat. Local bottle shop just stocked this so I was lucky enough to buy a couple bottles and not having to shell out the dough for an entire sixer. Assertive aroma dominated by crisp tingling hops that scream of sugary tart grapefruit and explosive evergreen. Smells "smooth" sure gets the senses excited. Hazy dark copper pour, almost amber in color. Good filmy head and solid lacing. This beer is thick and very full bodied, heavy malt with a big bitter kick. Aggressive on the palate with a fairly smooth finish. Hippity Hop this really is an IPA all the way (but I like the APA classification from FFF). Beautiful arrangement of hops both floral and fruity. Big time grapefruit with lemon and pine. Juicy malts that are bready and biscuity. An overall attack on the senses, well done.

On tap from Three Floyds; good head with piney/hoppy aroma.  Good flavor of citrus and hop with the expected bitter finish of an APA; always better from the tap.  Looking forward to try other brews from Three Floyd if this is their ¬ístandard¬í.

From the bottle, courtesy of MrBendo, pours an opaque dark orangish color with a foamy head and nice lacing.  Aroma is definitely malty, maybe some citrus, slight smell of alcohol.  Flavor is malty again, caramel, thick on the tongue, not much by way of hops though.  Really good beer.
thanks miketd for the bottle! pours hazy copper, 2 finger head very airy head with lots of lacing.  spicy caramel upfront hopfinish. not highly carbinated, but very lively

damn fine beer.  i¬íll work on writing better reviews over time.  i¬ím tempted to say "starts with a burst of pine hops - but that¬ís because it does and that what the reviewer before me wrote.  so, fuck it, that¬ís what i¬ím gonna say.  nice hazy orangish amber appearance. nice head when ya pour it right.  and there IS some chemical taste to it too.... kind of funky ... good shit though... can¬ít live without Alpha King.... AK (a to the mutha fuckin¬í k)

Thanks for the bottle from secret Santa!  in your face hoppy aroma as I pop the cap.  Small quickly fading head.  Amber color.  Hop bitterness has a mixture of grapefruit hops and something else..possibly the Warrior hops.  I would actually call this an IPA. Nice.  I can see why it¬ís rated so high.

This starts with a burst of pine hops.  It pours a hazy orangish amber, with a huge fluffy white head.  In tasting, there¬ís a nice hop bitterness, however, there¬ís an almost chemical aftertaste that I can¬ít place.  Get rid of that aftertaste, and this would be up amongst the best beers out there.

6 Pk - I¬ím not really a huge PA or IPA fan, but this sounded good and was the only thing remotely interesting at the liquor store I went to...  Pours a yellowish light amber color with a little foamy white head, (with surprising lacing for such little head).  Aroma is hops, pine needles, citrus (mostly grapefruit), honey, and general foral-ness.  Mouthfeel is dry, medium-to-full bodied, Flavor starts out hoppy, then slightly sweet and then to bitterness with dry finish and aftertaste.  This is similar to Founder¬ís Cenntennial IPA, which I actually liked just a little bit more, but don¬ít get me wrong this is pretty damn good!

Grapefruit all the way. Dark amber in color with long-lasting medium head. Very bitter taste of grapefruit and citrus. I can appreciate the complexity, but not my kind of beer. Not for those who wish to avoid bitter beer.

Very pretty amber and bright orange pour. Wild visible carbonation forms a well retained head, frothy and off-white in color. Lacing is thick and everywhere. The nose is loaded with Cascade hops, grapefruit galore. The grapefruit is only the beginnning however, as the aroma segues into a complex array of orange, spice, caramel, toasted grains, honey, flowers, tangerine and mango. This really gives me the impression it¬ís nearing aromatic capacity for the amount of liquid present. The flavor is very well balanced, with sweet malts nicely tamed by explosive bitterness and moderate acidity. A strange, mineralic, hard water composite floats around in each sip. Fruit is plentiful and varies nicely with each interpretive/contemplative swallow. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied, well carbonated and pretty smooth, but it¬ís also quite dull. I suppose that translates to an easily sessionable quaffer, but it interests my palate and stimulates my senses very little. I prefer a new world pilsner with these qualities for a session beer. The finish is aromatic, lightly warming, of admirable duration, with grapefruit acidity and floral and caramel notes lingering. Very nice, nothing amazing.

I¬íve been wanting to try this beer forever.  Finally got my hands on some after a road trip to WI.  Aroma of pines and...cat piss?  Very odd, bitter-sweet in the nose.  Flavor is pure pine and sticky-sweet malt.  Finish is excessively dry.  I wouldn¬ít consider this an APA.  I like my hoppy beers more floral/citrus and the hops here just taste odd and borderline astringent.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy dark amber color with a large creamy beige head that is mostly lasting and leaves thick lacing on the glass.  The aroma is citrus hops and sweet malt.  The flavor is again citrus hops (mostly grapefruit), caramel malts, and decent bitterness.  Medium bodied, smooth and creamy, hoppy dry finish.  This is at the top of the list for APA¬ís for a reason.

RATE NUMBER 200, A SPECIAL FOR ME:

Here I am, I consider myself a true hop lover, especially of IPA¬ís.  I finally got my hands onto a 3 Floyds Alpha King beer.  Yes, I know, they say it s a "Pale Ale".  Yeah sure, what ever you say.  I have read about it, longed for it.  And now I have it!  It poured dark amber out of the 12 oz bottle into a shaker glass.  Forms a nice frothy foamy, head.  Aroma is of pine resins, a bit of grapefruits, malts.  This beer screams like a horny girl friend, "fuck me baby, fuck me".  At last I take a gulp, Ah......strong pines, caramel malts and a bit of citrus.  It bucks backs, demanding more with each thrust...I take another drink.....Its unbelievable  Better than the dream.....one realizes as each stroke that its better than the one before.  This is truly a wonderful beer.  A pale ale? Ah no, I promise you.  Lovers of IPA¬ís, behold, 3F¬ís has done it.  I feel lucky, now leave me alone so I can finish her off, now its my turn..... (Thanks Matt from MHC).
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: damn tasty pale ale.  i could drink this for the taste all day.  very well balanced all the way across the board.  i should have bought more  :)

Another great IPA from Three Floyds.  Nice copper color, glass full of citrusy flavors, very smooth on the palate.  My favorite IPA brewery by a longshot.Get your hands on this and other floyds brews!

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2010 ++++ Re Rate 9 Jan 2010 ++++
12 oz bottle sent to me by my 2009 winter Secret Santa. Pour is ever so slight orange copper with a one inch slightly off white head. Nice lacing. Aroma is fresh and full citrus, tangerine orange and pineapple along with a nice toasty mild caramel malt. Leans towards the hops, but still nice balance. Really nice nose. Taste is the pineapple citrus, with orange followed closely behind by the caramel malt. Also a nice straw pine mineral thing going on as well. Balanced, nice, but not quite as integrated as the nose. Palate is thin to medium, bordering on watery. Touch below average carbonation - easy drinking. The finish has the mineral, and a b it of an odd ashy taste. Nice as always, thanks Santa (9,4,7,3,16 - 3.9)

++++ Original Rating 6 Aug 2007 ++++
12 oz bottle from Binny¬ís Downtown, Chicago.  Pour is reddish copper with a nice off white head.  Aroma is citrus hops, malt and is very fresh smelling.  Taste is more of the citrus (oranges and lemons) hops and sweet caramel malt.  Hops lead on, providing a clean bitter finish.  Very nice beer. (7,4,8,4,15 - 3.8)

Something of a benchmark for PAs.  Citrus grabs you first, but the hoppiness emerges as the bottle warms.  Plenty of hops, plenty of the associated crisp/dry flavor and mouth feel.  Lots of lace from a head that disappears quickly.

Nice copper hue with a frothy head. Weighty yet crisp on the tongue. Snappy hop flavors right off the bat. Resin, pine and citrus. Healthy amount of hop goodness to complement the big malt flavors.  Alcohol content is rather low for my preference.  A little higher, I would have rated higher as well.

A cloudy copper color with a thin head that leaves a thick film of lacing. At the first taste the citrus jumps out at you, hops present themselves nicely as the beer warms. A really good beer that I wouldn¬ít mind trying again.

On tap at the Clarke Street Ale House.  Clear orangy beer with a light head.  This has a super hoppy aroma, it¬ís a little all over the place.  Reminded me of Dog Fish Head 120.  Funky, funky, funky.  Sweet caramel taste loaded to the brim of hops.  Grassy and bitter and wild.  FUNKY!

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2007 I first had the Alpha King awhile back in pre-RB days, but never rated it after joining the siter (ating #750 seems like a good time).  The King disappeared from PA for awhile only to make a triumphant return.  Nice hazy amber color/body with a light head.  Aroma is thick and sweet with citrus and rich malts ¬ñ just the right proportion of malt to hops.  Very pleasant, thirst quenching taste.  Only the King and Two Hearted have that great balance of grassy-citrus hops, pleasant malts, sweet, bitter, and delicious.  Wonderful stuff ¬ñ easily the best APA ever.
Excellent.  Citrus hops aroma.  Pretty amber with moderate head.  Hops produce a slight lingering after taste.  Nice refreshing brew.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2009 Just finished a tiling job in my bathroom and poured the only one I was able to get my hands on.  Job complete, I was feeling like the Alpha King himself.  What a well balanced beer that couldn¬ít have looked more inviting.  The copper ale promised subtle malts and a bright hop ending.  This beer gets an "A" for Alpha.
I love it!  Just a great every day drinking Plae Ale from the best hoppy dudes around

Bottle Courtesy of MrRomero, Nice pine notes balanced against citrus, just the most subtle of malts. Nice hoppy, a great finish, very nice just the lightest touch of sweetness. Finishes nice and easy, no overwhelming bit, but it lingers very nicely. Really wish I could get this one on a regualar basis, sorry red seal. Very easily drinkable but with just a lot of flavor. Excellent.

From a bottle at the Olympic.   Bold hoppy flavor, absolutely great for hop lovers.  Plenty of citrus in the finish nice to have a place in town that consistently serves this one.  Rating number 100 for me.

12 oz bottle from trade with dra19.  Pours a cloudy deep orange with a slight reddish hue.  Head settles down to a low even white layer.  Nice lively citric hop aroma.  The malt aroma isn¬ít lost, but the hops are in the forefront.  Palate is good, but I expected it to be a bit thicker.  The hops in the flavor are a bit subdued, but really compliment the nice malt base.  The finish is crisp and mildly bitter.  Will rerate if I get a bottle that I know is fresh and it tastes any different.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2008 I guess this beer was over head.  I tried because of all the positive comments. I didn¬ít ¬ìlove¬î it.  Not the best pale ale I have had. I found it on the over powering side. With out the smoothness I enjoy.

This is worth the hype -- full bodied hop-ale here.  I can¬ít say/write anything else about this that hasn¬ít already been mentioned in the some 941 ratings here, so I¬íll say this instead, lefts are better than rights.

I am not much of a big pale ale fan, but I saw this was rated high so I tried it.  This was some good stuff.  Quite hoppy with the typical three floyds citrus smack.  Smelled of very floral hops.  Balanced nicely.  Big taste for a pale ale. I bought a six pack at the brewery for $7, what a deal!

Hazy light amber color with a foamy off-white head.
No real retention and lacing.  Nice Citrus hop presence. Sweet and Hoppy with a nice hop after taste. Mouth filling without over doing it. If you like hops this beer will fill your mouth with the flavor and not let go till after it¬ís down your gullet I¬ím very glad I have many more of these!!!!

12 oz bottle. Poured a very nice looking amber with a foamy average size white head. Aroma was intense with lots of strong piney hops and tons of maltiness. Palate was perfect with a huge amount of quaffability, I could swallow this beer by the gallon loads, and just the right touch of lively carbonation. The flavor fell flat compared to the aroma and there was no noticable hops until the bitter finish and was mostly malty mixed in with a strong bitter finish. Once again a nice beer from FFF but not sure if it¬ís worth all the hype.

I love this beer. This was one of my first favorite pale ales, and still is one of my top pale ales.

Pours a burnt golden color, that leaves a sizeable white head.

Smell is very strong for a pale ale, that allows you to smell the hops as if it were even an IPA.

Tastes of a smooth floral taste that stays all the way down to the last drop. A very consistent flavor

Smooth beer that I can drink a few of with friends. If I am every balking at the store, I usually pick this one up. Always a great decision!

Draft into shaker, Clark St Ale House (Chicago).  I can¬ít believe I¬íve never rated this; it has been a staple since I started drinking good beer six years ago.  Hazy, pretty much opaque red-orange in the glass with a creamy beige head that reminds me of Newcastle (which is not good in my opinion, but oh well).  Leaves a thick, very sticky layer of striated lace up the side.  Smooth on the first sip, the head feathering the mouth and letting the medium-bodied beer fill the mouth with a crisp, low carbonation feel.  Malts really set this apart from other beers of the style, even though hops are a defining characteristic of APAs: sourdough bread with big, juicy, beefy tomatoes and grapefruit (maybe I should try that in a sandwich).  The finish is perfectly bitter, though somewhat metallic, hops goodness lingering on the tongue for full minutes (and a citric hop quality lingering underneath that for just as long).  Although it is maltier and just generally stronger than Sierra Nevada, I¬ím always reminded of that beer in the hoppy finish (quite an homage; a copyright lawyer would say this is a derivative work).  The smell belies the balanced nature of the beer, between the malts and the piney hops.  This beer is the troof, and is a session favorite of mine.  It has held up all these years.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2008 Had this at the incredible Landmark 1850 Inn at Milwaukee.  I liked the bar more than the beer.  The beer was a greet looking offering  with some exceptionally heavy lacing.  It started out with a strong bitterness to match it tart hoppiness.  As the beer warmed it brought more malt flavor out.  Were I a hophead this would have gotten a higher rating.

Enjoyed again at the Rotten Apple in Grafton and enjoyed it more than before.  A nice Pale Ale with grapefruit hop flavors and some nice balancing caramel malt.  An enjoyable classic offering.
poured cloudy golden amber. nice hoppy aroma. love the lemony hop taste. i could sit down and drink a lot of these. fantastic APA.

Bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours amber with a average size creamy and fizzy off-white head.  The head fades quickly leaving poor lacing.  The aroma is of citrusy hops.  The flavor is of light caramel and citrusy and piny hops.  The body is medium with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.  Overall this has to be my favorite APA to date.

Pours amber with a moderate head. Strong aroma of hops. The flavor is a complete hop assault with a pleasant body under it to carry it through.

Excellent American Pale Ale!

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>shigadeyo, thanks Craig!) Quite the hop monster...Pours hazy orange/amber with a tall biscuit head. Aroma is strong hops (grapefruit and pine) with some vanilla. Mouthfeel is medium-full, actually a little light but fine for the style. Big foamy broken rings of lacing. The flavor, as previewed by the aroma, is big citrusy hops - grapefuit, pine, even hints of orange. Some vanilla/bready maltiness pokes through a bit. Medium-strong bitterness prickles the tongue. About as hoppy as you¬íd get for this style, and a bit much for my taste so I can¬ít quite put this at the top of my APA list (but almost).

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2007 12 oz. bottle from Capones.   Pours a cloudy orange/light amber color with a one inch head.  Hops rushed the nose from the shaker as did notes of citrus, pine, flowers and spices.  Excellent mouthfeel and the flavor is well balanced with some malty tones in the back.  This is top of the line in my opninion, what a tremendous beer from FFF.

prolly the funnest thing i¬íve had. really spritely but not too much. i had two last night and only stopped there because i ran out. perfect for me in that sunshiney evening when i don¬ít want to think about anything but i still want to taste something interesting.

12 oz bottle at The Daily in Chicago.  Murky dark brown/orange with small tan head.  Nice caramel malt with "drink me up" orange hop aroma, very classic three floyds.  Flavor has a nice orangey/piney hop balance which nicely takes over and controls the rich caramel malt in a very good way.  Med to full body with med carb.  One of my personal favorite IPAs.

Bouteille 355ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur ambr√©e-cuivr√©e et voil√©e. Nez de houblon citrique (pamplemousse), r√©sineux et l√©g√®rement floral, malt√© de caramel l√©g√®rement r√¥ti, fruit√© (agrumes, p√™che et abricots) et avec des notes de pain. [bottle, from the darkmagus solo mission across earth] Beautiful clear amber color, with a nice rocky white head. Herbal, citrusy aroma, with some slight maltiness. Flavors are crisp hops, with more herbal citrus and fruit flavors. Excellent malt balance, with some breadiness evening things out. Finishes really dry, emphasizing the hops. An outstanding beer.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 Bottle.  Smells of citrus and honey essence.  Very hoppy but balanced nicely with the malts.  This is one you should let warm up a little so you can really taste the whole thing.  I can and will drink this again.  If you are in northwest Indiana/Chicago area you should visit the brewery.  It¬ís worth it.  My brother gets out of the Army this year and I am saving my 3F¬ís Dark Lord for that day.
Pours a hazy biege with tan head.  Flavor and Aroma is smooth.  Nice hops bitterness but balanced so well with the medium-body maltiness.  Just superb.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.  This beer poured a hazy, dark amber/copper color with a minimal tan head that faded slowly, leaving a bit of light lace.  The aroma is something to behold.  It consisted of grapefruit, peach, and roasted malt.  Just a beautiful, big citrus/floral hop experience.  The flavor is more of the same.  Nice hop bitterness, balanced out by the roasted malts and some citrus sweetness.  The beer has minimal carbonation with a medium to full-body.  It doesn¬ít get much better than this.  A must try from Three Floyds!

It is the first three floyd that we have had from this micro brewery, we will definetly try others and the restuarant.
Good job Three Floyds.

A beer really doesn¬ít look much better than this. A dark 
                  copper color with a large 2 inch creamy off white tannish 
                  head. Carbonation bubbles stick to the side of the glass and 
                  thick sticky lacing is left behind.

                  Rich complex aromas emanate from this beauty. Sweet piney 
                  malt, with a big citrusy fruit, with grapefruit and flowery 
                  hops.. A little of both worlds in this one. Thick malt, and 
                  hop smells make your nose want to stay buried in this one.

                  Very piney hops, with a clean carbonated spicey mouthfeel. 
                  Lush flower, resiny as hell, somewhat of a sweet malt finish, 
                  not as much citrus in the mouth as the nose but it is there. 
                  Very complex, very balanced, unbelievably drinkable.
12oz - Among the best of its style.  I finally happened upon it in Indy.  Cloudy copper, nice lace, bright citrus notes.  Good.
Gift from Stegosaurus. Amber\ coppery pour. A nice blast of hop aroma. Citrusy taste with hop and bitter notes. Well balanced. A + WORK !!!
12 oz bottle - nice pour with an off white head that stayed around nicely.  Good rich color and good taste throughout.

Very, very fine pale, this one. Robust and a bit bold, but very drinkable. Got a nice floral mellowness but - even with a bit more age than it should have - a citrus tang that gives you a gentle, crisp slap in the chops. Balanced and complex, one of the better ones out there.

Dark golden color with a rapidly dissipating white head.  Aroma of melon, pear, peach, citrus, and a bready maltiness.  Flavors were predominantly hoppy, with notes of citrus, pear, peach, and melon, but were very well balanced by the sweet malty base.  This is probably the most well-balanced pale ale I¬íve had.  Of course this is brewed with a significant amount of hops, but the sweet maltiness was never lost.  Really great, I¬ím glad I bought two six packs while visiting Three Floyd¬ís.
On tap at the brewpub. Golden and amber coloured. Very well balanced with notes of malt, hops, flowers, citrus, pines and a slight sweet bread hint.

This one is courtesy of LeopoldStoch. Brandon, you¬íre the man. Pours an orange copper with a moderate off-white head that clings to the glass a cm above the beer. The aroma is full of citrusy hops, most notably cascade hops. Like grapefruit juice. The flavour, whew! I don¬ít think there is a better pale ale out there. It is incredibly fresh tasting, with a palate that is suitable for the flavours present. There is pine, citrus, and i might detect some barley. This is nice intro to Three Floyds beers for me.

12oz bottle courtesy of Tish. Pours dark with thin tan head. The aroma is light with hints of sugar sweetness and pine hops. Nice flavor that hits up front with highly roasted crystal malts and pine hop bitterness. This is a tasty balance between hops and malts. I like the way a more citrus tone takes over about midway but the pine seems to remain.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2007 A nice bonus in trade from drewbeerme, thanks again. Plenty of carbonation, a nice dark golden color with a good pillowy white head. Great floral aroma of pine and orange peel. Smooth flavor, the hops punch is blended nicely with the malts, finishes crisp and refreshing. This brew was quite bitter, I almost thought I was drinking an IPA, which I like! Thanks again, drew.

12 oz. bottle from J.  An above average pale ale by my standards.  Heavily more flavorful, hoppy, and bitter than most.  Wouldn¬ít mind calling this my flagship beer at all...FFF knows what they¬íre doin.

definitely on the high end of the APA hop scale...borderline IPA, but im happy its in the APA category. pleasantly hoppy with a citrus and pine hop flavor, with a nice malt balance underneath. super smooth drinking...an everyday kinda beer

Pours an amber color with a white head that lasted til the last drop. Aroma of hops, citrus, and malt. Taste was much of the same. Well balanced with just enough hops to make me happy. Thanks Matt for the bottle.

12oz. Bottle
$7.99 6-Pack
Sam¬ís Downers Grove

This is a constant in my fridge. Looking around on BeerAdvocate today I noticed I never took the time to review it. Here it is. 

Alpha King poured a slightly chill hazed dirty copper. A 2 finger white creamy head formed on an aggressive pour. Very few, slowly rising carbonation bubbles rise to the head. Leaves some patchy lacing.

I love the smell of a fresh Alpha King. Big piney hops that make my eyes and mouth water along with a squeeze of orange juice. A solid caramel maltiness in the background, just enough so the hops don¬ít run wild.

This beer is considered a pale ale but drinks more along the lines of an IPA. Caramel maltiness starts things off and is quickly taken of by a strong pine needle mouth puckering hoppiness that lingers through till the finish. The finish is even a little more bitter as the caramel sweetness disappears. 

Body is on the lighter side of medium. Sluggish carbonation lets the brew work it¬ís way through at it¬ís own pace. Hop bitterness gives the tongue a beating.

This is an incredibly easy drinking beer. Every sip makes you want another. The lighter body makes it easy on the stomach.

The best pale ale I have yet come across. It helps that it¬ís more along the lines of an IPA. An absolute classic and one of my favorites.

3/28/07

Nice light amber color with little head.nice hoppy aroma slightly, sweet malt as well thrown in.Taste was very well hopped with some maltyness in it but definately well hopped it shows up through out the beer.the finish is hoppy as hell with a slightly watery hop finish that is mild but pleasant a very well done brew that is well worth the effort in getting.

bottle pours a mahogany haze with amber tendencies.  the head here is subtly dense, and ever-so-slowly receding.  the strong scents of thick hops are similar to that of a dense fog, and are accented by the flavorful citric aromas crossed with notes of creamy caramel slightly toasted malts.  tastes?  liquid perfection.  i can¬ít state it any better.  it coats the palate from the front, with bright and lively warrior hops and slight spice, to the back where the thicker mouthfeel really shines and is accented by the mild, but non-offensive bitterness and slight salt flavor.  this is great.  all kinds of complexity here.  it¬ís just sad that there¬ís only 12 oz, and i can¬ít get it here.

Pours a deep amber color with an orange tint to it.  Creamy looking off-white head hangs around long enough to create lacing in my glass.  Bold and unique aroma: citrusy and floral, without smelling like a "girly beer."
Well balanced flavor that¬ís just as bold and unique as it¬ís nose.  Terrific beer!

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2008 Pours a rather barleywine-esque orangey brown with a dissipating offwhite head.  Aroma is very nice with plenty of grapefruit, citrus and flowers swirling around with some brown sugar and light caramel background.  Taste is pretty much like that as well.  Some light brown sugar, bread and caramel for the malt taste, but there¬ís tons of hop flavor and it¬ís very floral and grapefruity.  Finish has some butterscotch and earthy hop flavor, but not much actual bitterness.  This is incredibly good!  This is a creamy medium bodied (full for the style) very smooth beer.  Slightly sticky, but whatever.  Thanks to Peter for this bottle.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2007 Bottle.  Pours clear, dark copper with a creamy beige head and thick lacing.  Nose is pine and citrus hops.  Tastes nice and hoppy with lots of caramel malt to balance things out.  Medium body, goes down very smooth.  Finish is somewhat dry with a nice bitter end.  The most complete and satisfying APA, in my opinion!

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2007 This beer is phenomenal! It has such a unique taste that is literally synonymous with Three Floyds! I¬ím lucky enough to live within 20 miles of their brewery, and their $5 tour never gets old...especially for their seasonal stuff!  Overall, come on...its Three Floyds...and you get quality and consistency with their flagship beer, a strong APA, which is like a traditional American India Pale Ale
Bottle.  Aroma is sweet with some noticeable hops.  Good flavor of hops and malts with a great citrus tone.  A very well done IPA.

Simply a perfect beer here. The beer has so much hops, and such a unique taste to it that it truly does make the hoppyness apear to be floral. I wanted to save a rainforest when I first tried this beer because it was so life changing, but then I had a six pack and ran into a tree, so, I gave it a 19 overall instead of a 20. (Completely joking here of course).
You have to try this beer if you can get a hold of it, I no longer can.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2007 On tap at 3F prewpub.  A great, fresh tasting beer when tried on tap.  Like the Dreadnaught, I think this one loses a little hoppiness when out of a bottle or when it¬ís not super fresh.  Hoppier than Bells Two Hearted, but maybe not quite as pleasant tasting.  A great beer though!

My favorite IPA right here.  Whats not to like about this beer?  Fantastic looking in the glass.  Cloudy with a nice head.  Scent is amazingly strong with floral and citrus notes.  It tastes like no other.  Heavy in the mouth and a heavier hop flavor that lingers long after you swallow.

This is a fantastic looking beer.  I love the dense orangish-brown color.  Minimal lacing off of the pour which consisted of a almost nonexistent white head.  Hints of caramel, some piney hops and sweet malt.  Very easy drinking brew, slightly sweet beginning and mild hoppy finish.  Good beer.

Born on date- who the hell knows? Pours out a cloudy copper with minimal head - some soapy lacing. Smell is nothing to write home about- some fading hops. Taste- quite spritzy which surprised me given the lack of head. Grassy hops with a soapy aftertaste. Malt is solid- tobacco and solid caramel flavours. Its quite tasty, but doesn¬ít blow me away. Maybe its the age- I can¬ít imagine I have a bottle at its peak of freshness. First time trying, so I risked the purchase in my excitement not knowing its age. The hops are there, just in weird muted kind of way. given the rep of FFF, I was expecting more. Truthfully, pass the SNPA, as this pale ale doesn¬ít match the benchmark classic american pale that is Sierra Nevada. I would love a chance to try fresh on tap or bottle. Until they date these suckers, I can¬ít cut any slack.
UPDATED: NOV 10, 2007 My wife says it taste like perfume. I kind of agree, but I crave it anyways. It¬ís like no other. Love the late hops!

Bottle, May 07. Nice amber-orange color with some chill haze and effervescent carbonatation. Bubbly, creamy white head. Deep, intense, piney, resinous citric hoppy nose. Some mineral, earthy, humid aroma. Deep, citric, piney and slightly spicy flavor, layered with some crystal malt ending. Medium MF, hoppy and a nice, filling mineral ending. Ends just perfect balanced between crystal malts and dryness. Inmensely quaffable. Enjoyable, moreish big APA.

Picked up a bottle from the Coffee Grounds in Eau Claire, WI. Pours a cloudy burnt orange color brew with a good white head and decent lacing. Aroma of citrus and floral hops, lychee, grapefruit, and some tropical fruit. Taste is slightly carbonated, tangy, smooth and enough bitterness on the finish. A very well done IPA.
Thanks to skyview for sharing.  Nice hoppy nose with floral hints.  Gold color with creamy off white head.  Floral hops with hints of citrus in the body.

This is a very good pale ale.  It pours a nice hazy amber color with a thin white head.  The most impressifve thing about the beer though is the intense and worderful hop aroma.  Citrus hops predominate and it is done well.  In the flavor it is well balanced with a nice malt backbone with this intensely but nice hop beer.
Bottle.  Pours hazy amber, medium, fluffy white head.  Nice hop aroma, pine and citrus.  Taste is more hops with some caramel malt.  Good bitterness.  This is one of my all time favs.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2007 Bottle. Poured a nice amber. Aroma was very inviting, nice citrus and pine notes. Flavor is slight hoppy, again nice citrus and pine flavors, very subtle, not over the top. Will be having this one again.

My best tasting to date. Fiery copper in color with a moderate off white head. Nose on this one is perfect. Orange rind, fresh grapefruit, spring florals and multiple layers of piney hops. Full and complete. However, while the beer was crisp and refreshing, it was missing some oomph. I expect a tad more carbonation would complete this, make it perfect. At least in my opinion.

Bottle.  Ahh! The menacing Alpha King rides again!!  Now, there¬ís 12 

ounces of hoppy goodness if I ever saw it.  Pours a nice amber color, 

perhaps a shade lighter than iced tea.  Pour is hazy, owing to the fact 

that this is a bottle conditioned ale.  Makes a nice, fat, foamy head 

with moderate lacing.  Kind of looks like an egg fried in an overly hot 

skillet.  Once the head has calmed down a little, and when viewed in the 

right light, the remaining trace of head appears almost to have a green 

tinge to it.  Could it be that the boys at Three Floyds crammed so much 

hops into this recipe that the head actually takes on a green hue?  

Nah...must just be a trick of the light.  It is very hoppy, though, which 

characteristic lends itself to the long finish.  The hop bitterness 

dances on the tongue for a good 2 or 3 minutes after you take a quaff.  

This glass is not lasting long enough to warm very much, but I think 

warming a little releases the floral aroma of the hops.  That is what one 

smells when one sticks one¬ís proboscis in the glass: hop flowers and 

alcohol.  It shares that quality with its cousin, Gumballhead.  My nephew 

put his nostril down to the neck of a freshly cracked bomber of 

Gumballhead, and the first thing he said was, "It smells like incense."  

If one sniffs hard enough while simultaneously searching the olfactory 

memory banks, the same can be said for this ale, though that quality is 

not as profound as it is with Gumballhead.  One can taste the quality, 

the care, the love that went into brewing this beer.  Overall, a smooth, 

superbly crafted and very drinkable Amerian Pale Ale.
Nice and hoppy.  Isn¬ít that an insightful comment.  Sweet, with strong citrus and great hoppy finish.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish amber. Quite a nose! Very expressive with notes of hops, fruit, pine, malt... Same for the palate. Quite flavorsome for a pale ale. Who needs 2IPA¬ís when there is Alpha king?

UPDATED: APR 24, 2007 the most delicious, sumptuous and precisely balanced micro-brewed pale ale i¬íve ever tasted...heavy aroma of fresh centennial hops, citrus, cereal and sweet caramel with a thick, full-bodied, almost toffee-like taste bursting with gushing flavors of citrus rind(open a bottle and i reminisce on Trix and Fruitloops)...bitterness lingers, but is balanced with a preternatural grain bill to match(Very sweet upfront)...excellent head retention and lacing...¬íTHE¬í American pale ale, a force to be reckoned with in the realm of the beer geekery...there is no equal in my experience...

12 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy amber-red color with a minimal white head.  Smells of hops (!) and citrus... It¬ís been a long time since I¬íve had a nice hoppy beer so excuse me if I overrate this one... it smells fantastic.  Tastes like hops and sweet citrus... yum.  Wonderfully refreshing.

(Bottle) Pours a dark amber color with a nice head. Moderate aroma of hops. Great lacing. The hops are very evident in the flavor of the brew as well. A lot of citrus flavor, but that is generally well balanced by the amount of sweet malt that is in here. A really good beer overall.

Incredible hop aroma; loud yet subdued enough not to induce whiplash. Nose hairs intact. Nice citrus and malt balance. Truely complex flavor for a pale ale. Great malt background and the hops are perfectly balanced. Nice citrus flavors in there as well. Just an incredible beer that could easily become an everyday staple. Too bad I¬ím in NC.
Bottles in chicago area.  Excellent hoppy balance...refreshing pale ale.  Best casual drinking beer from the 3Floyd¬ís Fleet.

poured into a tulip.  Being in NC you cannot get three floyds, but I got my hands on this.  pours a cloudy copper amber with nice full head, aroma is fresh, smooth, sweet hops that tingles my nose and is mouth watering.... Taste is of the sweet fresh hops on the front with a mild bitterness on the finish, and a very crisp aftertaste... citrus is throughout in a mellow tone and gets pronounced behind the bitter finish....
great brew, complex? yes.... mouthwatering after every sip, I want more.....

Draft in Chicago.  Pours a deep orange with a modest head.  The nose is full.  A perfrct blend of sweet than bitter on first taste.  Left a little lace on the glass and a pleasant taste in my mouth.  Compare to the N.C brewery Red Seal.

Some Americans traded this with the Amsterdam beershop ¬íThe Cracked Kettle¬í for some local brews -  I, customer, was lucky enough to notice it sitting on the sparsely populated American-beer-shelf and immediately payed the sum of money that the clerk asked for it, which was about the equivalent of the cost of a small 2nd hand Dutch car. Hazy & dark orange/amber with a decent head and good lacing. Aroma of a broad range of floral citrus hops, reminding of roses, grapefruit and the resin of pine trees.. Strong taste with complex hoppiness, and some sweet malt providing a backbone of toffee and caramel. Not so bitter at all, the bitterness is rather just a component of the complex multilayered taste, instead of the main element like in some more one-dimensional full-on tonguescorcher brews. Long & sticky finish that slowly dried out, leaving a great piney hopbitterness. Mouthfeel is full-bodied yet light, with medium/low carbonation & combined with the dry finish I could drink liters of this. This was very balanced and rounded, a great brew.

Served in a Duvel glass.  Clear, bright red with dense 1-finger white head, which is both sustaining and able to leave a nice lace.  Aroma and flavor are intensly hoppy.  Mouthfeel is surprisingly rich.  Finish is long and bitter.  Holds true to its name.

YOU PAY FOR WHAT YOU GET. AND WITH THIS ONE YOU GET A LOT. CITRUSY, THE VERY BEST MALT BACKROUND AND A REAL AMERICAN IPA POWER PUNCH. NOT OVERWHELMING JUST SUBSTANTIAL. GOOD BODY FOR ANY TIME OF YEAR. NOW THATS HARD TO DO! ENJOY!
Hoppy, good head-lacing...nice lasting finish.  Three floyds can¬ít go wrong!

Bottle thanks to pantanap!  Quite hazy medium brown color, off white head that dissipates quickly.  Earthy pine and citrus hop aroma but a good amount of malts peek through.  Tastes IPA-ish but I think it¬ís classified correctly -- too much malt.  Very clean finish, extremely well balanced, very enjoyable.

12oz from Matt at Capone¬ís. Pours a very hazey dark amber color. The scent is a delicate mix of pines and citrus. You can tell the hops are going to hit you hard and all the way through from the second it hits your tongue. The thing most alarming is an incredibly non-bitter after taste. The citrus is also accompanied by a lighter fruit flavor toward the end. Maybe melon. This beer may become one of my new favorties.
Alpha King calls itself an APA, but it¬ís an IPA IMO.  It¬ís a huge hop monster with big bitters and some nice citrus.  I like it, but it¬ís a little over the top.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2007 12 oz from Ty5592. Believe the hype on this one. Great flavor and seriously agressive hopping. A lot of IPA¬ís claim that, but in this case, its true. White head that quickly disapates, hop aroma not in your face, which is nice because the bitterness comes as quite a nice surprise. Dark amber brown color, darker than most ipas..Flavor more akin to an imperial than a regular pale ale. This is a great beer, not found around Buffalo. Thanks Ty.

12oz bottle.  Pours a nice bright ruby red with a small white head.  Strong aroma of hops - ctirusy, some pine, resin, grapefruit.  Very sweet.  Beatiful smell.  Flavor is a wonderful balance between sweetness and bitterness, boldness and drinkability.  Pretty strong for an APA, tastes more like an IPA to me.  A very impressive beer.

Draft.  Dark orange color.  Aroma of citrus hops.  To me, this doesn¬ít taste like a pale ale, but a much maltier hoppy beer (like the oaked AB from stone).  The flavor was intense, and too intense for a pale ale.

On tap; color was a somewhat murky orange.  White head.  Aroma mainly of citrus/grapefruit.  Flavor reminded me of some oaked arrogant bastard elements; a nice strong hoppy flavor.  One of the best, if not the best American Pale Ales i have had.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2007 Bottle.  Nice hazy orange color with a soapy white head.  Citrus and hop character in the aroma, not hugely complex but very well balanced.  Flavor is similar to the aroma but the finish is a little bland for me.  Nice on the palate.  Definitely above average, but not hugely remarkable.  Seems like a good session beer to me.  P.S. I had a wicked cold when I rated this beer, might be why I under-rated this beer, or maybe not.
Strong aroma of citrus hops.  Copper color with white head.  Strong hoppy flavor with very clean finish.  Words really do not give this justice.  The best APA I have had.
fresh hop taste, full flavor but smooth. excellent if you like american ipa¬ís

[191-20070120] 355mL. Hoppy citrus grapefruit aroma with surprising sweet navel orange characteristics. Cloudy, brown amber body with swirly floaties left in bottle and a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Initial bitter hoppy flavour, lemony and grapefruit, nice aftertaste. Medium body, fairly complex and bitter palate. Nice togetherness.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2008 12oz bottle...poured a muddled dark orange with a white head...aroma was of a citrusy grapefruit with a decent amount of pine....taste was bitter throughout and basically resembled the aroma in nature.  it sweetened up a bit revealing more malts but it was consistently biiter tasting...not a bad brew by any means but i prefer a little more balance between the hop and malt profile.

multiple pints at Chicago Ale House on 08/30/2008..... not as bitterly astringent as when i had it out of the bottle.  piney hops present but were held in check but it all was just completely smooth and drinkable.  good balance with the malt...... 8/4/8/5/15

a  bottle or thrEE...Cloudy orange appereance. Wonderful hoppy and fruity citrus aroma. Flavor has mild malts and fruits followed by an overwhelming hoppy bitter and acidic (grapes?) finish. LoVe all Three Floyds!!!!

Pours hazy amber color with lacy white head. Smells citrusy with hops present. Pale ales aren¬ít my favorite but this is decent with floral hops and very piney aftertaste. Refreshing but not my favorite.

bottle: pours coppery orange with hardly no head. aroma is all hops very citrusy and earthy. very piney and earthy flavour with some malt behind it. very long lingering bitter finish. kind of drying also on the finish. very good pale ale.

Bottle:  Pure copper pour with a medium white, bubbly head.  Nose is a simple blend of citrus and floral hops, some malt and caramel.  Taste is floral hop base with some malty sweetness, hints of caramel, grapefruit, and pine.  Goes down wet!  Lingering hops bitter trailer.  Thanks LLafoe for sending this.

Thanks to Illinismitty for the 12ozer. An excellent aroma of piney hops. A slightly hazed amber ornage pour with a sticky lacing. A malty sweetness that rolls to a vry pleasant piney bitter that progressively covers your entire tongue A strong palate that is full without being thick . Just a tad on the fizzy side keeps it from being a 5. If you likd a balanced beer that eventually tios to the hop bitter this beer is for you.
Pours a hazy orange color with a white head. Aroma is very grassy, citrus hop aroma.  Flavor is grassy bitter hops.

Poured from bottle. Very cloudy copper color. Cloudiness came from my improper decanting technique according to my husband! :) HAH! Smelled sweet and citrusy. Taste of sweet citrus, lots of hops, some pine...This was prety hoppy for an American Pale Ale, I thought, more along the lines of an IPA, really. But a good brew none the less!
Aroma is slightly hoppy, nice malt, and sweet. The presence of pine is very present in the aroma and very noticeable in the flavor.  Very Good, medium bodied, slower finish.

Copper colored pour with little or no head.  Nose is malty with a fair amount of spicey/piney hops coming through.  Light bodoed and actively carbonated.  Nice citrusy hop flavor and a wonderful  hoppy bitterness in the finish.

Deep amber red color, thick beige head. Grapefruit and pine hops in the nose. Taste is sprucey piney hops all the way. Clean palate. Really sessionable and goes well with anything. I personally like this even more after about six months to let the pale malts come out as the hops mellow out. Lovely APA.

Bottle, pours a cloudy orange rust color with a slight head.  Floral hops aroma with orange peel, a hint of grapefruit and some pine.  Thicker mouthfeel with a nice hoppy taste that is very pleasing and unique, with a clean bitter finish.  Highly recommended.
12 oz bottle.  Pours an orangish brown with a half-finger off-white head.  Aroma is of hops, citrus and pine.  Taste is sweet with a carbonated bitter pine citrus finish.  Very nice.
33 cl bottle, Fargo, (picked up on move from Toronto). Amber orange colour, intense floral hoppy aroma. Thick in the mouth, good level of bitterness, sweet aftertaste, very nice.

Poured into my Dogfish Head pint glass.
Pours a very dark amber brown color. It has a frothy head that quickly recedes and leaves lots of nice lacing on the side of the glass.
Smell is very piny hops with some grassy undertones.
Taste is much the same, except with a good amount of hop bitterness to it. Mouthfeel is crisp with a good amount of bitterness. This has a decent about to maltiness and pretty full mouthfeel.
This is a highly sessionable beer which doesn¬ít get old after drinking a few.

I¬ím a craft beer noob, but I¬íve tried quite a few in a short time.  Some I actually poured down the sink after a smell and a taste because they are sad pretenders to Alpha King Pale Ale.  This beer pours a very attractive light nutty orange, with just enough sediment to give it a slight haze which I prefer (I also like Bell¬ís Two Hearted Ale, which is not fully filtered).  The nose on this beer is not to be neglected, it¬ís floral, citrus, piney, hoppy -- a treat.  This is not a thin clear pretender after thought of a beer, this is the real deal.  Thin head if poured correctly, but who cares?  The taste of this beer is smooth and creamy.  Mouthfeel is slightly thick, and lightly carbonated, bitter clean hoppy aftertaste.  The perfect setup for another sip, then another...I like to let the beer warm up closer to room temperature, which really brings out the taste, nose, and complexity of flavors.  Three Floyd¬ís Alpha King has become one of my favorite things.

Great brew all around. The mix of bitterness and citrus blend together here for an unexpected treat of a good beer. You can tell hops are present but seemingly no aroma of them and strangely not overpowering in flavor either which is good meaning that for me it¬ís balanced well.

A great beer. Very hoppy, very sustained flavor well after drinking. The citrus and bitterness of this beer will not soon be forgotten. Letting sit for 2 or 3 minutes after pouring from bottle to pint glass (if you can muster it!) and allowing a bit of room temp to settle in does this beer even better; giving it an even more intense flavor. I will have this in my fridge for years to come. Thanks for reading.

12 oz bottle via WBC.  Pours pale amber with with a thin, but firm white tan head.  The aroma is nice and fragrant, and very nicely hopped.  The taste is nice, a good balance of hops and malt with a good kick in the end.  This is a good brew, and while it is hoppy I don¬ít agree with incutrav, I think its a pale ale, its just a hoppy one.  Nice brew 3F thanks for the brew Brennan.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 Pretty good stuff here, sought this out as it is the top rated APA in the world I guess. I think the reason this is rated so high is because this is esentially an IPA brew from any other company. People see that it is classifed as an APA, and think, holy hell, hops and flavor explosion! Even if it was classified as an IPA, like it should, it would still be a very good example, but wouldnt be a top contender certinaly. What I hear about Dreadnaught is that thats VERY hoppy, so this is probably more of an APA for 3F¬ís. anyWHO,it is tasty, hoppy, citrusy good, I rated it high no matteer how its classfied, very nice brew.

Bottle from Ogglethorp. Thanks Brian. Pours a hazy orange/amber with small white head. Strong citrusy hop aroma--
reminds me the most of its uncle dread. Flavor is also very heavily hopped--grapefruit stands out, no surprise.  Caramel malts appear on the palate to balance out the strong hop presence. Basically a lighter version of the dreadnaught. A well done APA.

Bottle from Sprinkle. The best APA in the world? Let¬ís find out. Nice deep amber color upon pouring. Sweet citric hoppy aroma with a bit of grapefruit. Very nice hoppy APA. Most brewers would call this their IPA I¬ím sure. Very nice.

Heard a lot about this one. I was hoping it wasnt like the movie everyone says is great and then it sucks NG Schlong. Not this one. THis one, IMO, surpassed them. Im a hop head anyway so this was right up my alley. A solid all around brew. Great flavor, freaking smooth finish. NICE!

Pours a slightly hazed light copper with an inch of textured cream colored foam. Good spidery lacing. Excellent citrus hops in the aroma - they smell fresh picked.

Brief caramel malt in the first sip, then the hops take over. Tons of grapefruit and orange, with a little bit of pine tossed in for good measure. The caramel reappears in the finish with just a touch of light sweet licorice. More citrus hops (this time lemony) linger into the aftertste. Great carbonation - I love the carbonation + hops combination. This one has a burning sensation when held on the tongue.

Very citrusy, very hoppy.  Nut brown pour from a dimly lit room (I imagine a nicer orange if I bothered to flip the switch?).  In the most platonic of connotations -- explodes into the palate with wonderful flavor.  Delivers hints from the freshest of groves.  Wonderfully bitter finish.  A brilliant effort from the backyard here in Indiana.

Light nut brown in color with medium diminishing head and little lacing. Strong grapefruit aroma. Extreme flavor, full of hops, grapefruit and malt. A tad bitter, but certainly not overwhelming. Leaves the mouth with a nice light grapefruit taste.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2007 Hazy orange/copper with a large head. Good lacing. Aroma of citrus, pine and oily resin hops with some caramel. Taste is very citrusy, but there is a well meaning sweetness of caramel. Any sweetness is subdued by the oily, fresh hops in this one.  Oily texture. Light to medium body. Bitter finish. What more can a hophead ask?

Honestly, this beer disappeared so quickly I¬ím not sure I can even review it, but let¬ís see what I remember.

A: poured beautifully, a delicious-looking copperish orange color, a nice 2-finger head and instant lacing. I can tell right away it¬ís going to be stellar, especially when I stick my nose down to get the...

S: ...wonderful aroma emanating from this brew. It¬ís all very subtle, yet enticing at once. Some floral aroma, a nice pink grapefruit and certainly some piney smells.

T: Wow. Just, wow. Seriously, this beer disappeared so quickly, the flavors are just complex enough, and just subtle enough that it¬ís damned near chuggable. There is without a doubt a gorgeous piney overtone to the beer (from the Centennial hops?) as well as some wonderful malted undertones. Utterly delicious. I could drink this all night.

M: Again, just nothing at all wrong with this beer. It feels "right" in your mouth and bigger than usual gulps are real easy, too easy in fact.

D: As I just mentioned, this is an all day, all night beer. One of the most drinkable I¬íve yet encountered. Even my burps taste good.

Highly recommended.

Pours a nice cloudy arangish amber color with a decent head.  It has a nice mild almost English stylehop presence to it, with a nice citrus accent.  the flavor is wonderfully balanced with a nice citrus hop bite balanced beautifully by a slight malt backbone.  A very nice PA with a great lingering finish.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Pours a hazy orange red.  Quickly diminishing head.  Very nice mellow hops, and citrus smell.  Taste is pretty mellow, but a wonderful little hoppiness to it that makes it seem more like a lighter IPA.  Bitterness is pretty defined in the finish and and nice grapefruit as well.  I can see why this one is rated so highly.  This one was courtesy SoLan, and yes he is gangster.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2011 Orange-amber with big, foamy off-white head /  Elegant and complex pine, citrus, and bubblegum nose / Medium body, great fruit and balance, with long, moderately bitter finish / Flavors of bubblegum, fresh cut pine, grapefruit, orange, and resin /  A gold standard.

12oz bottle, courtesy of drewbeerme.  Thanks, Andrew!  Pours a cloudy orangish-rust color; fluffy, light-tan head with great retention and lacing.  Pleasant citrus hops and earthy malt character in the aroma.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: lots of chewy citrus, well-balanced by a maple syrupy malt backbone; average carbonation; very drinkable while still having plenty to it.  Medium finish, showing a balance of dry citrus and floral hops and brown sugar.

Bottle Pours a deep clear amber with a small off white head.  Minimal lacing. Nice balance of rich malts and hops in the aroma.  Flavor is a very big sweet malt and piney hop duel.  Big all around and a long lingering hop bite. A smooth heavy feel. A serious pale ale !
Thanks BuckeyeBoy for sharing this one.
12oz bottle Pours out a orange with some red. Topped with a off white head. Great hop on the nose and tast as well. I would call this a great IPA. Very hoppy. Thanks Buckybeer for this great one.

Bottle: Clear reddish brown color with no head.  It has a nice hoppy aroma followed by it in a similar taste.  The flavor has a strong hop presence but is still pretty well balanced.  It has a crisp finish and a sturdy aftertaste.  This pretty much kicks around every other pale ale I have ever had.  Thanks BuckeyeBoy for sharing this trade gem!

Poured to a hazy reddish-orange with thin off-white hhead that lingered well and left good lacing along the glass. Nice strong aroma of grapefruit citrus, with a hint of grassy  hops. Taste followed along the citrus vein. A tangy mouthfeel led to a dry bitter finish, much more like an IPA than an APA. A most enjoyable beer!!

A golden orange pour with a very faint head.  Citris and hops dominate the aroma.  Crisp, clean and full in the mouth.  The flavor was sharp - hops cut across the top with a sour grapefruit tinge that crept its way inside.  Obtained from John¬ís in Iowa City.  I enjoyed this sixer.
Citrusy, and hoppy, but not really as much as I like a IPA to be. Malts make for a great full mouthfeel. Overall a good example of an IPA. Recommended.

Massive citrus hop along with undying grapefruit aroma. I have to say I was a bit disappointed, as it had fallen well short of my vast expectations. In my opinion it is a classic example representing the many American micros, crazed over possessing deep & dense flavor profiles however forgetting the fine art of balance that truly makes a great beer. Take a page from the Belgians I¬íll have you.

Dark amber to copper red and a little foggy; nice off white head. The aroma, oh baby the  aroma is to die for! Hops, spice, citrus; all are apparant upon nasal inspection. Slick mouthfeel, perfect carbonation, big hoppy flavor and delightful citrus! THIS is why I love PA¬ís! I continue to be impressed with 3F and am blown away by Alpha King. Easily the best beer experience I¬íve had since sampling Hey_Kevin¬ís homebrew Saison!

from Sam¬ís in Lincoln Park. IMHO, this is one of the best pale ales out there. Golden/copper color, persistent head, perfect carbonation, great crisp unmuddled flavors of grapefruit and resin, balancing and equally present maltiness. One of my favorites indeed.
Good sweet hops, fruity finish, looking forward to try other beers from 3 floyds, also would like to try it on tap

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2014 you can drink this every day, at which point, every day, you will be reminded that life is indeed good. At least if you¬íve got a plump stock of this stuff. If not? Sorry, buddy.

From RB definition of a Pale Ale:
"...American Pale Ales are light in color, ranging from golden to a light copper color. The style of this beer is defined by the American hops used. American hops typically have high bitterness and aroma.

This beer nails it. Crisp grapefruit tartness and smoothness are outstanding. Very floral aroma and balanced pallet make this beer the best Pale Ale I¬íve had (yet...)

Copper red. Extra fine beige head settles quickly to an incomplete cap.

Resiny, citric hops lead the nose. Caramelly, bready malt lies underneath providing more than ample support. Excellent balance, and complexity. Very nice indeed.

Even better in the mouth, where a medium body conveys that magic FFF juicy hop flavor. Again, there is excellent balance between the big maltiness and even bigger hop load. Finishes with a long, lingering hop bitterness. Major league.

Mild, extremely fine carbonation from the bottle conditioning gives a lush mouthfeel. Liquid velvet. Perilously drinkable. Amazingly this is probably my third favorite of the regular FFF line-up, but that speaks to the quality of Pride & Joy and Robert the Bruce rather than to any problems with this beer. Top notch stuff.

On Tap at The Firkin & Fox in Glen Ellyn, IL. The finest APA I¬íve ever had. Pours a copper orange with white head. Huge citrussy and floral hops balanced with nice, long lasting sweet maltiness. I¬ím spoiled that I get to drink this almost daily.
Pours an orange body with a small white head. Very piney hop aroma. Lots of citrus in the aroma that¬ís echoed by grapefruit when it hits the tongue. Sweet, balanced, excellent APA.

I am origanally from NW Indiana & I am so proud that my heritage, "The Region" is making such great beer!  Pours a beautiful orange.  Aroama is very citrus with some pine.  Taste is bitter, but very consistent and stable.  You must love hops to enjoys this beer.  A lot of carbonation.  This is a very memorable beer!  You will want more of it!

Beer heaven for the hop lover...there is a reason this is #1! Purchased at Vintage Estates in Ohio (made the hour drive there almost exclusively for this beer). The pour was a perfect burnt red/brown. The taste was all floral hops that allow the malt to mingle and stick around afterwards. I can¬ít say enough about this great beer and can¬ít imagine another APA coming close to this.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: What a great pale!  The aroma is superb, strong and pleasant at the same time.  I loved the hoppiness and the offsetting slightly sweet taste.  Peppery on the tongue.  It has a great kick.  I wish I could get this at my local liquor store.  Two-Hearted Ale and Hop-Rod Rye are the only other brews that I would put in this category.
Smells great. Taste is very nice. Lots of hps; this is really good. almost has some scottish graininess to it. An excellent excellent beer.

One great Pale Ale.  This one rates up there with Burning River Pale Ale from Great Lakes.  Pours a clear, dark amber with an aroma bursting of fresh hops.  This Pale is dominated with my favorite piney, Cascade hops.  A very drinkable and tasty beer.
The best pale ale out there. 12oz bottle @ Coles. Buffalo, NY Orangish-red color with heavy hop aroma. Well balanced & should be the standard on which all american pales are based on.

Bottle.  Pours an orange with a reddish hugh, thin beige head.  Notes is floral and some citrus.  Medium mouthfeel, hoppy taste.  Some spice, little metallic.  Must say i was hopin more out of this, maybe because of the FFF big hitters, but this could be a nice session brew.

12 oz bottle from Holdenn via trade.(Thanks!)  This stuff smells awesome with a floral hop aroma that rivals Stone PA.  Pine trees, hops, and citrus dominate the aroma.   It pours an deep dark amber color with a medium sized white head.  Taste is big on hops again and very complex!  Somewhat sweet, nicely contrasting bitterness to it too, and an overall citrus flavor through out the beer.  Palate is lively, and very easy drinking.  Overall, This is a wonderful American Pale Ale with a very complex aroma and taste.  Great stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 Amber body, with an off-white head. Some foam clinging to the sides of the glass. Mostly hop aroma, but there¬ís some malt there, too. Semi-sweet malts, and hops, are nicely balanced throughout the flavor experience. Wonderfully bitter hop finish. Nice carbonation, and very smooth. This is a quality beer, and certainly worth the investment.
Nice bronze color, bitter-sweet aroma and very easy taste... Finish is outstanding and can¬ít notice the alcohol

12 oz bottle.  A nice trade item I scored recently.  A very easy drinking Pale Ale that tastes like a very easy drinking IPA.  Excellent balance all around, which is something I¬íve noticed that 3F really doesn¬ít do a great job at.  But, at last, I¬íve found an outstanding ale that I¬íd drink many times over.  Probably in the course of an evening.  At home, so I don¬ít hurt anyone.  But I might hurt myself.

I cant believe it took me so long to rate this one! Pours a orange amber color with a nice white head.Awesome hop and malt aroma to it..Wonderful hop flavor with just the right amount of malt backing.Great bitter finish too!This stuff is great!

Bottle ¬ñ thanks shigadeyo! Pours a hazy amber with a massive white head. Aromas of nuts, fruit, grapefruit. Creamy, smooth medium body. Biscuity malts amid hoppy flavors. Nice hop bitterness at the end. Overrated? Probably, but still not bad at all!

This beer pours very dark for a pale ale...is a dark amber that is more reminiscent of a barley wine.  The head appears a bit soapy, with large uneven bubbles, particularly a moment after pouring.

Smell is less like familiar hop bitterness than it is like pure citrus-ness.  Given the very dark appearance of this beer, the smell is much lighter than I would¬íve guessed.  

The taste is extremely good.  Full and sweet up front, with citrus note throughout the finish.  This beer is very apparently bitter, but not in an intimidating or challenging way.

Like Gumballhead, mouthfeel is light and pleasant for such a big beer.  This beer is not at all "sticky" the way many big IPAs/APAs are today.

I could drink a few of these...I should say, I would really enjoy having a few of these.

Bottle.   Pours a slightly hazy copper color, with a huge white head, beautiful lacing.   Aroma is pine, grapefruit, floral hops.   Flavor is much the same pine, grapefruit, floral hops, some caramel, grass.   Palate is medium, medium carbonation, wonderful resionous, bitter finnish.   Freakin great!

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2007 12oz bottle fresh from the brewery. aroma is freakin bliss, PNW hops, grapfruit, pine needles, one of the best aromas i¬íve experienced. color is amber nice head. flavor is very hoppy and bitter for the style, PNW hops, caramel, and toasted cookie. very refreshing........................................ - 5/2/07, 12oz bottle fresh from the brewery. this nose 9 worthy, reduced to 8. similar flavor profile but this seems sweeter than I recall, like they brew it with sugar. perhaps they do. nevertheless, this is really tasty. 8/4/8/5/16.
Nice amber color, a bit cloudy, slight tan head.  Very flowery and hoppy aroma.  Crisp hoppy flavor, a bit citrusy.  This is one of my favorite IPA¬ís.

Pours dark amber with a tan head. Aroma is hoppy and clean, actually this is hoppier than I thought it would be smell like I¬ím getting ready for an IIPA or hopped up barleywine. Taste is hoppy, with citrus and grass. Kinda oily, slick, thicker mouthfeel I get from every FFF beer I¬íve had so far. Awesome beer and even more impresive that a beer this good is thier "flagship" beer and is thier most common. Cheer to the guys a Three Floyds.
aroma is floral citrus with biscuit malt underneath.  Sweet citrus and biscuit in flavor.  moderate bitter finish.  very nice apa

Bottle from Chicones.  Pours murky orange, the color of a clementine.  Fragrant floral meadows and grapefruits, perfumes in the aroma.  Peppery flavor with a cucumberish taste and flower petals.  I wish I had a spicy, vegetabley gyro right now.  Seems to fall from a different branch of Two Hearted Ale¬ís apple tree...and I certainly have no complaints about that.

Bottled sample via my friend Trevor. Medium amber in colour with a bit of haze. Slightly below average carbonation for the style. Dominant pine needle aroma, with some background notes of sweet citrus, both sweet and toasted malts, and even a bit of yeastiness. In the mouth, there is more pine, but more reminiscent of the wood itself as opposed to the fragrant needles. The citrus notes become more distinctive and remind me of tangerine, mandarin orange, and grapefruit. The hop flavors are substantial, but their sharpness is blunted by the equally assertive malt presence. The bitterness is about on par with the style, which is somewhat of a disappointment considering the name of the beer. Overall, this is a very well executed beer, but not the mind blowing, mouth-puckering experience I was hoping for. Something a little dryer and a little more bitter with the same amount of complexity would have garnered a higher rating from me.

12-oz., courtesy the fine hospitality of BitBucket. Thick cloudy medium brown pour, under an impressively rocky and dense head (for an APA).  Big sweet bread and yeast nose, with some vanilla-ish notes in there. Subdued attack: medium body, low-medium carb, mild flavors. The flavors come forward in a big way on the mid palate though: biscuit, warm toast, herbal hop, especially at the finish. The sweet and mild breadiness persist as well. Nice stuff but hard to see it having quite the average score it does...FFF bias?
full of aroma and flavor- Head did not last long, but the beer had good lacing.   Great microbrew.
Get some bitter hops in the aroma.Pours dark copper with an off white head.Get some sweet malts and hops in the flavor.Mouthfel is medium with a bitter hop finish.
Nicely bitter, but with fruit under-tones. Dark amber color. Medium body. Had in IN. Not available in MI 100 miles from brewery!?!

On tap at the Map Room. Amber colour with a fully diminishing frothy off-white head. Fresh piny and citrus hop aroma. Slight caramel flavour with a piny, grapefruit, and earthy bitter finish. Medium bodied, juicy mouthfeel. Good stuff.

12oz bottle snagged as soon as i heard FFF was ceasing distribution to Ohio. Amber color nearing dark copper, smells quite citrus approaching IPA status, however absolutely phenomenal taste This beer is balanced just right and one heck of a flagship.

Bottle: Pours a hazy amber color with a nice, slightly off white head. Smell seems to have a nice pine smell to it, with a bit of citrus in the background. The smell is very nice.
