Taste is piney, with a hint of maybe some caramel and grapfruit. The more I taste, the more intense the beer seems to get. With each sip, the taste of toffee seems to be creeping forward. This is good.

Such an amazing flagship beer, too bad it can¬ít be more oa flagship price so that I could drink it everyday.  Pours a dark copper amber color with a thick fluffy head.  Nice PNW hop aroma:  lots of pine and grapefruit.  If its a fresh bottle you¬íll know right here.  Smooth mouthfeel with  citrus grapefruit carmel and a lasting hop bitterness.  Three Floyd¬ís is never a strickler for style and they make great beers because of it.  When fresh this is closer to an IPA than many IPA¬ís I¬íve had.  But however you classify it, it is one great beer.

Poured a deep copper with orange hues with a almost non existent whispy white head.  Aroma was heavy and strong of pine, flowers and citrus.  Initial flavor was orange citrus, floral and sticky like pine tar.  Mouthfeel was strong, tingly on the tongue, with heavy and long lasting bitterness.

12 oz bottle. How have I not rated this before? Likely because I could always get it readily. Now that 3F is leaving VA, I guess I better get to it. Orange amber with a nice white head. Nice orange and grapefruit nose with a solid malt base. Piney citrus flavors, evenly bitter. Once the initial hop slap subsides, a snappy dry pine bitter lasts through the finish. Alpha King, I shall miss ye...

Not a fan this this, due to the FFF¬ís combination of hop¬ís that is present in most of their brews.  A bit sharp to me, but I understand some enjoy that type of profile.  Good mouthfeel and body to it with a bigger malt character than I expected.  Hmm, this actually saves it for me.  Very representative of the style, but I¬ím rating on my personal preference.  Not a poor beer, but not one that makes me jump up out of my chair.

Bottle. Pours a copper color with a nice off-white head on top. Aroma is a nice whiff of hops, and quite a bit of it, citrus, pine, floral hints, and caramel. Flavor is hops hitting the tongue with tastes of citrus and pine coming in as well. The hoppy flavor is well-balanced out by a nice sweet caramel taste for middle tastes and then finished with a nice bitterness. An excellent beer made by an excellent brewer.
A very drinkable APA.  The hops are very well balanced and not harsh at all (pine and floral).  There is a solid malt backbone, but it is the aroma which really draws me to this beer.  Fantastic.

Bottle. Pine floral hoppy aromas.  Amber brown color with good head and lacing.  Flavor is strong rich hops, citruy, pine, well balanced with light sweet flavor.  Mouthfeel is creamy and  thick.  Very good bitter finish.  Very good pale ale.

Very very nice. Man oh man, I wish the 3 Floyd stuff was easier to get here in So Cal. The Dreadnaught is simply the best DIPA. 
This pale ale is so balanced. It has all that a good pale ale ought to have. Some hop, some citrus, some pine. Very good.

A flat-out huge pale ale. Pours to a pleasantly full head. The very hoppy scent puts you in the mind of an IPA, but the taste is more balanced and the finish is pleasantly extended. Well worth the investment.
very good pale ale, bordering an IPA.  great hop aroma with a hint of malty sweetness.  smooth hop flavor from top to bottom.  citrus, pine, floral, the whole spectrum of flavors.  great beer
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Great ruby-mahogony body with a nice vanilla-bean colored head.  Excellent hoppiness though a bit more than I¬íd expect from an APA.  Very nice and smooth body, malty with some light hop accents, overall very good.  Ending is slightly too hoppy with too little malts to balance it.  However, this is a great beer though better classified as an IPA.

copper with an off white head. piney citrus hop aroma dominates with nice caramel toffee malt undertones. big bitter hop flavor with a good amount of toffee flavored malt. medium body. bittersweet toffee like malt shines on the finish leading into an incredible dry bitter hoppy end. this is how an apa should be.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2007 this is one hell of an apa bordering ipa! nice strong hoppy taste strong smell but not over powering citrusy smell, and goes down smooth this is the best apa especially for the price.ok size head but who cares this is a great tasting apa and has a nice orange hue to it. i love it!

Delicious sweet caramel malt, piney hop, and citrus aroma.  Pours a hazy gold with a small off-white head.  Flavor of hops, caramel malt, grassy notes, more hops, and grapefruit.  This is a damn good APA.  Very strong for the style, more like an IPA.  Medium to maybe a little thin body.

HOPS HOPS HOPS! Man this one has some bite to it, but in a very good way. Sampled this multiple times at the great american beer festival (definitely sampled it enough to warrant a review). Very strong hop flavor and aroma, nice hop resins present. This is definitely more then just an APA... it¬ís more aggressive then most IPAs. Pours a nice orangish hue with good lacing. Man what a treat this brew was, i¬íll never forget it. Although I have a VERY hard time getting any three floyds brews, everytime I try one i¬ím simply amazed.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2007 GABF 06.  Seems like more of an IPA than an APA...but is still delicious. Strong resiny citrus aroma and flavor.  Enough malt to back up the hops, overall an excellent beer IMO.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 A brewery has to be mighty confident to name one of its own beers with a compound of two flattering titles.  ¬ìKing¬î suggests a monarchial patriarch steeped, thanks to the popularity of democracy, in mystique and mythology.  An ultimate if foolish authority - the highest form of legal impunity.  But then to borrow some equally alluring and scholarly Greek to legitimize the regal appellation with the language of the ancients ¬ñ it shows no lack of gall, and a high risk of extreme gaucherie.  But they did it.  They made a beer entirely deserving of its name and more.  The more pale ales I drank at the GABF the more I realized it¬ís a style I dislike, but there were a handful that stood out.  They were the last bastions of quality in hops, and leading the pack was the Three Floyds Alpha King.  It was more than tolerable.  It was divine (gives a whole new meaning to divine right to rule).  Similar to the distantly related pale ales that sprawled across the festival floor like a plague of locusts, the Alpha King glowed brightly in a simple clear and gold garb topped with a thin laurel of off white foam.  Nothing extraordinary, but if the appearance was mundane then the aroma was exceptional.  The first smells to hit the olfactory are whipped cream and berries.  These punch into the nostrils, followed by the spine melting aromas of creamed honey, genuine ripe grapefruit, and a bouquet of wildflowers.  All of these heavenly, bellowing whiffs of dessert follow suit on the tongue, though taking an ancillary role tip-toeing on the palate behind bubbly and springy hops and floral qualities.  The key here is a balance.  Too many breweries think hopping up their beers and quantifying IBUs in scientific notation makes for an extreme experience.  And many drinkers think this is tantamount to a pleasing experience.  Since this is becoming the rule I¬íve progressively felt more and more ostracized from the pale ale community.  But the Alpha King, in his just and benevolent rule, has welcomed me back to a court where balance and focus make for the finest beer.  It¬ís well textured, well flavored, well scented, well balanced and generally well made.  It is, in my mind, the finest pale ale available and justly deserves its eminent title.
I¬ím a big hophead so this is right up my alley.  Great orange color, wonderful citrusy aroma (loads of Cascade  in this one).  Overall it is currently one of my favorite IPAs.
Thanks to CMUBEERMAN. Bottle. Pours hazy red caramel, off white head. Aroma is citrus, floral, hops, and caramel. Flavor is caramel, citrus, floral, and hops.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2006 Woohoo, my first 3 Floyds beer! 12 OZ Bottle via trade with cornboy(thanks!). Pours a clear dark copper with a small head.Nice hoppy aroma with notes of orange, grapefruit, and yeast. Medium bodied and carbonated just right. Taste reminds me a LOT of Rogue St Rogue. Has that nice hoppy Amber Ale taste that stays somehwat subdued but hits the spot. I always have trouble with this style as far as discering flavors as they seem to meld together so well. I think i taste some orange, grapefurit and caramel malt with a nice crisp finish. But it blends together so well it is hard to discern individual flavors. In any case, this is a well well balanced, refreshing easy drinking beer. Gimme more! Best APA i have had.

This big berry brew is a darker raspberry juiced red with a small orangeish head.  Hoppy naughtiness abounds.  This is the first of what I hope to be many of the 3 floyds.  But Ohio doesn¬ít seem to be getting any more of this brewery any time soon.  Please say it ain¬ít so!

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2006 Bottle courtesy of LeopoldStoch.  Pretty nice looking amber colored beer.  Nice fresh hop bouquet.   Pretty standard APA flavor.  Good beer, but im perplexed as to why the ratings are so high for this one.  Sometimes I think Three Floyds is paying you guys off.

Bottled.
Slightly hazy amber color, small off-white head. Bready, nice citric hoppy aroma. Light citrusy-grassy flavor. Pale malts are there. Hoppy aftertaste.

awesome apa!   smells of a citrus forest.  poured a foamy head.  great hoppiness in flavor as well.  a nicely balanced malt backbone.  my only problen with it is that is so damn hard to get a hold of where i live.  it was on the shelf for only two weeks, if i would have known that i would a have bought more.

12 oz bottle courtesy of my dad.  Poured a respectable antique bronze (slightly cloudy) with a large, somewhat rocky, off-white head, eternal and everlasting.  Hail to the king, baby.  Impressive lacing.  Big hoppy aroma of grapefruit rind; some resin.  Notes of soap, sugar, vanilla, lightly bready.  Medium sweet and heavily bitter - exceptionally balanced - with some buttery candy malt flavors appearing as the glass warms.  A very long, lightly sweet, heavily bitter, somewhat metallic finish.  Smooth and creamy, medium body, substantial carbonation.  To summarize, nothing is lacking in this beer.  It really does everything well.  It¬ís hard to say that one thing about the makes it the best, but all things considered in one bottle, you¬íd be hard pressed to find a better all around pale ale.  Super dynamo, yo.

355 ml. bottle.  Hazy orange.  Upon first sense of aroma I thought this was an India Pale Ale.  This is highly hopped.  If I¬ím not wrong the Warror hop has high amounts of alpha acids and the Centennial is lower.  But this is where is must get part of its name, yes?  Bottle conditioned.  Finely crafted.  More on the grassy side than citrusy side for me.  Nice long lasting bittering finish.  No sweetness here.  I thought pale ales would try more of a balance between sweet and bitter...this is all hops...I¬ím not complaining, but why is this not in an (American) India Pale Ale style?  Very good beer though.

From 12oz Bottle.  Pours a deep amber color with some fiery tones of peach skin and a creamy serving of off-white head.  Deep breath - man, I love centennial hops.  A nice, mild fruity spiciness accompanies the fresh hop character.  Some silky layers of white peach and creamy vanilla toffee line up eagerly behind the saturation of white peppered ruby red grapefruit that kisses my nostrils gently.  The mouthfeel is actually a bit heavier than I¬íd expect for the style, but its just so delicious I have to force myself to slow down and savor this one.  It is here that I discover this beer¬ís true genious.  It tastes like the aroma, but flawlessly - very fruity and very hoppy without being overly bitter and with a light, clean finish.  I¬ím amazed at how much flavor and character is built into such a small, easy drinking package relative to the style¬ís big brother peers.  Its like the jack-of-all-beers - fantastic as a sipper, perfect as a thirst quencher, and frighteningly easy drinking.  Marvelously done.  Thanks, Brandon!

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2006 Bottle.  Extremely hoppy aroma, light ale fruitiness, lightly sweet.  Tons and tons of grapefruit and a little miscellaneous citrus.  Pours a beautiful orange/copper with slight notes of red and an ephemeral tan head.  Very bitter taste, lastingly bitter, good grapefruit and citrus retention.  Tons of hoppiness, just a touch of non-grapefruit sweetness and sourness.  Medium body, crisp ... has its way with my taste buds.  Coating, lasting aftertaste.  Overall, aggressive and memorable, one of the best summer brews you¬íll ever find.

Medium light beige head over dark red slightly hazy body. Light, spicy
aroma with notes of chili, sweet caramel malts, and citrusy hops.
Taste is deep, peppery, bitter malts with strong harmonious citrusy
hop taste. Hard to make out the components here. Peppery, malty
aftertaste with some bitterness. An excellent session beer. I¬íd
happily drink many liters of this. (0.355l bottle, thanks to gr0ve.)

One of the benchmarksfor the style here. Slightly hazed, copper body topped by a small, but sturdy, beige head that laces nicely. Citrusy hops with a note of spruce dominate the flavor and aroma of this medium bodied APA. Well balanced and equisitely refined. Nice backbone of caramel tasting maltiness to accompany the exceptional hops profile. Consistently topnotch. An American classic!

Bottle from NachlamSie and memories of it on draught last year. Pours red orange with offwhite head. It has a hoppy aroma of citrus and some earthy spices with just a faint note of toast. The flavor has tons of grapefruit and an interesting spicy, sagelike finish. There is some burnt toast and sourdough malt notes to support all those hops, too. Very clean aftertaste.
Orange color with a small white head.  Citrus and pine aroma.  Hop flavors continue with a bit of maltiness.  Crisp hop finish.  Very nice, but their Dreadnaught spoiled me.

Boy, this is a fantastic APA. Got this on Draught at the Map Room on my last day in Chicago. Pours a dark honey orange gold color with a white head. Aroma is a nicely arranged blend of floral hops, citrus, pine, and I wasn¬ít going to say this, but I noticed someone else did, so what the heck, cannabis. Flavor is strong on the fruity, floral hops with a light caramel sweetness, and a nice not exactly bitter finish. What a flagship beer for Three Floyds!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2007 (Bottle at O.T, Stockholm) Pours beautiful, clear orange/red with a small wite head. Full bodied hop aroma. Notes of pine and citrus. Fruity with some sweeter malty notes. The flavour has a full fruity bitterness that moves through your mouth. Pepperish ending. Good sweet caramel maltiness. Pine spruces. Rough but oily. Some resin.

Maybe it¬ís just me, but this is my favorite style of beer and though I haven¬ít ventured too far into trying lots of different pale ales, this is the first time I¬íve really smelled "hops". It has a very grassy aroma, very dry hop like, which you don¬ít often smell from my experience.  I like it.

The flavor left me a little confused, as it tastes much lighter than it smells.. and gives you the same grassy, hoppy, light citrus & pine flavor.  I had hoped for more or different flavor, palate is a little watery, but this is a solid brew.

UPDATE: The grassiness, gets a little old quickly, so I had to lower my rating a bit.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Nice beer. Pours a slight hazy amber with a small head. Aroma is of grapefruit, floral and hops. Feels dryish to the palate but is also nice and crisp. A little soapish flavor.

Hazy light brown/amber. Small, frothy, tan head. Nose of cannibus, grapefruit, flowers, generic malt is barely detectable. Same flavors with a subtle caramel sweetness and some pine notes. A hint of lime in the aftertaste, along with those hops. Medium body is smooth and creamy with enough carbonation to balance. Damn easy drinking with a ton of hops. Hophead¬ís fix.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2006 Bottle. Pours a nice hazy light copper color with an average off white head. Very dominant pine and hop aroma. Nice good bitter dance of the tongue. Finishes with a lingering of the hops that make you want more. A good complex beer with lots of taste undertones.
Bottled. Amber reddish colour, with mediumsized white head. Strong flowery and caramellish hops in aroma. Fruity and a bit strawish hoppy flavour. Aftertaste is longlasting hops and hay.

A hophead¬ís dream come true.  Deep amber, with average sized beige head.  Flavor is intense--full hops & malt, and a nice hoppy finish that lingers on and on.  This is $11 a six here, and well worth it.

12oz bottle poured a clear copper in color with a nice white head. Aromas hop citrus and pine with some bubble gum notes. Nice bitter taste with a good malt balance and a huge charge of finishing hops that linger. Overall a great Pale/IPA.
Aromas and taste are hop dominated. Some caramel in there too. Not bad, but no as good as expected.

Bottle pured a hazy dark copper with a minimal amber head. Aromas of perfume, pine, hint of citrus and light carmel. Palate was light bodied and slightly resiny. Flavors of carmel, pine, earthiness, floral and a hint of grapefruit with a lingering lightly bitter finish.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2006 Wonderful aroma of hops.  Pours a deep golden/copper color with a nice crown that stays around.  I need to be more careful when pouring because this one was churning with carbonation and hop sediment.  Strong flavor that lingers with a bit of bitterness on the end.  I would think this one would age pretty good as well.

Aroma of western hops, with grass and grapefruit dominating.  Appears as a hazy copper beer, wigth a small yellow head that dissipates quickly.  Flavor is hop-dominant, with a bitter grapefruit punch overlaying a sweet caramel backbone.  Palate is moderately light, with a certain astringency, and with appropriate effervescence.  Overall, a very nice APA that is a bit more than the sum of its parts.
Very nice very good APA! I feel like the goose island brand does a better job, but cant deny that if this is a choice on a menu its a good one.
Loads of flavor, the good kind of bitter smooth and a bit of pine, very much like an IPA.  Long finish.

Hero 27 put it best when he said " 12 oz bottle. Pours a somewhat hazy golden/orange color with a billowing, fluffy white head. Sticky lacing residue on the glass that is there to stay. This is a PA?? Am I not seeing the word "India" somewhere on the bottle?..I had to look at it a few times just to make sure. Definitely an IPA in style, but what the hell, no complaints here. This bad boy is loaded with gorgeous floral hops.. Metaphorically speaking, the dominant grapefruit hops have the malts handcuffed to the bed here. Being somewhat of a self-proclaimed hophead, this was indeed heaven on earth for me. This thing should have an American flag on the label, because it is the pinnacle of the great American hop flavor. Very lively in the mouth, stinging hops jump back and forth on the tongue..the bitterness running it¬ís due course. This is why I drink beer... Very crisp and refreshing for such a complex and strong taste. Clean finish and lingering bitterness. Easy to drink is the understatement of the year. This can be found in my fridge year round, and is perfect on hot summer day or just when you need a quick hop fix. One to be respected and definitely a treat for any beer lover. If you haven¬ít tried it yet, track it down and do so ASAP. Still one my my all-time favs." Put like a champion
Tremendous tasting beer,pours a glowing copper big headed beer.Might be the best apa i have ever had. Keep up the great work.This is a must try beer but it is hard to find in pa.

Bottle.  Average-sized off white head that dwindles but a nice thin layer stays on top throughout, helping keep the piney, almost astringent citrus aroma alive.  Tons of flavor.  Perfect body and feel in the mouth.  Terrific hoppy kick.  I¬ím not 100% sure about this beer¬ís label of APA - may be more of an IPA. A very nice beer. A must try.

This has got to be my "go-to" beer.  I love this stuff and cant imagine ever growing tired of it.  The aroma is the typical strong floral hop aroma that you get from all FFF beers, and the taste follows nicely, although their is a little noticeable bitterness in the flavor (not a bad thing though)  I love that I can get this stuff all the time and never have to drive more then 5 minutes to get it.  Great beer overall!

The 12 ounce bottle poured a slightly hazy reddish amber beverage with a creamy off-white head that was fully lasting and left good lacing on the glass. There was an unmistakable huge hop aroma that was dominated by the grapefruit-citrus presence of Cascade hops. You would think this was a west coast ale. The body was medium-full with lively carbonation and a smooth, creamy texture. The flavor started off slightly sweet with a subtle bitter undercurrent. You can definitely taste citrus here. It has a long lasting finish and as the flavor matures the sweetness dies away replaced by a smooth pleasant bitterness. Nice.

This one seems a bit overrated to me, but that doesn¬ít mean I don¬ít like it a lot.  From a growler, into a glass. Nice, deer orange and red with a small, well retained head.  Lots of hops, mostly of the floral hop character with a bit of pine and citrus in there too.  Some berry-ish esters further compliment the modest malty sweetness.  Lighter side of medium bodied until you get to the finish, which is ridiculously clean, too much so if you ask me.  Lots of hop aroma with very low percieved bitterness.  A pleasant, interesting beer that fits any occassion, even though it let me down a little at the end.

Pours golden with medium white head.  Aroma is piney and citrusy.  Nice grapefruit aroma.  Tastes is bitter hops balaced really well with sweet malt.  Don¬ít get me wrong, this beer is over the top hoppy.  Finishes bitter and delivcious.  Coats the tongue nicely and the flavor lasts and lasts.

This copper ale poured with a medium off-white head that dissipated rather quickly. It is very smooth and hoppy with a grassy aroma and a nice bite at the finish. I really enjoyed this beer -  it just has a very nice flavor.
A dark golden beer with a strong hop aroma. The taste is superb, lots of tasty hops. Bitter, fruity with zing!  The combination of hops are perfect. One of my favorites.

12 oz bottle.

Pours a somewhat hazy golden/orange color with a billowing, fluffy white head. Sticky lacing residue on the glass that is there to stay.
This is a PA?? Am I not seeing the word "India" somewhere on the bottle?..I had to look at it a few times just to make sure. Definitely an IPA in style, but what the hell, no complaints here. This bad boy is loaded with gorgeous floral hops..
Metaphorically speaking, the dominant grapefruit hops have the malts handcuffed to the bed here. Being somewhat of a self-proclaimed hophead, this was indeed heaven on earth for me. This thing should have an American flag on the label, because it is the pinnacle of the great American hop flavor. Very lively in the mouth, stinging hops jump back and forth on the tongue..the bitterness running it¬ís due course. This is why I drink beer...  Very crisp and refreshing for such a complex and strong taste. Clean finish and lingering bitterness.
Easy to drink is the understatement of the year. This can be found in my fridge year round, and is perfect on hot summer day or just when you need a quick hop fix. One to be respected and definitely a treat for any beer lover. If you haven¬ít tried it yet, track it down and do so ASAP. Still one my my all-time favs..

Got one of the last ones at the Foodery in Phila.  Interesting style with hops maybe a bit over the top of what I¬íd call my ideal beer.  As Nelson Muntz said, "you gotta pet the dog so he can FEEL it."

bottle. nice copper/amber pour with thick head.  great lacing.  Big grapefruit and hop aroma.  Beautiful hops.  I want to chew this beer.  bitter bite.  grapefruit.  aftertasted lingers long, thankfully.  Great APA

On tap at the Map Room. Great Great Brew! Mucho hops both in the aroma and flavour. Good body and medium bite. A very pleasant session beer. Reminded me a little of a toned down dreadnaught. Hats off once again to 3F.

What a great APA. This definitely leans to the IPA department, which is just fine with me. The pour is golden brown, with a nice off white head. Immediately, you can smell the pleasant citrus hops wafting from the glass. I could sit and sniff this sucker all day long. The mouthfeel is thicker than many other APA¬ís I¬íve had, which is nice. The flavor is hop dominated, of course, but there is enough malt to balance that almost to perfection.
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2008 Pours amber with a small head. Sweet hoppy aroma. Sweet flavor with a little bit of a grapefruit after taste. Nice mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 New Rating: On tap at the brewery. Pours an amber color with orange highlights and a big fluffy white head. Hazy body. Nose is citrus and flowers mostly grapefruit and hops. Taste is very refreshing and bitter with a nice toasty malt presence. and medium mouthfeel. Great beer that packs a punch but is well balanced. Very nice.

Bottle. Big, sweet, fruity hop aroma, with warm flavors of malt and orangey hops. Most remarkable was the soft, velvety, enveloping mouthfeel - almost no carbonation and tons of flavor. I¬íd like to take another crack at this one.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 In march 2007 I had a few that had more tea in the mix and it wasn¬ít good. Still, one of my favorite ales so far. I  went around the block from very good to great a couple times but have settled on great. Unique. Smoot yet dry with great flavor and feel, but sometimes I prefer more bite and less citrus.

via trade with Slob - (Aahhhh, my 1st Three Floyds) Pours an amber color with a nice initial head that faded to a film rather quickly.  Very light spotty lacing.  Has a big floral citrus hop aroma.  Flavor is mainly hops, but has a nice malt background.  Very smooth, no astringent aftertaste.  Medium body.  An excellent beer.  Thanks Bert.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Amber/copper color with a small just off white head.  Aroma of big citricy piney flowery hops.  Mouthfeel is good with malts to start with lingering bitterness in the finish. Taste of citris, pine, grass,  to grapefruit bitter which lingers well after.  Even better on a second tasting.
Re-Rate: I just love everything about this beer and can¬ít help but up the score everytime I drink this.  I enjoy it more each time I have it.

bottle.  Aroma:  Wonderful hop nose!  Grapefruit, grass, floral, and some resin.  Also picked up malt sweetness and honey.   Appearance:  poured a clear deep copper color, with a good light tan head. Not much lacing.  Flavor:  An immediate flavor of floral hops with some grapefruit undertones gives way to a caramely malt flavor which then gives way to a nice bitter finish.  I was expecting this to be more bitter than it was, but it is very well balanced.   Also detected a faint earthiness that is unlike anything I¬íve had in an APA.  Almost reminiscent of a fine scotch.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Moderate, but appropriate carbonation.  Slight alcohol detected in back of mouth.  Overall:  One of the best APAs I¬íve ever had.  Well crafted, well balanced, and delicious.  It¬ís hoppy, but not crazily so.  Every flavor plays a part and all synch together very well.
This APA is a definite winner.  A gorgeous amber colour.  A fruity flavour, slightly malty.  A big winner of APA¬ís.

Bottle, poured deep amber with an off white head, little lace. Aroma is fruity, maybe apples? Low on Malts which balances well. Flavored as a citrusy American hop with a balanced medium finish, leaving a slight bitterness. I picked up a few extra for the frig.

A deep, dark amber pour with a diminishing head and little to no lace.  Bouquet of honey, fruit, malt and floral aromas.  This is graciously hopped, with notes of fruit, peppered toffee, bitterness, grapefruit and a smidge of caramel.  The finish is nice, long and bitter, really highlighting the back of the palate.  Nicely complex, and a wonderful APA!

Thanks to the_Epeeist for the trade! Red-amber pour, white head that instantly dissolves into a thin film. Very little lacing. Nose dominated by sweet malt, with a suggestion of citrus and piney hops beneath. Conversely, it is rather bitter on the tongue, and the malt tone is more grainy at first, before finishing with a nice balance between the hops and malts lingering after the last sip. Its as if the hops and malts battle throughout the nose and initial downtake, and then just say, "oh what the heck, I guess we can live together as equals after all. Let¬ís compromise and contribute equally on the finish." Something like that. Additionally, it really coats well in the mouth and the carbonation level is perfect for the style. Flavor seems to continue to pop off the tongue well after sipping. Overall, a very fine APA in my book.

355 ml bottle. Amber coloured. Almost clear, but has a slight haze. Thick off-white persistent head. Bold grapefruity and grassy hop aroma. Really strong hop aromas for a pale ale. Malty body with strong hop bitterness. Slightly harsh notes, but the sweetness from the malt depth does hide most of these. This is a great pale ale. The aroma promises much more than was is actually happening in the mouth, but what‚Äôs there is well balanced and makes a wonderful pale ale. It even got the looks. Recommended.
Big citrusy/hoppy nose; amber/orange body with a small off-white head; Flowery citrus/hoppy flavor with a nice bitter hop finish. Well balanced!

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2006 Wonderful burnt orange color with huge citrus hops aroma. Tastes like grapefruit/orange/flowers. A sweetness balances the bitterness of the hops, but this can make it seem a bit syrupy. Gets a small hit overall due to expense (compared to other quality APA¬ís).

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2007 Pours an amber color with an orange color on the edges.  Has a thin off-white head.  Aroma is of grapefruit,  pine hops, and caramel.  Flavor is the same with huge citrus and pine hops.  Gives way to the caramel flavor and finally finishes decently bitter.  Very delicious APA, probably one of my favorites.

The Alpha King is the stuff of legends. He killed people. He loved people. He was indifferent towards people. Most of all, he consumed a shitload of hops. 

Excellent Bottle. Pours pretty but unexceptional into a tall pilsner glass. Nice head, good retention. Light orange/amber.

Goodness, what a nice smell. Hoppy as a bunny rabbit along with a light floral hint. It¬ís like a rosegarden, really, completely natural. Not fake flowers. Flowers. This is nice.

Strange as it may sound, it tastes pretty much like it smells: an insanely hoppy flower garden. Complex as hell. The hops are a little bit smaller upfront than in the back, the aftertaste is dry as can be and nice and bitter. Unique as hell. Hops and hops and sugar and a whole array of flavors that I¬íve never tasted before. It¬ís like a Ricola losenge, those natural, flowery ones. 

Full body. Goes down smooth, but there may be a bit too much hops for me to drink more than a few of these. It gives me the tastiest feelings in my throat long after I drank it
De richlikebeer. Belle ambr√©e, petit collet, beaucoup d¬íeffevercance. Fort arome d¬íhoublon et d¬íagrume. Go√ªt am√®re de th√©, un peu d¬íagrume.
Pours a dark amber color, and releases a fantastic, hoppy aroma. This is a citrusy, bitter ale and the floral-hop flavor puts it near the top of my list.

Bottled. Beer is a clear medium-dark brown with an average-sized, frothy, white, mostly and rapidly diminishing head. The aroma is quite hop-centric and not very complicated: Malty with a light note of toasted grain and a trace of caramel; Heavily hoppy with notes of apricot, resin/pine and a light note of herb. The flavor is heavily sweet and lightly bitter with a long, lightly bitter, lightly acidic, lightly-to-moderately sweet finish. The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively. Sorry kids, I don¬ít see what the hoopla is about.

Dark amber colored, thick medium sized light brown head. Rich and kind of soft aroma with fine hops, floral tones, caramel and bitterness. Medium bodied. Flavor has also dominating floral tones with hops and caramel, still palate is somehow soft and creamy. Finely balanced APA, but still misses something.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 A darker pale ale with a rich malt profile--almost an amber but not quite.  Very fresh dark citrus, resinous hops notes with substantial bitterness that coats the tongue and lingers on pleasantly.  The alcohol is well integrated into the full, well-rounded body.  A very big, though excellently balanced pale ale--assertive and distinctive.

Gorgerous copper brown color with a two finger head with good lacing. Huge oily hop notes. Plenty of lemony leafy hops. Very sweet citrus hop oil taste. A little malt balance. This beer is delightfully smooth and creamy. A textbook APA that I¬íve heard lots about and certainly hasn¬ít disappointed.

(Bottled) Clear, deep amber color with a medium head. Slightly sweet, very aromatic nutty-woody-hoppy aroma with a lime-lemony twist. Aromatic-hoppy, birch and blackcurrant leaf flavor with a very bitter, dry finish. Medium-bodied, dry and bitter palate with quite low carbonation. A very dry and hoppy, quite balanced pale ale. Still not the most pleasant one.

I don¬ít know, maybe I was caught off guard by the "pale ale" label. But, heck, this one was as strong as any IPA I¬íve ever had. Not the kind of beer I¬ím looking for while sweating during summer activity, and I was therefore disappointed. Within the IPA class, it was certainly pine and floral smelling. The flavor was much of the same but with a touch of that grapefruit flavor. Too much pine trees here, though. If you¬íre a hop head and ready for hops, then give it a try. Otherwise, you won¬ít like it. Next time I¬íll go suck on the evergreens in my back yard.

Thanks to px2grafx for hooking me up with the 3F stuff! Poured a slightly darkened orange body with a small to moderate head. Lacing was decent. But, what a blast of fruity hops! Tons of grapefruit, lots of citrus. Enough malt to balance it. Huge flavor as well, quite bitter, especially for the style. Mouthfeel was slightly watery. Otherwise this was amazing for an APA... easily the best I¬íve had for the style. All I want now is their IIPA... ahhhh.

Thanks to artusory for sending me this 355 mL bottle.  Pours a copper and burgandy color with a small off-white head that finds it necessary to quickly retreat to the edges and wait for the opportunity to provide some lined lacing.  Aroma is fragrant fruity, floral citrus hops, sweet, malt (meal, cookie), caramel, faint pine and spruce notes.  Moderately bitter, heavy hop acidity, a distant sweetness, tart citrus rind acidity, finish is smooth yet acidic, not bothersome, attempts to scorch the tongue.  Medium to full bodied, crisp and fizzy palate.

Had this one bottled in St. Charles, Illinois.  WOW.  One of the hoppiest beers I¬íve ever had.  A deep copper color with a thin white head that dissipated rapidly, spice and flowers in the nose with a pronounced hoppiness, with rosewater, the tartness of coffee without the flavor, some apple and cinnamon.  Excellent.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2006 Bottle.

Sweet aroma, light amber color with good head that stays.
Taste is sweet and hoppy. A good ale.

I bought a case of this recently, although I¬íve had it on draft and bottle before, this time I¬íve decided to rate it.  Pours clear amber with nice thick tan head.  Flower aroma, definitely hoppy.  Medium character, outstanding taste, tons of bitterness.  Definitely one to put onto the regular rotation.

12 oz bottle, via LeopoldStoch.  Dark copper pour with a one finger off-white head.  Clear, with no sediment noted in bottle.  Big citrusy hop aroma with a sweet caramel malt base.  Very bright with lots of grapefruit.  Flavor is well balanced with lots of hoppiness without being overly bitter.  Nice malt background rounds out the flavor well.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with creamy texture and moderate but soft carbonation.  A nice enjoyable brew that would make a good session choice.

12 oz Bottle: Pours a copper color with an average off-white head that diminishes rather quickly to nice lacing. Hoppy aroma is citrus. Flavor was sweet and hoppy with a bitter grapefruit finish. Very drinkable and delicious especially for Hop lovers.

Bottle courtesy of Illnismitty. Poured an amber color with an off white head. The nose found citrus and spices with light pine and malts. The flavor was very hoppy with citrus and green tea standing out. Orange in the aftertaste. Light to medium body. Smooth bitterness throughout. Very enjoyable! Thanks Sean!

Dark golden with fast disappearing white head; big fat hoppy nose, deep and complex, it changes all the time you smell it: bitter pine, loads of citrus, overripe pear, a little metallic white sugar, white bread dough; great carbonation in a medium full, super balanced body (could be more apparent); very bitter and super, super dry finish, very complex, lacks body but stands exceptionally on its dryness, it has quite alot of barley in it, but also fresh fruit. A very interesting beer.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours amber with a slight haze and a creamy, beige head. Very hoppy, grapefruitish aroma. Medium-bodied, rather sweet caramel malt and a marked, bitter finish with very delicate notes of grapefruit from the great hops. 020506

first legal beer.  smooth and cheers worthy.
recommened by eboats and enjoyed by all.

remember the first time you masturbated?
drinking this almost brought that feeling back.
UPDATED: MAY 18, 2006 The floral aroma was breathtaking.  It had an amber hue.  The head  seemed to go away quickly.  Excellent taste of grapefruit and hops.  Overall an awsome beer

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2008 draught. Pours copper with a dense white head, laces quite well during the drinking process. The aroma is very floral, spicy, and mildly sweet. The flavors are wonderfully harmonious and of green tea, bright, crisp acidity and the honey-esque sweetness is perfectly appropriate.Completely balanced and easy to drink though still with adequate complexity to save it from being boring.
br
Bottle - Y¬íknow it¬ís really amusing that this is their flagship beer. I mean, this is supposed to be the accessible, easy-drinkin¬í session beer. This is indeed easy drinking for any beer enthusiast, but still with more than enough cajones to frighten fizzy-yellow-beer-drinkers. This is one of the finest examples of an APA I can reference. All the elements of tea, grass, pine, caramel come together perfectly in the most tasteful of proportions.  
br
[March 6, 2008]
br
Bottle. It seemed a little more difficult to track down some Three Floyds on this trip to Chicago, but thankfully I was able to enjoy this bad boy again. This is the king of APA¬ís. It has the perfect level of crystal malt sweetness  to provide some type of balance while the bright citrus, pine, and marijuana-like hops do their thing.  Awesome.

br
[June 21, 2008]
br
On tap. It has been way too long since I¬íve had a sample this fresh of Alpha King. I¬íve got a couple of bottles in my hotel room and as delicious as the first one was, it doesn¬ít measure up to the pint I enjoyed earlier at Rich-O¬ís. Taking a sniff effortlessly bombards my olfactories with aggressive, perfectly defined hop character. Loads of grapefruit and pine are all over the place with zesty, herbal hints in between. The malts are medium-sweet, really just an afterthought. The amount of hop character imparted on Alpha King is truly remarkable in both its strength and clarity, yet this semi-dry brew is notably sessionable.

(Draught at Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Colour is dark amber, some ruby notes, clear with little head. Lovely, fruity nose with a burst of fresh hops, citrus (grapefruit) and some chocolate. Fruity taste with notes of grapefruit, fresh hops, chocolate and even some dark cherries. Slightly nutty. Long, hoppy, bitter finish. Some initial sweetness, but turns drier towards the finish. Beautiful balance between malt, fruit an hops. Brilliant!

Maybe I Had an old bottle, but i wasn¬ít terribly impressed.  I got barely any aroma.  Some dish soap and some hops.  The flavors were bitter and astringent.  Hoppy with some of the feel of an amber ale, tasting like carmel and a very nice malt backbone.  Decent.  Will be glad to re-rate when i move to IL.
I¬íve had this little gift from God both in bottle and from the tap at the brewpub.  Nice dark amber, wonderful hops taste with just the right amount of bitter.

I wa slucky enough to get this one pulled from a cask at the maproom in Chicago. Thick foamy and soft head. Dark amber coloured with maybe a hint of brown colouring. Mostly citrusy hops aroma. Nice tasting beer with an up-front hops taste with some bitterness. I get soem floral notes in the taste as well. Finsihed smooth with little aftertaste.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus.  Pours brown with a  tan head. Aroma of citrus and hops. Flavor is smooth, citrus & and bitter. I wasn¬ít crazy about this one.

IBU¬ís are fairly high in this brew but I¬ím not sure I would call it the Alpha King!  (I¬íve made & had hoppier brews)  That being said, this brew has a very respectable ¬íhopping¬í that would please every hophead.  The hops utilized work well together to create a nice, dry yet bitter palate while letting caramelized malt flavors through.

Bottle. Wonderful Pale ale. Pours with a mediumhead, and good lacing that dissipates fairly quickly. Clear with an amber color. Spectacular aromas of malt, perfume and flowers. Flavor is of strong hops with a bitter finish. The carbonation is just right and the lingereing bitterness lasts for a long time.

Great hops!  They smell so fresh on the aroma -- apricot, grapefruit peel, soap, geraniums.  Good hop bite is bitter and fruity, drier on the finish.  Plenty of balancing malts, but they do not overwhelm the loads of hop flavor in this beer.  Low carbonation, medium mouthfeel.  Thin head, some slight lacing, copper in color.

I¬ím becoming a big fan of Three floyds. 
great hop flavor and even better hop aroma.  Thankfully this is available in PA.  Very much worth a try for any one into hoppy beers.
This beer was a little strong for my taste but I can see why people who like a beer with a ton of flavor would like this beer.
This is definitely a brew for the hop-heads.  This is another fine example of the craftmanship from 3 Floyds.  Hops and more hops in the aroma and in the flavor.  A must try.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2008 [Bottle]  Clear honey-amber with topped off with an eggshell head that sticks around for a part of the ride.  Flowers and citrus fruits hit hard in the aroma, which is splendidly complimented by toasty malts.  The nerves residing on my taste buds react to the myriad of flavors and I¬ím overcome with clarity.  As the background noise melts away the sweet caramel malts and the grass and citrus (oranges, grapefruit, honeysuckle) hops blend into delightfully balanced sensation.  Despite it¬ís easily distiguished hops characteristics (and the fact that I¬íve encountered a few IPAs that didn¬ít ¬íbring tha noize, bring tha funk¬í) I don¬ít agree that it should be categorized as an IPA but still resides a few steps above your everyday pale ale.  Definately a top notch creation and deserves a swig from anyone that knows anything about beer.

Starts with a stong floral and citrusy aroma.  Apears golden and inviting.  It has a medium sweetness and a  lightly bitter after taste.  Fascinatingly complex interaction of flavors -- Indeed, it is truly the King of all Alphas.

Nice redhaired body.  Thin fading head. Nose is mostly pine with orange blossom, grass, and lemon.  Palate is balanced, with finishing bitterness.  Flavour is orange peel and pine, a citrus blend floats in the middle,  supprisingly there is no yeastyness for a bottle condition.

Aroma is clean hoppy hoppy hoppy.  A wonderful amount of floral hops with a hint of citrus, almost a cross between lemon and grapefruit.  Appearance is clear medium-dark brown/orange - looks like liquid toffee although I¬ím sure it won¬ít taste that way.    Lots and lots of hops on the taste - grassy earthiness, some citrus, very bitter in a good way.  Some malts noticable to some balancing out, but the hops are very predominant.
It is indeed more like an IPA than many IPAs I have drunk.  That said, it is a delicious IPA.  Great hops and a terrific nose. The depth of flavor in this is impressive.
On Tap at Richos, Pours nice tane with generous head with vigorous amounts of CO2.  Fairly Hoppy and can almost have a bit of palet striping effect. I would say is more like and IPA then a pale ale.
Clear, medium tan.  Crystal clear.  Off white, generous head.  Big citrusy aroma.  Full mouthfeel.  More citrus and pine in the flavor.  A big watery aftertaste.  Pretty good.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2006 Big hoppy nose.  Orange pale ale.  Strong American hoppy taste.  A kinda grapefruit type kick, a bit of pine with some stickiness.  This is the kind of bitter I like.  The best pale ale I have tried.

Standard orange color with a thin head, very mild aroma (but non-offensive).  The surprise is in the taste.  I¬ím not a huge pale ale fan, but this was tasty.  Nice hops, but not too bitter.  A little citrus, and sweetness that balanced the whole thing out.

On tap.  A pale red brown with a few too many bubbles, but perhaps that¬ís how the thin head persisted for the first half of the pint.  Sweet floral hops were immediately detectable.  There¬ís some thin malt in there, but the sweetness smells like its coming from the hops, more like a sweet smelling flower than a beer.  There¬ís a little bit too much CO2 here, but not painfully so, and it provides a good frothy mouthfeel with a bit of thickness to it.  The flavor is really well balanced: subtle pale malt provides an almost cornsyrup like sweetness against  the big (but not too big) floral fruity hopness.  Pretty darn enjoyable, I could knock back quite a few of these!
Orange with a small white head and looks highly carbonated.  Flavour and aroma were each similar- not super complex, a bit fruity and bitter but well balanced.  Refreshing.
Wonderful color and aroma.  Does not taste like a pale ale but more like an IPA. Just a great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2006 For me, this has trumped Victory Hop Devil and Sierra Nevada.  My favorite APA, style IPA.  A very intense hops aroma, surprisingly unexpressed in previous reviews.  Not particularly engaging in appearance; standard hue, very thin head; but just how an IPA should taste.  Great citrus/piney hop flavor.  Balanced.

This is a very potent ale.  I could smell the aroma of wild flowers the second I opened the bottle.  A complex flavor of citrus and fruit wine.  A bit too hoppy for me to drink regularly, but I¬íd still recommend anyone to try it.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2007 Rerate!  12oz bottle straight from the friggin brewery, no date as always.  Pours a slighly hazy copper orange with a half finger yellowish white head--decent retention.  Also, there were a couple of floaties in this bottle, which I¬íve never seen out of my many many bottles of this stuff.  Aroma of pineapple, grapefruit, some pine needles, and caramel malts.  Smells hoppier than most APA¬ís I¬íve had.  Caramel malts do seem a bit stronger in the flavor than the aroma, though the hops still shine--pineapple and grapefruit are up front, and some pine and floral hops linger in the background.  The caramel malts do a good job of giving the fruitiness of the hops a pleasant sweetness.  Semidry finish.  Bitterness doesn¬ít creep up until the dry swallow after the  swallow of beer, and it¬ís around a 6 (out of 10).  Burps pine.  Low to moderate carbonation with a medium fairly creamy body.  Without looking, I think this is still my highest rated APA--one great thing about living in the Midwest.


Old rating follows.  12oz. bottle.  Pours a clear amber orange with a mod sized off-white head.  Aroma of grapefrtuit and piney hops, with a sweet caramel backbone.  Taste follows the aroma.  So well balanced, only offers a slightly bitter finish.  I think this is my favorite everyday APA to date--I don¬ít even think Sierra Nevada Pale compares.  9-4-9-4-17--4.3
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Hoppy aroma, but well balanced on the tongue.  Deep color, somewhat creamy body, easy to drink but the flavor is full.  There wasn¬ít anything surprising about this one, nothing too original for the style, but its about as delicious as can be.

Has a nice orange amber color, with little head.  Pleasant mild hoppy aroma to it.  Flavor is excellent, nice and hoppy and a little bitter.  Pretty good body, light on the carbonation.  Overall, this is good.

Bottle. Clear copper/orange pour beneath a thin, but persistant bone white head. Aromas of freshly sliced grapefruit and orange dominate with a hint of pine and caramel malts in the background. Mouthfeel is fairly light and smooth. Although somewhat tauted as a hop-bomb, I found the balance of this APA to be its strength. The citrusy/pine hop flavors are incredibly balanced with the caramel malt sweetness to make this a classic, benchmark APA.  Finishes clean and crisp with a fairly aggressive bitterness. Great stuff!

Raw amber honey pour with a small layer of butter colored head. A sweet and citrus aroma that reminds me of candied oranges, with a bit of gingerbread. Lots of sweetness and lots of hop flavor that don¬ít seem like they have much interest in playing nice, leaving the sweetness feeling a bit sticky and the bitterness feeling kind of coarse. As the glass progresses, the marriage become a bit more civil and some pleasant underripe fruit flavors appear. Some winey tanic quality. A surprising amount of alcohol is noticable in the palate, distracting from what is otherwise a medium to light mouthfeel. Not sure what to make of this. A very dissappointing taste, and given the almost universal raves, it seems almost certain that I bought was a past it¬ís prime. I will re-rate this as soon as I can find it again.

Probably the best APA i¬íve had.  It looks like it will be an average micro with a pale color and medium foam.  However, the hops take over on the first sip.  It¬ís got a good hop bitterness without being overdone.  This would be a great beer to have on tap, with a light refreshing palae and delicious flavor.  I would happily have a barrel of this and drink one of these nightly.
For a pale ale this is pretty clutch.  Has citrus element to it, not overly hoppy, finishes slightly bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2006 first fff beer i ever drank. wow what a surprise i was used to regular beer  but this put me in a whole new world of beer.everything good you read about this beer is true i drink it all the time and it always taste just as good as the last one. try it at brewpub fresh from tap wow you will not want to leave CHEERS to the guys .we know why it is their flagship beer
Bottle. Amber colour with a big tan head. Malty, grape, hoppy aroma and taste. well ballanced. Medium to full body with a sweet dry finish. Very nice.

On cask.Pours clear auburn-copper, thin bubbly white head that quickly dissipates and leaves small bits of lace here and there. Big huge citrus hop aroma (lemon & grapefruit) in the nose backed by a good does of caramely-sweet malt. Flavor is an amazing balance of caramel-like malt sweetness and big floral & citrus hops that are plenty bitter but not obnoxiously so. Fruity elements are definitely allowed to play and are not drowned out by the hop bitternes. Thinnish & slightly gritty palate befitting of a cask-served beer. If there¬ís anything better than Alpha King, it¬ís Alpha King on cask.
Light hazy amber colour with a small off white head. Hoppy aroma with a nice citric and light pine note. Malty, light caramel sweet flavor with a hoppy citric and light dry finish.

Bottle.
Clear amber colourred with an off white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel and hops.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel and hops.

My go to IPA...12oz Pour a warm brown color with medium size white head and nice lacing. Aromas of citrus, pine, and grapefruit. The flavor is perfectly balanced and not overly bitter. A first rate beer from one of the best brewers in America.
Deliciously drinkable. Very citrusy, grapefruit aroma. Fresh and wonderful in the mouth, and extremely well balanced. Wish I could get this stuff locally.

12oz bottle- Poured a reddish orange color with nice head. Aroma of citrus - grapefruit and pine. The best part of this beer is the well rounded hop and malt balance. It finished dry but it is a very drinkable beer for the ammount of hops. I will have this beer in my fridge most of the time due to its availablity and due to its drinkablility.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 After years of drinking the big buisness macros, i  am now trying real beers. From a New-B percpective this was nicely intence after putting in the freezer for a few minutes. Poured into a glass it looks like a brownish honey color with a very small offwhite head. Nice hoppy sweet smell and not over fuity like the highly rated Dreadnaught Imperial IPA. If your just graduating from the Bud-Coors lightstuff and this is your very first try at this beer, it may seem too intense. But after you have tried a few differenent beers i am sure you will find this very enjoyoble. Also very affordable. $6.99 a six pack in Pawtucket RI. *** Its been almost 2 years and i finially have a chance to try this beer again, i¬íve come a long way in  my tastes and since discovered that i¬ím not really crazy about pale ales, but i still respect this one as one of the best. I also look forward to comparing it to the Dreadnaught which i will guess i will not like as much as this one, the King is much easier to drink and enjoy.
UPDATED: JAN 4, 2007 unreal beer.  Had it almost a month ago, so it is not that fresh in my head, but I will be going back to New Albany soon, and will try it again.  Sorry Piscator.

bottle. pours a copper-orange body with a medium creamy white head that slowly recedes leaving lace sheets. beautiful aroma of cookies, orange resin, and soft bread. bready flavour with oodles of chewy C hops. smooth and creamy palate achieves amazing balance and drinkability. yeah, I want more of this! Thanks for the bottle, Derek.

maybe my favorite beer altogether.  could drink a 6-pack in one night and be very happy, and not an especially expensive 6-pack either.  tons of citrus/fruit flavor, tons of hops.  same aroma as dreadnaught almost, but with a flavor lacking the dreadnaught¬ís slight alcohol bite.  if i was stuck with one beer for the rest of my life, i do believe i¬íd choose this

UPDATED: APR 13, 2006 in the description it says "a hop lover¬ís cult beer", They are so right. Pours a deep dark amber. Floral hop aroma. Extremely bitter and hopped like mad. There is a sixer of this in my fridge at all times. 6.99 for 6 and I¬íll keep buy it until the end of time.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2007 I understand why this beer is rated so high, but it must not be my style because it was a little intense for me. I am still a newb at craft beer so maybe I will give this a try again in a few years. The aroma citrus and floral aroma was great I had never smelt a beer like this, but when i tasted it i felt like was sucking on flower petels. I think it was worth the deal of $1.79.

Rerate: I have had this many times since the above rating which was a 3.5. This beer is great. A great hop profile, malt profile, and its easy to drink and not that high in alcohol. I downed 4 of these last night on the 4th easily.

12 oz bottle.  Orange tea colored with creamy beige head that settles to pond scum.  Tangerine, grass, Schweppes Bitter Lemon and clover honey.  More tangerine in the taste that fades to melon with hops gently creeping through in the end.  Fruity burps.  Medium-light body with faint carb.  Crisp with a clean finish.  I could drink this every day!

Bottled, At first the smell is overwhelming, so is the taste, after a few sips it mellows out quite a bit, but its very intense at first, so much going an at once its like an overload. Very hoppy flavor, slight citrus finish, overall this was a very excellent beer, no wonder i hear so much about it.
Pours a deep amber color.  Aromas of mild malt and citrus hops.  Big hop flavor is balanced with a smooth malt taste.  Good dry hop finish and aftertaste.
Hazy amber color with a thin off-white head.  Hoppy aroma with some citrus and grass.  Taste is big on hops with a nice citrus balance.  Smooth beer that goes down well.  Impressive.

(bottle - 12 oz) Very nice amber color with about a half inch of slightly off-white head and lacing that stays with it all the way to the end. Aroma is full of flavorful hops, citrus, grass and some caramel. Very floral and peppery. The flavor is very floral as well. Lots of hops and sweetness in the flavor. Tons of hoppy bitterness and pepper notes in addition to a very prominent citrus flavor. Very smooth and extremely well blended. Possibly the best pale ale I¬íve ever run across.

I was given this beer, I would not buy it because I simply don¬ít like any pale ale except Bass. This has the grapfruit bitterness that keeps me away. I notice any beer with higher then normal alc levels gets a higer rateing. If you like this style I bet you would love this as it is well crafted, smells nice, and looks nice. I just don¬ít like pale ales at all.
One of my all time fav¬ís.  So good it¬ís worth the drive to Rhode Island.  FFF¬ís: Please distribute to Massachusetts!
great great great. bitter hoppy sexiness. ful flavoured clean and crisp. smells like weed but thats just the fantastic hops. mmm i love this beer.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Illinismitty. Poured a nice amber color with a frothy well retaining head. The aroma was of citrus and hops. Much hoppier than the pale ales I am use to drinking (Sierra Nevada).  The taste was nice and hoppy as well. Initially, the flavor of the sweet malts fills the palate.  However, this beer finishes with a nice hoppy, pine aftertaste. A very well balanced APA, probably the best I have had.

Ah the famous Three Floyds.  It took a little searching to get my hands on a bottle, and I happened to get my hands on three different.  this was the favorite of the pack.  I just have trouble believing this is an American Pale Ale.  This is very hoppy with citrus hints and an almost belgian undertone.  If I was only rating APA this would be a 5.0.  Well done, now I know the style has promise.

On tap at Landmark in Milwaukee WI.  Pours golden amber with off-white head.  Aroma is of a strong caramel malt with some grassy/hoppiness.  Very smooth on the palate and very developed in the flavor, which follows the aroma splendidly.  This was my first offering from this brewery that I have heard a lot about and they did not disappoint.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2007 What Amazes me about this beer is the aroma ¬ñ Being a home brewer I get to know the smell of brewing very well. The mash and the boil and the addition of hops. Smells great!

This beer captures all of that and retains it in the beer. This beer is unlike any beer in the world!!
A nice grainy flavor and aroma. Nice hoppy flavor
This is the best 6% session beer in the world

Also considering Three Floyds Ridiculously High prices on some of the other beers, It¬ís also a tremendous value

Great on tap also

Thanks Dough77.  Pours a medium gold/copper color with a very small head and just a litle bit of lacing.  ARoma is slightly grassy with hints of citrus (maybe grapefruit).  Flavor is very similar, citrusy with strong grassy/hoppy hints to it.  This is probably the best APA that I¬íve ever had (IMO).  It¬ís very smooth and easy to drink as well!  Another great beer by 3F
Bottle pours caramel w/ virtually no head.  Big, caramel flavor w/ traditional FFF hop bite.  Another nice brew from these guys.

Bottle from Ray. Caramel colored body with a lasting thin head. Nose is very clean and very hoppy. Taste-low-medium sweet, medium bitterness, grass PNW hops, orange zest, light caramel, sweet malts. Good stuff. A very well done APA.

Bottle.  Pours a light copper hue that is perfeclty clear with a carbonted off-white head that leaves good lacing and a thin head througout the drinking.  Hoppy scent with an overriding orange citrus smell that is followed up in the flavor.  Refreshing, not overly bitter but the hops shine and citrus makes the most bold appearance and lingers in the mouth of this beer which gently tingles the mouth with a crisp carbonation.  A very drinkable and flavorful pale ale.

Pours a rich copper color with about a half inch of white head that seems to linger around for a while. Aroma hits you in the face with hops, citrus and a sweet malt as well.  Flavor is very hoppy. Also the citrus shows up along with some caramel malts.  Has a nice bitterness to it thoguh not overpowering. The mouth is nice for a pale ale with a bitter finish. One of my favorite Pale Ales.
Nice amber color.  very hoppy aroma and taste to back it up.  Still very hoppy, tastes more like an IPA than an american pale.  Well worthy of its ranking
Poured a brownish orange with a small tan head that faded quickly into nice lacing. Aroma was very hoppy and citrusy. Flavor was a good bitter that lasted all the way down but was not overpowering.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2007 I am not a huge fun of the IPA, but this one is very good.  Starts with a very citrusy aroma, and finishes with a sweet yet bitter taste.  It¬ís a mild IPA which falls into exactly what I Like.

12 oz Bottle  Pours a hazy amber with an off white head.  Head has good lacing.  Aroma has a good mix.  I pick up lemon citrus and a good prsence of what may be carmel or molasses malts.  aste is excellent a clean well carbonated beer wit great flavors.  The mix is perfect.  Has a good bitter finish with a nice duration.  This is one awesome pale ale.  I would drink all of these I can get my hands on.  If I see it, I am buying it.

Pours a copper color with thin tan head that needs some help getting started. Nose is nice and hoppy very floral and sweet maybe a little grassy. Flavor is predominantly bitter with some nice toasty notes thrown in there. Finish is dry, crisp and bitter. Nice nice nice!

The alpha king has a clear reddish yellow color with a quickly fading head. Decent smell of grapefruit, citrusy hops. Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel. A good taste is of slightly bittersweet caramel malts followed by a floral hop taste to finish.
Not really what i was expecting here. Seems to be "only" a better than average pale ale.
A tasty brew nevertheless.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2006 Ok here¬ís a proper re-rate, I¬íve got a bottle to myself thanks to Blankboy.  Very deep dark brown orange, small white head.  What a colour.  Lots of hops, somewhat resiny, but more malt like in aroma.  Taste is excellent:  Sure lots of hops, but lots of bread like malt too.  Just about the best balanced and best example of and APA I¬íve ever had.  My rating holds, awesome stuff.

Sample.  Tons of malt and hops in aroma.  Golden orange, small white head, hazy.  More malt than hops in taste - incredibly balanced.  Some fruit hints as well, but this one is all malt, which is nice, as I was expecting a hop monster.  The fact that is 6% means I could drink this all night - what a session ale.

Alpha King pours to a beautiful, bright, deep orange color with a rocky white head, and a lively carbonation. The nose is just bursting with waves of fresh, citrus hop aromas. Strong aromas of grapefruit and lemon flood the nose. The palate is a solid base of pale and caramel malts and touches of estery fruit. You really need some good malt character in a beer this hoppy, and I like the fact that this beer has enough malt to stand up to the huge hop character. This beer reminds me much of Victory¬ís Hop Devil in that regard. The finish explodes into a long, dry, citrus hop bitterness that jack hammers the taste buds and peels the skin off your throat. 

Wow. This is one bracing, hoppy beer, in flavor and aroma, and bitterness. The bitterness is a touch harsh, but not a problem for a hop head. This beer is not for the timid, you have to really enjoy hop character and bitterness to enjoy this beer. A hop monster like this, goes so well with hot and spicy cuisine. I would match this beer with nuclear hot Buffalo wings, Thai or Indian curries, or Mexican dishes

Lovely deep amber with a solid white head.  Enticing floral/piney/spicy aroma. Flavor is slightly on the bitter side, but nice.  Personally, I prefer the balance of the 90-minute, but I¬íd be a happy man drinking one of these.

Pours a nice hazy deep orange amber color with a small amount of white thin head.  Aroma is very citrusy, large grapefruit and orange notes.  Flavor is delicious: lemon grapefruit apple with some piney hop bitter notes.  Overall, an excellent apa.

From bottle.  Pours a deep orange with nice white head, good lacing.  Wonderful aroma of orange and other citrus with just a little grass.  Flavor follows the nose with a perfect bitter finish.  This is my everyday drinker.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2006 Bottle. Wow. Pours deep red with a creamy off-white head. Immediately as it¬ís poured, hops aroma hits me. Spicy, floral/piney, and especially hoppy aroma is refreshing... Maybe hints of apple. Spicy flavor fills mouth with bitter hops and notes of pine. Nice bitter finish lingers. Alcohol is subdued but noticable. Malt characteristics barely noticable but present. Finishes very bitter but balanced by sweet malt presence. Extensive lacing through whole beer as head diminishes slowly. Very lightly carbonated. Excellent and refreshing beer. Light moutfeel but not watery.

This beer pours a nice dark amber, with a nice white lace that sticks to the side of the glass. The smell is citrus, hops, and lemons and flavored with a sweetness of honey and the faintest hint of vanilla. The taste is great, it has a nice bitter kick from the hops as well as some great lemon flavor that is brought out by the honey. The mouthfeel on the palate is very clean. Great beer overall glad I was able to get my hands on this beer, I will def go back to it again.

"Wow this was like chewing a pine cone. Pour a hazy copper color with average head that left lacing. Smelled of pine and floral. Tasted of pine and lots of it overwellming. Not a huge fan of this one"
Bottle.  Pours with little head.  A little bitter with a light body and minimal aftertaste
user_location: People¬ís Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: great beer, deep amber pour, small almost nonexistent head.  grassy citrus aromas.  extended hoppy finish- couldve used a bit more hops on the nose i must try theyre IPA.  my batch was somewhat undercarbanated

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2007 bottle - Hoppy aroma, medium head with a bit of lace.  The flavor has a bit of sweetness initially and plenty of hops with a hint of citrus.  It¬ís medium bodied with a finish that is hoppy as expected (figured out that the hops is the main draw here yet?), but given that it¬ís also pretty smooth.  This is an excellent pale ale with a nice balance.  

edit:  still great... I just noticed ratebeer has this one as an IPA though.  That¬ís odd given that the brewer has always said it¬ís an APA.

this one tonight wasn¬ít quite as balanced as previous, but still excellent! Nice head subsides; a lot of good lace. Definite hop nose. Reddish amber. Mostly hop flavor giving way to lingering sweetness with memories of the hoppiness. this was from a bottle at Bodega downtown La Crosse where they also occasionally have it on draft too.

The nose is greeted with a very citrusy aroma.  The color is a cloudy orange and the head is small and off-white.  At first there is a very slight caramel sweetness but the dominance of the hops cops through with a oragne rind flavor.  The finish is hoppy and dry.

(01.07.06) On tap at Firkin¬ís, Libertyville, IL. Clear dark amber ale having a large long-lasting head with good lacing. No discernable carbonation. Clean hop aroma. Medium bodied that starts with light malt sweetness and citrus (grapefruit)/hop flavors. Finishes with light hop bitterness.  Well-balanced and smooth. An excellent hoppy ale that went well with my hot Caribbean sandwich. A classic beer.  This gem has been on tap at Firkin¬ís for years and yet I never noticed it until now.  How sad.

Pale Ales have never been near my favorite types of beers, but Alpha King is definitely good.  VERY hoppy, with a strong malt backbone, AK is best (at least for me) paired with food to "wash it down", as I dislike the extremely hoppy aftertaste.  This is going against the grain of my Great Divide Titan IPA review, which was glowing, but I prefer the Titan due to it¬ís dryness.  There¬ís a sweetness in the background of AK that I can¬ít get over.  Still, Alpha King is outstanding, but I prefer other pale ales.

Poured a clear orange/amber color with a slight off-white head.  Strong floral, piney, hoppy aroma.  The flavor has all of that plus some.  Plenty of bready malts to keep the huge hop flavor in check.  Very smooth, easy drinking beer.

Beautiful looking beer that is clear deep amber with a medium off white creamy head, and lacing better thatn any APA I¬íve seen. Big hop aroma of pine and citrus so characteristic of Northwest hops. Mediu/full body with a rich malt feel that few APAs seem to achieve. Falvors of caramel and roasted grain take a back seat to the huge hop flavors, yet it doesn¬ít seem unbalanced. Lingering, refreshing and astringent bitter finish. I¬íve been trying to get my hands on some of this for a while, and I¬ím not disappointed. The best APA that I¬íve had, without question. Actually, I¬ím not convinced that tihis isn¬ít actually an IPA considering the hop presence. Classification aside, this is a great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 Pours dark amber with a fully receding beige head. Aroma of grapefruit and oranges. Taste is flowery fragrant hops and sweet citrus. Not as aggressive as I was expecting. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied and slightly resinous with moderate carbonation. Enjoyable hop bomb.
UPDATED: JAN 26, 2006 I love this beer.  Hoppy, fruity, and dark in color.  Could be my fave APA.

Poured a medium brownish color with lots of head that slowly faded away.  Extremely hoppy with a fruity smell.  Has a very complex flavor that transforms on the tongue from a grapefruit start to a woody finish.  Extremely enjoyable and a great value.

This is truly a stand-out APA--up there with Anchor Liberty APA and Stoudt¬ís APA.  Medium bronze body with a hearty head and the wonderfully luscious floral hop aroma (Williamette & Cascade??) wafting easily from the glass and fending off the smoky bar atmosphere.  Refreshing Cascade/Williamette hop flavor that strikes just the right malt balance and mouthfeel.  Top notch.

I love this beer.  It is bitter the way I like it while not overpowering with hops.  The aroma is a little sweet with a good fruitiness.  Apperance as good as any other pale ale, not anything special but nothing lacking.  Very very smooth with a very nice aftertaste.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2006 Thanks Sliffy for two bottle of this one.  This is a very good IPA.  I feel like the reason it is so highly rated is because it is considered an APA.  Compared to other APAs this is extremely bold.  As an IPA, it¬ís good, but not as outstanding.  It reminds me of 60 min, SN Celebration and Harpoon IPA; all good beers.  On the the notes:  Smells like juicy grapefruit and pine needles.  Flavor is surprisingly malty at first, with a good sweetness coming from the fruity hips.  Powerful bitterness on the roof of the mouth in the finish.  Very well balanced.  A very good everyday beer.

One finger buttermilk/off white head with moderate carbonation, earthy straw color.

Nose primarily citrus (lemon) and yeastiness, with the hops surprisingly subdued.

Fresh, carbonated presence on the tongue with citrus and malt up front, hops bringing up the rear with residual bitterness in the aftertaste.  Surprisingly hoppy considering the lack of same in the aroma.  Pretty strong hop taste, probably edging closer to an IPA.  Good all around balance.

Overall, an excellent American pale.  A good medium choice between the weaker hops of a typical APA and the overwhelming (to some) hop bitterness of an IPA, making an ideal session beer.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2006  A good robust aroma of hops introduces this beer.  The red oxide colored solution sits under a thick off-white head.  This beer tingles the tongue as it enters the mouth.  The taste is a full-bodied one offering the strong presence of hops intermingled with mild hints of yeast and citrus.  There is a gentle sweetness that covers the bitterness as this beer pursues a path over the palate. (Try this beer from a cask--it is interesting to taste the transformation.)

Pours a dark amber with a medium sized head. There is a lot of nice lacing. Aroma is of hops and citrus with some grapefruit. Flavor is very complex for this style. there is a lot of hop bitterness mixed with some sweetness from fruits. The finish is very smooth. My favorite APA.

12 oz. bottle thanks to afterexile.  Deep amber pour with a decent head.  Aromas of fruit cocktail with extra citrus.  Flavors of grapefruit and more hoppy citrus.  Vanilla in the finish.  Very good APA.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Very nice crisp taste with a citrusy, hoppy flavor.  Excellent for a relatively easy to find pale ale (at least in Chicago).
wow this beer is awesome.......without a doubt this beer produced the best tasting burps that i have ever had......
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2006 Pours with a small off-white head with a little lacing on a dark orange body. Strong hoppy aroma with citric hops dominating. Good sweet-bitter hoppy flavor on a dry thick body.
Creamy white head on a deep orange colored body. Aroma of grapefruit. Flavor is of semi-sweet grapefruit.
Beautiful pour, strong aroma. Sweet and citrus, very full of flavor with prominent finish. Overall, very well done.
A very hoppy and biiter beer.  A liitle bit too much for my taste, but overall a decent beer.
Bottle.  Floral scents on the nose.  Poured copper with a very nice puffy white head.  Not expecting that level of hops in a APA, but more in a IPA.  A very hoppy IPA at that.
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Had during a beer tasting party.  Poured copper and had aroma of ornage peel.  Bitter finish which I ¬ím starting to aquire over time.

Copper pour with signifcant head. Aroma is hop-heavy of pine and citrus with a faint breadiness. Flavor is something of a surprise at first with a malt smoothness that recedes before an agressive wave of hops that finish the taste out with a distinct dry character. A very good full-bodied APA.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2006 Dark amber pour, medium head that lingers for a while. I love the finish on this one. After the aroma you expect a big hop flavor, but it isn¬ít there initially, it builds in your mouth moments after the sip. A little doubt, before the reward. One of my favorite Pale Ales for sure.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2007 Deep copper color and nice head. Strong citrus hop aroma. Starts with sweet hops and malt, and has a medium/strong bitter finish. Perfect balance. A very well crafted APA, a top 5 american version in my book, and a regular in my beer cellar.

This beer is actually called beer? It does not even taste much like beer. I heard of how good this company is, and so I tried this beer. I think this is the worst beer I ever had. I am so disappointed. I hope that if I try this company again, I will be happy. But with this, I think it is the worst I ever had. I was at Beck¬ís Brewery in Bremen, and their bad beer was even better than this. This is a nasty grapefruit drink, and not beer. I wish I could have a refund so I could try one of their other beers.
Bottle: An amber pour with a nice head, lasted for a while on my 2nd bottle.  i think I may have mispoured the first.  Extremely hoppy... a savoured flavour.  A top 3 APA I¬íve had, if not THE best.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry -- courtesy of Dave B. Pours a clear bubbly amber with an average size lasting white head. Big aroma of fresh citrus hops -- grapefruit galore! -- with a touch of malt. Smells awesome. Flavour is delicious, again all citrus hops, but so well balanced with some malt that it goes down really easy. A very hoppy APA and a classic -- one of the world¬ís best.

Bottle (12oz).  Share with blankboy and Dave B, courtesy of Dave B.  Poured clear oily amber with a smallish lasting beige head.  Aroma of rich resiny/citrusy hops backed with woody roast malt.  Taste is strongly of hops - rich, resiny, but above all else grapefruit - there¬ís a little malt struggling to be noticed, but it goes down for the count quickly - long, long bitter linger, but it¬ís great.  Full body for the style - I couldn¬ít drink much of this because I¬ím not a hop-head, but a superb brew.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2008 Draught at Old Capitol Brew Works and Public House in Iowa City, IA. Turbid orange-red hue with foamy white head. Big tantilizing flowery hop aroma which comes out again in the flavor. The hop flavor is well balanced with the dry malty undertones. Slips smoothly along the palate. This is good.

Bottle:
Outstanding!  Excellent balance of hops along with some citrus, malt, smoke, mountainous, falvors and aromas.

Pours a beautiful burnished bronze with a thin head.  Fresh grassy hop aroma, big round complex hop flavors balanced with some fruity--pineapple, candied orange rind--malt sweetness, then more hops on the finish.  This is my kind of IPA, dee-lish-us.

Poured an amber brown with two fingers of head that did not have very good retention.  The aroma is of citrus and hops.  The taste begins with sweet malts and then transitions into a bitter grapefruit hop flavor.  This is a very well balanced beer.

12z bottle.  Amber hue with an orange glow around the perimeter of the glass.  Sweet and fruity in the nose.  Call me crazy but all I could think of was a lemon danish.  Good oily hopness also aromatically.  And a slight malt roast.  Sweet and tart, and full and spicy, piney in the mouth.  Resinous and bitter.  Delicious and piney, initially in the mouth.  Then sweet hops and the malts come through.  Finally, bitter and dry.  This is a truly great beer.  Perfect example!

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2005 Top 10 beer.  Freakin delicious.  Smels like citrus hop pineapple zing.  Tastes like a hop explosion - I want to say bubble gum because I wish I could chew and eat it.  It¬ís savorlicious.  the aftertaste can be a bit overpowering, the only flaw in an otherwise, perfect as can be in this world, extraordinary pale ale.

Pours a clear amber, with a decent head. Fresh hops and citrus in the aroma. Aroma just keeps getting better with each sip. Flavor starts out a bit sweet and malty, and finishes tart and bitter. Awesome APA.
