On tap at the Irish Bistro - Chicago.  I know -  Irish Bistro, it¬ís an oxymoron, but the food is quite good and they have a good beer selection for a restaurant.  Anyways, what else needs to be said about what is probably the best balanced APA in the world.  This stuff rocks!

Caramel and hops greet the nose, citrus and a little pine. Why are IPA makers so fond of caramel. If you like bitter, you like bitter, why all the sweetness?
Anyway, full, bitter flavor of hops and malt finishing bittersweet. A good IPA and one that I enjoy from time to time, and would more often except that it¬ís generaly a dollar or two more expensive than some other equally fine and even superior IPA¬ís.
Recommended.

If I may say it, meh.  Exceptionally made, fresh, strong, robust, intense, etc, etc, etc.  But I simply didn¬ít care for it.  Somewhat like escargot, you know it¬ís supposed to be awesome, but you don¬ít like it as much as you should.  I can appreciate the quality and would not shy from drinking this again, but...meh.

09-Nov-04 (12 oz bottles: Obtained in trade with marinaro500, thanks Joe!) A very flavor packed pale ale, quite malty, moderately sweet, with clear grapefruit hoppiness balancing the beer, or perhaps overbalancing it.  While I¬ím enjoying this beer tremendously, it does seem overpowered by the grapefruit flavor, especially considering this is supposed to be an American pale ale.  Solid mouthfeel, medium body, clean finish.  Malty, but strong grapefruit aroma.  Dark amber in color, fairly cloudy.  Hardly any head, but the resulting sheen during the pour is off-white in color. (8, 4, 7, 4, 15, total: 3.8)01-Nov-05 Since I received two bottles of this beer in trade, I thought I see what the second bottle would be like after one year of aging.  Naturally, I expected the hops would drop off, leaving a really malty pale ale, which sounded pretty yummy to me.  But no, the grapefruity hops is still the dominant force, lending solid bitterness from start to finish.  There¬ís also a bit of tea in the flavor.  The nose is more balanced between a moderately earthy and toasty maltiness and grapefruity hops.  Medium bodied with a nice clean finish.  Dark amber in color and a bit hazy.  And this time, the off-white head rose to nearly an inch before gradually settling to a ring.  Pretty amazing how well the hops have held up on this beer.

Pours amber brown with a big white head.  Aroma is very hoppy (very piney with a touch of citrus), with just a bit of sweet maltiness in the background.  The hops take center stage here, with just a slight underlying malt sweetness.  I think this would benefit from a bigger toasty/caramel backbone, but it¬ís damn good nonetheless.  Bice and smooth on the palate.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2005 Bottle:  Thick pour; head didn¬ít seem to last very long; best part is the nice taste/aftertaste which wreaks of herbaceous delight.
CaskConditioned:  Of course the blossomy aroma and goodness is tripled on CC.  Choice.

Bottle: Poured a deep amber color ale with a small white foamy head with minimal retention. Aroma of strong bitter hops with some floral malt. Taste is mostly overpowered by hops with some caramel malt. I¬ím not sure I get what is suppose to be so great about this beer, seems to me that it lack balance. Will give this another try though.

excellent appearance and color.

Robust flavor, but not offensive.

very hoppy. Bitter and slightly sweet, but not fruity.
Medium amber orange hazy body with thin off-white head.  Aroma of hop, pine, citrus.  Flavor of sweet hop, citrus, malt.  Medium palate and smooth, medium hop finish.

Damn I was exepecting the earth to move...it didn¬ít. This is a great beer, well structured, good taste BUT I have to say I found the hop flavor to be too reminicent of dish soap. Don¬ít get me wrong...I LOVE hops but this seemed unbalanced to me and a little to sharp in taste. I guess for once I¬ím rowing against the tide of poularity this beer has. Oh well...to each their own.

pours dark orange with a foamy white head.  has a nice citrusy aroma that¬ís not too overpowering. Wasn¬ít too hoppy for me like some other pale ales.not too heavy with a bitter finish.I¬íd buy it again for sure.

bottle thanks to duand for this one. pours a combination of red and orange with a decent fluffy white head that leaves lots of lacing. aroma of hops light citrus notes and malt which almost seems to take on a roasted charecter taste is hops orange peel grape fruit has a smooth and lightly bitter mouthfeel. very good beer.

Bottled. Very aromatic, with a citrusy, floral bouquet. Pours a deep, hazy amber with a light tan, fluffy head, leaving lots of lacing inside the glass. The flavor is very well balanced, the malty notes complemented rather than overwhelmed by the hops. The finish is hoppy, but not overly bitter. A truly great American Pale Ale from a top-notch brewer.

Bottle with cousin Bryan.  Thanks bud. A well balanced, full blooded pale ale.  Easily one of my favorite styles and my favorite brew in that style.  Not so hoppy that it gives you that sour feeling like most other pale ales.

aroma of grapes and oranges with wheat undertones.  appearance: slightly hazy clear amber color with small head. Flavor is quite complex with lots of orange rind bitterness, ending slightly sweet but hoppy.  smooth and a little tangy.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2007 This is really unfortunate. The bottle was bad. Full of brown floaties. It looked like it came out of a garbage disposal. I have to murder this on the ratings until I get a decent bottle. 

Rerate. Extremly fresh. Very hoppy. Decent APA but over rated.

Bottle.  Pours a perfect amber, slightly hazed, and an adequate small head.  Aroma is sweet and truly caramel, with fresh strong grapefruit hop nose. Smells like delicious bite size hop candy (if it existed).    Also sweet glazed doughnut in the aroma. Flavor is great light sweet with strong woody hop balance.  Excellent representation of the wonder that is the hop.  Just delicious.  Flavor lasts.  Highly drinkable.

Wonderful lively citrus and floral hops aroma.  Thick head.  Taste is top notch.  This is soooo good.  So smooth I could keep drinking these all night.  Even better as it warms.  Nice hoppy finish which sticks with you.  Thanks wawood for this special brew!

Poured an orange amber with a medium size off white lacing head.  Aroma is orange peel, pine and some grapefruit.  Flavor is orange with a nice hop and malt balance.  Had this right after Dreadnaught and it was very similar just slightly stepped down. But you can tell they are using the same ingredients.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2010 Pours dark amber with big frothy off-white head that is mostly lasting. Nice lacing. Aroma is very strong, pine and grapefruit. Flavor is much more mellow than aroma would lead you to believe. Fairly balanced between the malt and the hops, with a slight edge to the hops. Medium body. Finish is somewhat short, but a little hoppy bite lingers for a while on the tongue.

Good pine and citrus aroma that stands out . Copper color body with white head. Mild sweet malts trying to hold back the citrus hops. Dry grapefruit flavor, a joy to have. Man I have a great wife to get me these beers.
floral aromatics, dark copper coloring.  smooth hop flavor that lasts until way back in the throat.    hops become more pronounced as the ber arms
thanks to heemer for this one.  pours a dark amber. good hops aroma and taste to match with a slight bitter finish. very malty......excellent pale ale
Nice amber color, deeper than some APAs, very citrusy hop bouquet, nice bitterness and hop flavor as well. Maltier than many pales as well. Slightly overrated, but nice ale nonetheless.

Reddish-brown,small off white head. Smells of hops and flowers. Lgihter than expected with a watery body and medium carbonation. It finishes bitter with a hopsy tone. The hops are crisp at the begining then muted by a sweetness. Very good but not great.

Citrusy hop aroma, but it is muted. Copper/tea colored with a finger thick white head. very quaffable. Nothing revolutionary here just a good malt base followed by ample hopping that leaves a mildly sweet malty beer that finishes citrusy and grapefruit bitter. Very solid.

Draft at Rich O¬ís.  Pours a reddish-orange tint with a tight white head. Initial taste is a little sweet, but the hops drown that out in a hurry with just the right amount of bitterness. This beer makes you want to take another look at other APAs, but is one of the best out there period.

I tried this beer after reading the posts here.  I¬íd seen it before but stayed away because of the cheesy graphics on the label.  I¬íll try not to judge a beer by its label in the future.  This is great beer in a style I like.  Hoppy, but with enough balance.  I just need to take enough starch blockers.  This beer was a real treat.  If you like Northwest Pale Ales or IPA¬ís give it a try.  Can¬ít believe It comes from so close to home.  I¬ím definately doin¬í the brewery tour.

Bottle. Small ivory head that mostly diminished, fine-medium bubbles, fair lacing, carbonated, transparent and an orange hue. Malty, hoppy, caramel, sweet, and fruity aroma. Flavor was malty, caramel, hoppy, and somewhat sweet tasting. Very tingly, hoppy mouthfeel. Medium body.

Pour is hazy bright amber with a thin dense tan head...smell is rich and sweet with citrus all over it...some mild vanilla toffee too...taste is sweet and rich with toffee and citrus sweetness followed by a mild satisfying bitterness...

Ahh, I¬íve been drinking far too long to have overlooked this for some time. I couldn¬ít get it in Arizona but since I¬ím back in the 330 it¬ís been a watershed. Only with beer instead of water. You might say it¬ís been a beershed.

12 oz bottle, thanks Sammy.  Deep hazy ruby-copper beer with a thin yellow head.  Beautiful citrus nose,  grapefruit, pine, caramel, light plummy fruit as well.  Flavour is absolutely beautiful, bready caramel malts with a huge citrus/pine hop aroma, brown sugar, biscuit malt and a touch of plummy special B goodness.  Low to moderate bitterness but fantastic aroma.  World-class.
Last time I was in Indiana, no one knew about Three Floyds! Hard to believe. Rich in hops. Deep taste. Another beer I don¬ít understand why we can¬ít get in Michigan.

Bottle. Deep golden amber color with offwhite head. Strong bitter/piney hop aroma with some slight floral and citrus hops. Flavor focuses on the bitter hops-- piney, astringent-- but with nice lingering notes of grapefruit citrus and medium malt sweetness, certainly enhanced as the beer loosens up. Really good stuff.

Bottle.  Pours a translucent brown with a reddish tint around the edges and a good sized, foamy head.  Aroma is a beautiful blast of piney hops and grapefruit citrus with a hint of malt peeking through.  The flavor... if you drink it cold your palate is positively mugged by the intensely dry, piney hops.  Let it warm a bit and the hops still slap your tongue around but the sweet malt is much more noticeable and balances the hops nicely.  The finish is, of course, dry and bitter but again well tempered by the malt.  I enjoyed it more as it warmed but either way it¬ís a wonderfully complex brew that begs further sampling.  My compliments to all the Floyds!

Bottle from Ughsmash and from SecretSanta.  Now, I must say that normally, I¬ím not a fan of APAs.  Normally, I find them bland and uninspired ... a boring cousin to the IPA.  Maybe I was just sampling the wrong ones.  Or maybe these Three Floyd guys know what they¬íre doing.  Great aroma of piney and grassy hops, along with honey, grapefruit, orange and sweet malts.  As it warms, the aroma gets a little lighter.  Drink this out of the fridge, and get ready for an assault on your palate.  Tons of dry hoppy goodness!  However, it goes through a wonderful transition somewhere around mid bottle.  The hops stick around, but the latecoming grapefruit, sweet citrus, honey and caramel make for a great party.  The finish is bitter and dry, but not too much so.  Damn you Three Floyds!!  Why can¬ít you be available in New England??

On tap at the Blind Pig, Champaign, IL. Perhaps its unfair of me to rate this given I was sampling the Dreadnaught next to it. But I¬íve had this enough in the bottle and on tap, and my reactions have been fairly consistent. The beer¬ís appearance is much darker than I have come to expect from a pale ale or ipa, almost scotch ale in colour. Notes of caramel and vanilla on the nose and palate blended in with citrus from the profusion of hops. I think part of my qualm with this beer is calling it a pale ale when its quite a bit more hoppy than what some brewers label their ipa. But coming off my soapbox, this is good stuff, not exceptionally good as one might be led to believe by its 99 point score.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2005 Pours a dark amber color with a thick 1.5 inch head with a lot of good lacing.

Great grapefruit and hop smell to it. 

Fruity citrus and hop flavor with just the right amount of malt. This is one damn good beer.

Wish that this was sold this in my area. I had to order it from John¬ís Grocery In Iowa City. I have a feeling that I will be ordering more of this in the future. The more I sip it, the better it gets. Wish I could get other Three Floyds brews after this one.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Clear, bright, orangish ruby red with a huge, white, coarse head; significant lacing all the way down.  Smells of light toffee, orange, and pine; heavy note of sugary fruit.  Flavor is big: Spicy with light alcohol; not much up front; way too much in the hops department; extremely strong hops taste; burnt.  A bit watery, which is surprising.  Lovely aroma and appearance, but too much hops!!

Pours a bubbly, very hazey orange color.  Small white head that disappates quickly.  I suspect this is very hoppy right away.  Aroma has hints of bread, yeast and fruit.  Taste is just out of this world, has a grapefruit front end with a moderate hop kick in the finish.  I would drink this anytime.  Had to travel eighty miles to get it though.  Such is life.....  Hopheads will love this APA.
Looks like a stronger beer from apperance when poured.  Just a perfect blend of flavors.  Very drinkable with the grapefruit but just bitter enough.

Very piney, very citrusy... very stong... hops stand out and smack you in the face, just not double IPA calibre, if you¬íre into that.  An easy drinking and well rounded APA for sure... better than most.. hopheads rejoice.

6 pack found in East Greenwich, Rhode Island mysteriously...Aroma is very piney and citrusy.  Mild roasted caramel notes as well.  Refreshing aroma.  Transparent amber color with a frothy off-white/yellowish head.  Start is mildly watery, turning quite bitter and hopped in the middle.  Aggressively hopped, with not much in the way of malts in the middle to balance the hops.  A bit burnt.  Finishes dry, spicy and hopped with grapefruits.  This is nice.

Another gem from the Three Floyds Brewing Company.  Pours an amber copperish color with a creamy white tannish head.  Smells of pines,hops and various citruses.  Taste is very citrusy yet not quite an IPA.  Probably my favorite every day beer.  An excellent choice.
Delightful first sip that screams unusual quality! Sly and seductive hops had me smitten by glass end.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2008 Bottle sampled pours amber, with a medium beige head, with an aroma of citrus and hops an excellent combination, the taste very smooth fruity & malt flavor, wow this is good, excellent body,and finishes with a piney bitterness.

12oz - A bright hoppy aroma for a pale ale, that¬ís for sure.  There is also some malt and a touch of citrus.  Pours a clear amber with no carbonation, head, or lacing.  Flavor is a delicious blend of hops and malts.  Carmel and citrus that¬ís getting there butt kicked by Mr. Hop.  Smooth and blanced, this is a great drinking beer.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 Bottle. When this is fresh, it is full of citrus hops and bitterness with a delicate malt back bone. Less than fresh, the malts begin to dominate and it¬ís not near as satisfying. Unfortunately, 3F doesn¬ít date its bottles. This rating is for a fresh bottle. Medium amber body with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of grapefruit, orange peel, pine and resin. Some toasted grain in the background. The flavor is moderately to heavily bitter, lightly to moderately sweet and moderately acidic. The finish is bitter and dry and long lasting. There is just enough of a hint of sweet malts throughout to balance the big hop flavor. Medium body with a watery texture and lively carbonation. Outstanding and a favorite.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2005 12 oz bottle-pours a nice creamy tan head.  Clear gold-amber color.  Aroma-lots of citrus&hops.  Flavor is lots of citrus-bitter grapefruit (from the hops).  Taste finishes with the bitter grapefruit lightly, and without a bite.  A very good, occasional beer.

Undoubtedly the best IPA I¬íve ever enjoyed.

Very Citrus/fruity but not overpowering.  Extremely hoppy; savory aftertaste; very flavorful but drinkable.
On tap at Cap Ale House.  Great amber color, very smooth.  Taste very much like an IPA, great hoppiness and nice toasted malt flavor.
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2005 Freebee 12oz from Ohiodad. The best pale ale I¬íve ever had, mostly because it tasts like a good IPA. Very smooth, bitter pale ale.

Dark orange-amber color.  White-cream head which didn¬ít last.  Good lace though.  This is the third Three Floyds brew I¬íve had.  The first was Dark Lord (thanks Chuck), the second was Dreadnaught (thanks Grapes and Grain, Mequon, WI).  Both were excellent so I didn¬ít hesitate to pick up a 6 pack of alpha king for 6.99 (again at Grapes and Grain).  I¬íve drank three before rating it.  Not counting free beers I¬íve been given to rate (from Chuck, Blake and Matt) this is the best beer for the price I¬íve ever bought.  I love me the bitter bitch goddes pale ale.  Citrus hops.  This pale ale gives makes most IPA¬ís or imperial IPA¬ís it¬ís bitch.  I¬íve been drinking all night so I¬ím starting to get creative (who was that writer that would drink for inspiration?).  Anyhow, I think I¬ím rambling so I¬ím out.  Check the ratings.
I enjoyed the welcome mat of a citrus hop aroma the Alpha King rolled out me when I popped the cap.    Orange bodied beer with right amounts of hop and malt balanced this APA.

In the bottle at the 2005 Bad-burek party. Dark amber with an off-white head. Aroma is of a little man jumping out of the bottle to rake your olfactory senses with hop vines. This is a veritable nasal lavage of big dog power hops. Flavor matches the smell. I¬ím sure it has a malt backbone, but who cares? I¬ím in absolute palate fatigue after the second swill. My carnal hophead desires are satiated.

A damn fine brew. Poured a beautiful translucent copper with a very thin layer of white head. Minimal carbonation. Smells of strong grapefruit and piney hops. Taste is a good mix of hops and some sweet carmel malts, but the hops defintely win the battle. This beer is all about huge hops, but the bitterness seemed subdued, perhaps by the malts. This makes for an interesting APA. A permanent member of my fridge.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2006 Bottle.  Smells of pine, floral hops, and citrus.  Taste mimics the aroma .  Very intense hop flavor throughout.  No question that what little the caramel malt does it¬ís destroyed by the over the top amount of hops in this one.  More hop taste in this APA then some IPA¬ís I¬íve head.  With that said I wish for a little more malt/hop balance in an APA.  My first from 3F.

Tap. Beautiful color. Aroma was of citrus and honey suckle flowers. Nice head without a ton of lacing. Good hoppy crisp refreshing flavor. Definitly some notes of alcohol. Fairly strong malt covered up nicely by the refreshing hop. Dry and bitter after palate.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2005 Dark amber color, smooth pour with long-lasting head.  A bit thicker than I expected from a pale ale, but it had the extreme hoppy flavor I had heard about.  Excellent, complex flavor.  Bottle.  [upon a second tasting in Chicago on 7/30/05 I upped my rating a tad -- what an amazing pale ale!]

Bottled.  Orange-copper coloring - dark for a pale ale - with white head that laces moderately onto the glass.  Aroma is very hoppy, and the flavor is mostly bitter but with some malt put in to make it interesting.  Finish is dry and hoppy.  This is an excellent pale.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2005 Pours a fairly dark orangy copper for a PA with a white head that lingers a bit.  Aroma was packed with piney, citrussy, grassy american C hops.  Flavor is intensely but pleasantly bitter with excellent hop character but with sufficient caramely sweet malt backbone.  Some modest ester profile complements the flavor.  Slighty buscuity as well.  It is also quite full bodied and smooth.  I really think this beer should be classified as an IPA and pride and joy should be their american pale ale but that¬ís just me.  I could drink this regularly.  A really excellent beer from an excellent brewery.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2005 em, this is not an ipa?  i woner what their ipa tastes like then.  floral aroma w/ ¬íhint¬í (a big one) of hops.  very hoppy, but balanced by malt.  actually quite drinakable, quite impressive indeed.

I have had this beer for some time now.
It seems to have changed a bit over time.
When they were located in Hammond I used to get it on tap at a local pub. It was a yellow cloudy "cheap" beer. It had great aroma and citrus flavor.
Now it is cleaner with the same great aroma.

Complex aroma.  Floral, aromatic hops and a hint of red wine.  Amber with a large thick head that fades but not quickly.  Some malt in the flavor, but the dominant flavor is fruity hops.  About as good as a pale ale can get.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2011 This is the first beer I have managed to try from this brewer. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a bright bronze color with a medium sized tan head. The aroma is strong sweet hops - very fruity. The mouthfeel is rather thick and smooth. The flavor is strong fruity hops - almost a fruit cocktail element to it. Very sweet.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2005 pours an almmost off orange tan yellow color w/ a small white head that laced well but fell apart quickly.  Aroma was very good floral and citrus hops hints of some fruits probably apricot.  The palate is a bit bitter fairly carbonated and overly dry.  Flavor is a little over dry in the hop area w/ a decent bitter finish a touch piney w/ its big hop flavor there are hints of the fruitiness i smelled as well.  Overall an ok beer in my mind nothing more, I¬íd rather have robert the bruce anyday.
12 oz. Bottle:  Very large floral hop aroma, pine, and fruits.  Flavor is dominated by dry hops, and complimented nicely by sweet fruits.  Finishes long and dry.
I found this one incredibly over-rated...It had a nice head, but I didn¬ít think the hops were quite as strong as i was expecting.  I found the whole taste on this one incredibly average.

I little strong for my likings.  It pours with a decent head, especially for an ale.  The color is one one of those crayons in the box of 64 between orange and brown.  It¬ís got some fruit, to give it some much needed sweetness, but I find that the hops dry the beer out.
Bottle from eyedrinkale. Aroma is very hoppy. taste is smooth with a great hop finish, grows stronger as you near the end. great brew.

Bottled.  Pours a deep orange color with a rapidly dissipating, rocky, white head, which leaves a thin layer of lacing on the top.  The aroma is almost completely dominated by floral American hops.  The [possibly?] Centennial and/or Columbus hops give this beer a fantastic floral, citrus, apricot, and slight pine aroma.  There is a faint malt-caramel aroma present as well, but, don¬ít let me fool yah, this beer is all about the humulus!  The flavor is sweet up front.  Citrus-hop flavors are ascendant -- grapefruit with orange zest and maybe a little lemon.  The hops are supported with a strong troupe of malt character.  A touch of caramel, toasted, and maybe a little nutty flavors give great play with the hops.  Again, grapefruit is the dominant flavor.  The beer is fairly well balanced, and has average alcohol feel.  The brewer lists this is as a medium-bodied beer.  Which is probably correct, but relative to other PA¬ís, this is most definitely full-bodied.  The finish is quite bitter, but not overwhelmingly so.  The aftertaste is quick, dry, and bitter with a bit of grassiness (perhaps from some dry-hopping).  There are no perceptible flaws in this beer; as, the intense hopping simply won¬ít allow any, if they exist, to show through.  Overall, I thought this was an intensely flavored beer with incredible body, but was surprisingly drinkable.  The flavors and aroma are well organized.  I can see how it might be a little too intense, in flavor/bitterness/alcohol/body, to drink all night for some, but I still consider it a session.

Out of a bottle,  nice piney citrus aroma.  Dark amber color medium foamy white head that leaves thin layer on top.  Taste on the hoppy side but finishes fast and dry.  I liked the bitterness and crispness that accompanied this brew.

Amazing hops hit you right in the face.  They are very present and give off a very strong pine odor.  The nose is also very sweet.  Plesent boardering on obnoxious (almost soappy?).  The appearance is great.  Nice amber colour topped with a big fluffy head which is gone pretty quickly.  NIce lacing throughout the glass.  Great IPA like flavour that gives off a great malty yet very hoppy smoothness.  Not too bitter, no alchol apparent.  This one reminds me of a home brew I once made.
Great beer.
Great IPA.  This is my first Three Floyds beer.  Good hoppy aroma, great taste and after taste.  Balanced extremely well, couldn¬ít taste the alcohol.

Pours clear amber color, with thick white head.  Tangy hop smell with strong nutty maly undertones.  Sweet tangy hoppy taste with a slight nut taste to it, much like the smell.  Slightly bland aftertaste but smooth and damn good.

Poured a reddish-amber with about a 1" head that stayed quite well.  Aroma was of citrusy hops (lemon and grapefruit came to mind).  Beer was medium-bodied, and seemed to be highly carbonated (I think this was due to a very bad pour from the bartender).  The bitterness and the citrus flavors danced across the taste buds very well, with a light hoppy finish.
Well, my wireless connection died so I lost all my info I typed in.  Good, but not as good as gumballhead or dreadnaught.

12 oz bottle.  I think I¬ím the 500th rating for this...awesome.
Super hoppy aroma.  Deep amber pour.  Ridiculous piney taste.  Super hops, not overbearing hops, but I love hops kind of hoppiness.  Delicious.

Thanks igneous1 for hooking this one up!
Pours a dark orange body, almost a reddish colour. Head is a foamy white, and thick. Aromas are hops like crazy, pine, citrus, malt. taste is lots of hops, but not overpowering, subtle citrus and some mild malt that balances it out nicely. FInish is smooth, crisp, and the 6.5% is not noticable. I wish I could get more.

12 fl oz brown bottle, courtesy of heemer77. Brassy orange pour, full head of cream white head. Resiny, raw hop aroma. Bitter hops coat the tounge, but there is some detectable malt sweetness. Lingering hop finish.

Solid balanced taste with more of a bitter finish than most APAs - closer to a IPA I think. Hoppy throughout.  Highest rated APA? I¬íd suggest Great Lakes Burning River or Sierra Nevada Pale or their Harvest Ale.

Bottle poured the hazy color of a new, copper penny with a frothy, ecru head that left some nice lacing. Strong aromas in both malt and hops; citrus up front with a caramel background. Good hop-bitterness in the flavor, albeit one-dimensional, with a bitter finish and dry texture. 
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Forest, IL<font size=-1>
Copper/amber color, off white head. Hoppy aroma with grapefruit. Hoppy flavor, with some orange. Strong hoppy bitterness in the finish.

Appearance: Deep hazy copper with a creamy dense tan head. Lacy.

Smell: Citrusy hops, floral and sweet

Taste: Bitter and tart citrus. Smooth lightly sweet malt. Floral.

Mouth: Long hoppy finish, medium bodied.

Drink: Tasty and quite drinkable.

Overall: A bit unbalanced for a pale ale but it does have character. The malt profile could be more steadfast and while it is nicely hopped it doesn¬ít have much to complement it. All in all though a good brew.

I poured it in and witnessed a lot of carbonation but the foam was short lived. It has a very hoppy aroma of a coppery nature. It is very well rounded as far as taste-it leaves a bitter impression on my tongue and throat but relaxes my senses through its intermingling of hops and malts. This is definately what one wants from a bitter. I¬ím not sure the extra alcohol content is necessary to accentuate the taste though. But this is definately a top notch pale ale which I¬íd buy a six pack of anyday.  This is one of those beers that you know are good because you see how quickly it goes!

pours a slighly cloudy rust colored brown, with a creamy white head that fades down to a light layer of lacing.  aroma is very strong with floral hops and some citrus elements as well.  very strong hop flavor coming at the start, a smooth, slightly caramel backbone leads down to a huge hop tail with a nice amount of bitterness that gets your attention, but doesnt pucker your face shut, a very nice balance. the bitterness of the tail lingers for quite awhile. a nice amount of body for such a hoppy brew.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2005 Amber with and off white head. Fair retention. Minimal haze. I get some bold citrus (orange or tangerine) hops and rich breadyness for malt in the nose.
Very full flavor. Again citrus hops and robust breadiness from the malt. Maybe some caramel. Moderate body. Not a lot of ligering flavor.
Rerate 8/21/05.  I am now ratinge this based on Alpha King as an APA vice and IPA.  This is by far the best American Pale Ale on the market.
bottle. wow. dark amber color, nice creamy head. very smooth, nice hoppy flavor. great finish. wish i had more right now.

Aubernish amber with a medium white head, slightly rocky.  Crisp amarillo hop aroma with a malty sweet undertone.  Citrusy hop nose, becomes slightly sweet with malt flavors.  Dries out quckly to finish with a spritely hop crispness.  Very sessionable, even if a tad alcoholic.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2005 Pours a dark amber color.  Surprising for an APA.  Nice tan head hangs around a while and laces the glass.  Aroma is citrus and hops very nice aroma.  Carbonation is great in this for an APA.  The powerful hops overwhelm the alcohol in this.  It is bitter at the end and quite citrusy.  A refreshing brew that I truly enjoyed.  I can¬ít wait to drink the rest of the 6 pack!
Rerate - I let one warm up a little last night and as a result I¬ím upping the numbers a little bit.  Refrigeration masks many of the great characteristics of this brew.  This is top notch for an American Pale Ale!

dark amber color.  whif of pine in the aroma.  deliciously bitter.  fizzy palate, that kind of sticks in throat, but i like that.my notes say ¬ía nice, nice beer¬í, but i seem to say that a lot.  maybe i should have that printed on every page of my notebook to save time.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2005 Thanks to lamas for the bottle.  12 oz. bottle.  Pours a beautiful copper.  Head dissipates quickly, lots of lace.  Solid grapefruit/citrus aroma.  Perfect level of carbonation.  Hoppy flavor makes the slightly higher than usual ABV unnoticeable.  Nice, sharp, bitter finish...very refreshing.  The best APA I¬íve ever had?? I¬ím not sure - definitely near the top though.  I¬íd like to throw back a couple more of these.  Very tasty nonetheless.

Okay, not a big fan of pine, and this brew has lots of it.  I used to love Three Floyds¬í brews, but have noticed Dreadnaught now tastes like PineSol and I¬ím not into ingesting kitchen cleaner.  However, Alpha King is not as strong, so I can¬ít knock it too much.  Apparently, the recipe has changed or I¬ím missing something, because I¬ím not picking up on the citrus and malts that others have in their reviews.  Oh well...

Thanks, Egaj and Shag!

My goodness this is bitter-a different kind of bitter.  Maybe it¬ís been too long since my last strong apa/ipa.  Piney, citrusy, strong malts, very dry.   It made my little sister¬ís face squinch up in the cutest way.

More of an IPA than an APA I would have said, but what¬ís in a name? Big brassy copper colour. The usual US pine resin hoppy aroma. More of the same on the palate. Rather astringent mouthfeel. Pretty good. Bottled at the London Joet gathering, January 2005.
This beer had a dark orange appearance. The flavors are mainly grapefruit and orange. It had a good malt profile as well. The aftertaste is bitter. Overall its a very good pale ale.

pour a light copper color with off white head.  the aroma was of floral hops and grapefruit with definite sweetness.  the flavor was much of the same...strong the the spicey grapefruit hop flavor.  a very good pale ale.
Hoppy aroma and hoppy flavor.   Beautiful looking and easy to drink.  Strong amount of hops, though never overpowering.  Tasted similar to an IPA.

Aroma is dominated by hoppy smell - very citrus, very pleasant. The appearance is coppery with a definite haze. I¬íve even got some "chunks" in mine. The flavor is very nice: sweet, citrusy up front with a nice bitter finish - love those hops! The body is very nice, not too thick but definitely there. The carbonation is just right and the overall feel just leaves my mouth craving more. An excellent APA, one of my favorites.

Clear copper color with a ring of white lace. Excellent aroma of spicy and citrusy hops (Goldings and Cascade ?) with caramel. Excellent flavor of spicy and citrusy hops with caramel and a very long lasting bitter finish reminiscent of Cascade hops. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. I agree with dirtymike, it puts a lot IPAs to shame, excellent beer. Thanks to csbosox for sending this.

Amber in color with a medium off-white head. Aroma is of citrus,grapefruit,pine,orange and earthy hops. Flavor is moderately bitter, lingering from start to finish. Meaty body with a mild sweet caramel character that is balanced and covered up nicely by hops and bitterness. Agreat pale ale that puts alot of IPA¬ís to shame.

Fairly reddish for a pale ale.  Aroma of pine, wood and a little earthy.  Head is fairly thick and is around for the long haul.  Flavor starts with a definite twinge of alcohol, almost scotch-like, then pine flavor comes in that blends nicely into hops aftertaste.  Excellent.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Poured a medium amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of grapefruits, oranges and pine. Tastes of grapefruits, pine, and caramel. Nice bitter finish with a light sweet balance. Very good IPA, oh mean APA.

12 oz. bottle. Very good APA.Reminded me alot like an IPA, but there was some difference. Pours a bubbly, hazy, red/orange color with a thin white head. Good floral hoppy aroma. A lot of pine scents. Strong hoppy, refreshing flavor. Really a great cool, tasty beer.

So we pour it in a Pernod bottle and start for New Orleans past irridescent lakes and orange gas flares, and swamps and garbabe heaps, alligators crawling around on broken bottles, neon arabesques of motels, marooned pimps scream obscenities at passing cars from islands or rubbish...

Smells of lemon, grapefruit, and pine phenols.  Taste is strikingly citrus hop that slowly fades to a dull bitterness that restes on the sides and tip of the tongue.  The flavor is strong, with lots of citrus (lemon, grapefruit, orange), but the taste is a little one-dimensional.  I suppose I expected something more than this could have provided, and so it let me down.  Mouthfel is a little thin, but not overtly watery.

Copper colored and clear with a creamy thin tan head. Strong and hoppy aroma of pine, citrus, and caramel malt. One of the better ales I have ever smelled. Very delicate flavor of hops and malt that dances on the tongue and finishes clean and dry. One of the best APA¬ís I have ever had.
The way an IPA should be!  Upfront citrusy hop aroma, nice full cloudy color, a hop flavor that is to die for. Drink and enjoy!

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2006 Let me start by saying that I liked this beer but, because it is a Pale Ale, I found it very difficult to rate.  That said......   It pours a clear dark copper with a medium sized, rocky eggshell white head.  With my eyes closed, my nose told me I had just poured an IPA due to the bountiful floral, citrusy grapefruit & hoppy aroma.  Keeping my eyes closed, my tongue would have confirmed the nose¬ís conclusion that an IPA was escaping the glass.  Hop bitterness up front with citrus fruit, vanilla and malt sweetness not too far behind.  Finish was dry, bitter and refreshing.  Mouthfeel was - well, here¬ís where the problem of rating this beer became a challenge - mouthfeel was very thin for an IPA but appropriatly light for a PA.  All in all, almost everything about this beer screamed IPA and that¬ís great - for an IPA.  I love IPAs but I don¬ít always want one.  If I want a Pale Ale, I expect it to have the flavor & palate profiles of a PAle Ale - not of an IPA - and that¬ís where I think this beer falls short.  Don¬ít get me wrong - I like it and I¬íd gladly drink it again but I¬ím putting them on the IPA shelf because that¬ís what it is - a tasty Pale with an identity crisis.

A nice deep golden w/ a slight red tinge to the color. Strong floral hops aroma which actually has a lighter taste than you would expect. Somewhat bitter in the aftertaste that doesn¬ít disappear quickly.

Rich orange red color with a frothy off-white head.  Sweet smell of earthy hops; citrusy.  Flowery, citrus flavor with a finish I can¬ít quite put my finger on, but I know it¬ís dry and the hops linger for a while.  Only detraction comes from the somewhat thinner body.  At $6.99 two blocks away, this will definitely become a regular.

much thanks to growler for this bonus beer.the king pours a lovely translucent orange with a creamy white head that leaves wonderful webbing.this pale ale honestly smells alot like an i.p.a.citrus and pine dominate the smell.the taste had the citrus and pine in it as well.along with some ice tea,caramel malts,cream soda,and flowers.the mouthfeel was a little on the light side but not in a bad way.overall this is very drinkable,but its damn close to an i.p.a.

Wonderfully hoppy for an APA.  I¬íd say at 66 IBUs, more than DFH¬ís 60 Minute, Three Floyd¬ís might look into reclassifying this fellow.  Great hops, though.  Cascade stands out most substantially, giving it that grapefruity citrus-ness.
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2006 Hey, what can I say, its good stuff. Copper color. Small white head. Smells good. I could drink a lot of it. Lots of better beers out there, but this is a great pale ale.

Bottle.  Pour is a deep copper with thin light-tan head.  Aroma is strongly of caramel with a touch of hops.  Taste is nicely balanced.  Sweet malty start and a touch of bitter hops at the finish.  A good bit of caramel in the taste along with some warming alcohol.  Solid beer though nothing exceptional.  Based on other reviews maybe mine has aged??

It does bear quite a resemblance to an orange in aroma and taste, of course there is less sweetness and a sharp bitter finish.  This beer pours a lovely amber color with a thick head.  An extremely enjoyable Pale Ale without the malt heaviness of some.
Smells like a sweet ffesh orange.  A little cloudy.  Initial taste is sweet with a very citrus finish, like chewing on an orange peel.

Pours amber, with a white head.   Nice citrusy hop aroma.  Lots of hops in the flavor, more citrus, especially grapefruit, with some malt sweetness.  Finish is dry, long and bitter.   I¬ím not much of a hop head, but this was good.
Pours light brown with a small white head. Aroma is hops and malt blended nicely. Taste is similar to sierra nevada but better hoped. Alpha King has some earthy tones to it. Great stuff.

Abundant head with light carbonation.  Head lasts for a while frothy and rocky on top.  Color is a clear dark amber.  Juicy hops aroma.  Plenty of citrus and spruce.  An absolute joy to inhale.  Plentiful hops in the flavor.  More citrus and grapefruit.  Crisp and dry with plenty of bitterness.  Little malt for balance.  Finish is long and bitter.  A top quality pale ale with plenty of hops for the hop-heads out there.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005 Bought this when I turned 21 and wasn¬ít disappointed.  Like the other reviews have said, this is a very hoppy beer which was new to me.  Bitter flavor dominates this beer but it is suprisingly smooth as well.  Overall I was impressed.  Hopefully I can make it to their brewery sometime since I am in Indiana

12 oz bottle.  Orange color with an ever so slight haze and a fairly moderate off white head.  Has a wonderfully refreshing scent of mixed citrus fruits including, grapefruit, oranges and tangerines.  Strong bitter flavor up front from the agressive hopping that quickly disapates to a nice a dry crisp finish.  A great pale ale; one of my favorites.  Hops...it¬ís all about the hops......

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 Original Rating, February 23, 2005. Dark gold color with a thin head.  Apple and hoppy aroma.  Good crikey... I think they might have added some hops to this one.  Heavy hops and pine flavor with some more of that apple and citrus blend.  Good malt backup.  Damn fine tasty pale.

Re-rating, January 20, 2010: Copper color with a medium head.  Big orange and tangerine aroma.  Moderately bitter flavor.  Light grass, orange and caramel malts.  Really lovely.
Bottle @ Oliver Twist, StockholmExtremely hoppy aroma, what else to expect? Very hoppy taste without any hint of malt, what else to expect? Dry and long hoppy aftertaste, what else to expect?

Props to Duane. Poured amber, with a HUGE off white fluffy head. Wonderful aroma. I detect, something sweet, under the barrage of pine sap hops. Flavor is hops of course, but there is a small amount of malt sweetness to help balance this. I am NOT a hop head, but I enjoyed this.

Clear pale amber colour, thick firm white head. Soft but really strong juicy hop aroma of grapefruit and lemon. Loads of citric fruit in flavour with silky smooth malt profile. Fresh green hops in the long bitter aftertaste. Very good.

Deep hazed copper,  thin white creamy head.  Nose pumps out grapefruit, spruce, florals, sweet buttery toffee, and caramel.  My older bottle seems to be more balanced then past fresh bottles that typically were hop nation. Even so, flavor is still hops galore with a bitter-sweet rich malt backbone shining through nicely.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, smooth, creamy, bitter-sweet citric finish. One of the best APA¬ís in the world......
Nicely balanced, complex palate sweet, piney/resiny.  Dry pleasant finish with a medium bite.

Bottle. Dark amber color medium white head. Complex aroma of sweet malt and hops. Flavor was very good and finish was strong with small bite. Good beer to use as my 100 beer rated on this page. Great service.
Had on tap.  Orange in appearance.  Very hoppy flavor with a taste of orange.  My friends can¬ít handle IPAs, so I ended up drinking theirs as well.  Very good.

A clear copper colored brew with a creamy thick tan head. WOW, another wondeful hop explosion. Man, who doesn¬ít like the aroma of Cascade hops, it¬ís so refreshing!  Just as tasty as it smells. Has a nice malt flavor too, some crystal perhaps, it¬ís there but you have to find it. With several IPA¬ís I¬íve aquired in trade, you guys are turning me into a real hop head! No complaints, keep them coming!
Wow, what a well balanced beer! Nothing dominates over the other, malt, hops, great flavor, A-1 American beer, 3floyds should be proud! Balanced!

Very good pale ale. Pours amber with dense medium head. Aroma is of FRESH hops but just enough malt to balance. Flavor is hoppy with a smooth dry finish. My girlfriend had this beer shipped to me all the way from Chicago. Makes the beer even better. What a damn fine woman.

Poured light orange. Nice fine bubbled head that really lasts and gives great lacing. Orange color in a shaker glass. Perfect amount of citusy hop aroma. Supercarbonated. Nice slightly malty, citrusy flavor with a bitter punch at the end that is not overpowering and fades to a pleasant aftertaste. A pretty flawless pale ale, but on the flipside, no particularly interesting notes to give this one distinction. Nonetheless, this is one of the best american pale ales I have tried.
Bery nice amber hue.  Think white lace of a head.  Very hoppy armoma.  The taste  backs it up with the first sip.  The finish is crisp and dry leaving you thirsty for more.
Copper with a beige lasting head. Mild toffee, citrus and pine aroma. Sweet malts balanced with orange, grapefruit and lychee. Top stuff, medium bodied. Would be a brilliant session beer.
Great from the look to the feel.  A good head tops off this hoppy brew.  Truly one of the best beers.

Poors a medium copper copper colr with a very nice, thick and creamy head and excellent lacing.  Strong and seductive hop nose.  Taste is initially bitter, with a pronounced dry hop flavor.  Great aftertaste.  A bit maltier than i had expected and hoped for.  Almost reminds me of a combination of a barleywine and a IPA.  I disagree with those who claim thiis is more of a IPA, as it¬ís clearly much more malty than the majority of IPAs.  This is a very good beer. I wonder, however, whether this deserves the distinction and rating it has.

Poura a cliudy amber/orarange hue with a smal small white head with decent lacing.  Aromas of hops, a little yeastiness....somehow.....A little herby, wit ha hint of celery.  MOuthfeel is medium bodied with a nice smooth finish,  Flavors of caramle, a slight hop bitterness, roasted nuts with a finish that begs for more.   Citrusr flavors with a grapefruit finish without veing an IPA, yet with a decent hop finish.   WOW......This is te pinnacle, session ale.

Pours copper orange with a big rocky beige head. Aroma was mostly citrus hops with some malt detectable. Flavor was very well balanced, with an all hop finish and lingering aftertaste. Very well done.

This is a good beer, but if it¬ís really in the top 1 percentile of beers, they¬íve changed something since I used to buy this stuff as my regular "drinking beer" a mile from the brewery when I lived in Whiting, Indiana four years ago.  At that time, they were a tiny outfit brewing their beers in a non-descript warehouse in Hammond, IN (they didn¬ít even have a sign on the building!).  I think they have since moved to new digs.  I used to buy it because it was brewed locally, was very hoppy (too hoppy for most), and wasn¬ít terribly expensive, about 2 bucks more a case than my usual Sierra Nevada Pale ale.  Good stuff, but back then, underneath the high hoppy initial taste was a somewhat disappointing wateriness and lack of depth.  Like I said, they must have changed something to get these high ratings, and I¬íd like to try it again today to see.  A memorable beer.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2005 Bottle at Chris¬í - brought by joet. I was very happy to see A Three Floyds beer. Red with a slight head. Hoppy U.S. aroma. Lovely and hoppy with some citric qualities. A good beer at the high end of the session beer scale.
The Great Kilburn Gathering. Heavy oily cascade aroma repeated in flavour. Soft sweetness. An IPA.

Bottled at The London/Joet Gathering Chez Chris_O.  A mid brown coloured beer with a good hoppy nose which has some orange notes.  The taste is smackingly hoppy with pomegranite notes.  Just really a good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005  Fantastic!  This is my first offering from Three Floyds and I am very impressed.  The pour is similar to the Victory Hop Devil but with an even cremier head.  The aroma is sweet and Malty with a lot of hops.  It is close to an IPA but not quite.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2005 An American/Indian pale ale?  I find it hard to consider this an pale ale when the description of their Dreadnaught is it is a step above their APA.  How can you go from an APA to an Imperial IPA.  The color is medium amber and a decent off-white head.  Strong pine/ citrus hop aroma and taste that comes off a little too medicinal for me, if not slippery.  Rather limp body.  A nice flavorful beer that I find a little lacking in the malts.  Lacks the body of SNPA and the smooth creaminess of Burning River, but I am sure the high hop profile will make most overlook this.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2005 If I didn¬ít know, and just poured and sniffed and looked at it, it would come off as an IPA.  (A plus, of course.)  Very good sign.  And it goes about as far as an APA can go.  (Actually, not even as far as Great Lakes Burning River does.)  Citrusy on the front, sweet on the finish, yadda yadda yadda.  I think it¬ís an inescapable feature of APA¬ís: they present much like an IPA but they¬íre smoothed around the edges, finishing soft and, well, flat.  A lackluster orgasm that just ends with a kind of thud, emptiness, unintrusiveness, non-lingeringness.  Okay, maybe that¬ís a bit harsh; after all, an APA can only be so much and a critic¬ís got to be a Bastard.  It¬ís good stuff.  The sudsy sheen on top and lacing are real eye candy, like Stone IPA.  Go on now, hop lover, join hands with the gargoyle, take that next step and go the rest of the way...
Dark Amber in color with a nice head.  Smells of grapefruit and spruce.  Tasted the citrus and spruce with a grassy aftertaste  Fairly bitter.

Deceptively sweet smell, and initial taste finishes (too?)  bitter and hoppy.  My girlfriend tried it, made a face, and said it tasted like cockroach juice. I¬ím not sure how she knows, but I disagree.
Another one of my Top Ten.  Carl...just rating this one makes me want to get back to The Maple Tree for an all nighter...or maybe follow those up with some free Budweisers...

thanks to Jimmack04 for this one.  clear and deep amber color, big rocky tan head that lasts.  pine, floral hop aroma.  taste is surprisingly malty, powerful hop balance.  mild carbonation.  nice sweet departure but not too sticky or cloying.  lots of crazy lacing.  nice IPA, but APA??

12 oz bottle. 54¬∞. NB Worthy glass. Poured red with orange tints and a 1/2" off white head. The head fades away after a minute or so leaving a ring around the glass and a few fat bubbles huddled together off to one side. Lots of lacing, the beer seems to coat the glass. Aroma is big floral hops and a bit o¬í honey.  There is some pineyness in the aroma as well. Nice aroma.  The taste is all hops. It tastes like you are chewing on a pine tree.  There are also some citrus rind flavors and some spicy ones as well. The flavor is almost completely hops driven, but the beer is not overly bitter.  The finish is dry and flavorful. Mouthfeel is full.  I might rate a finely balanced beer higher, but I sure do love a hoppy beer, and this is a great example.

The hops are so aromatic, this beer is hard to resist.  Usual grapefruit, floral scents, but in a much greater magnitude than other, hoppier pales.  Nice balance, hops hit quick and fade into a dry finish.  The malt middle is a bit thin, but I¬íd be knitpicking.  Another great FFF beer.  Cheers!

[bottle at MontreAlers meeting - Thanks, JM and Enkerli]  Bright brownish orange with a creamy head that recedes quickly to a thin film that leaves some lace on the glass.  Aroma heavy with pine and some grapefruit--it¬ís like smelling fresh hops but it¬ís only a tiny bit vegetal.  Surprisingly gentle but ascertive hop flavour that perfectly reiterates the aroma: pine and a little grapefruit.  Also surprisingly moderate bitterness considering the amout of hops in the front end of things.  Extremely smooth finish with a medium body and perfect level of carbonation.

Bought this 6-pack at Norm¬ís in Vienna, VA. Cloudy, orangy/copper pour. Nice frothy head. Nice strong hoppy aroma. Citrusy. Very strong hop presence in the flavor. Nice  balance as well. However, this should be considered an IPA like poivre said. Too much hops, and I believe the alcohol is too high for a Pale Ale. But still, even if it¬ís a little over-hopped, a damn good beer.

I¬ím sorry, this is a great beer, but here¬ís the problem: it¬ís an India Pal Ale, not a Pale Ale.  Judging an Alpha King as a Pale Ale, it¬ís simply too hoppy.  Either ratebeer has it miscategorized or 3F decided that it was tougher to market an IPA.  Put this as an IPA and I would give it top marks all around.
Pours a clear copper color with a nice thick head and great lacing.  Nose of citrus.  Nice pine and citrus bitterness as well as flavor.  Has a nice crisp and bitter finish.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2005 Very nice lacing on the glass.  A very nice orange/amber color and a very attractive hop character to the aroma.  Crisp clean flavor that finished quickly and refreshing.  A little over-hopped for a pale ale, even if it is american, but still delicious stuff.

Poured dark murky amber with a tall frothy white head that didn¬ít dissipate.  Excellent clean hoppy pale ale aroma.  Taste has great hop bite with some citrus undertones and a strong malt backbone.  Delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2005 My first experience with this beer was early in my career and it was on tap.  Since then, I¬íve been buying it by the sixer repeatedly, and each time I find that I want to bump up the rating.  Nevertheless, here¬ís the ongoing compilation from the countless times I¬íve had the beer from both bottle and on tap...Color is a deep copper-amber with a nice head that¬ís about 1/4" thick with random bubbles breaking at the top.  Smells strongly of Amarillo, lemons, grapefruit, nectar, pineapple rung and pine with trace wafts of amaretto-meets-lemon grass.  Altogether, a very bright and awakening aroma.  Hits the palate and bliss instantaneously registers as remarkably crisp, satisfying and hoppy as Three Floyds can be ¬ñ but, let¬ís not go without saying that there¬ís phenomenal malt sweetening at its regal center.  Welcome to Nick Floyd¬ís balance clinic, please take a seat.  Tingly grapefruit, papaya and pine resin accentuate that bitterness which is boding well - and reaching great distances - across the palate.  Perfumey and herbal complexities hint at freesia, lavender, snapdragons and lilies of the valley in liquefied form.  A small bite creeps-up at the end of each sip and leaves one of the best bitter remnants that an aftertaste could ask for.  Such a damn good beer by such an admirable brewery.  Well done, every time.

Hazy coper in color. Aroma is hops, grapefruit. Flavor is hops, grapefruit. There is considerable bitterness. Notes of sweetness, perhaps caramel. The finish is crisp with an excellent hops bite. A great thirst quencher and an excellent brew.
I really did not like this one at all, huge hop flavor to it that was real citrusy, but this just wasn¬ít my style, the warmer it got the more you could taste the alcohol, this was a drain pour.

bottle.  pours a tarnished copper color with a medium head.  my first sip of this brew was met with a strong hop aroma and flavor, which did not sit well.   but as I continued to drink this one, my first Three Floyd¬ís brew, I couldn¬ít believe how fast it went down.  Even though it was strongly hopped, it was very smooth and quite delicious.  The morale of this story is: don¬ít judge a beer by your first drink!
Bottle.  Melon and hops aroma.  Opaque tan with little head.  Primarily grapefruit and hops flavor throughout - slight hint of melon.  A very nice beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a tawny amber with a nearly-white head and substantial lacing.  Hoppy, citrusy aroma.  Hoppy flavor full of floral and citrus notes, with a tough of grapefruit and a slightly bitter, satisfying, aftertaste.  Medium-bodied and smooth on the palate.  Kind of tastes more like an I.P.A. than a pale ale.  Overall, awesome; something I¬íve sought out for quite some time now.

Hazy copper color, thick cream colored head. Full grapefruit hoppy aroma, some underlying malt sweetness. When first cracked open, the flavor was dominated by big, bold hops, as it warmed a bit the caramelly malts seeped their way in and created some very nice balance. Medium, creamy body. Very tasty, thanks wohlfs and qdog.

hoppy hoppy new year...  aroma citrisy.  The flavor is grapefruit, orange, and malty rolled up to a nice package.   It hits the palate with a wide assortment of flavors that has a long lasting bitter finale.   Just right .  I couldnt resist visited the brewery and bought a keg of this fantastic beer.  You will like and then some.

Hugely hoppy nose - grapefruit, orange, pine, spices.  Deep copper coloured with off-white/tan head that recedes slowly to generous cover.  Toasted, biscuity malts awaken the heavy, soporific hop flavour.  Plenty of hop bitterness but never overwhelming.  Creamy, smooth texture to the chewy thick body with gentle effervescent mouthfeel.  Bottle savoured with Enkerli and others.

Let¬ís rate as I drink...Aroma: Chewy, chewy, citrus hops. Almost sticky (if that¬ís a smell...) with very lite caramel malt riding the hop underneath.  Great copper-mahogony color, very clear.  Reasonable head for such a beer too.  Looks good.  Well balanced right off the start but leaning towards hops.  Gives you a hint of quenching liquid (and little malt) before moving into a hop brewhaha.  Dry with citrus peal and pine (maybe mostly citrus peal).  This is very good!  WOW!  I keep adjusting my ratings up as I continue to drink.  I always chew a bit of hops when I brew, anyone else get THAT strong a taste?

If I had to chose one ale/lager to drink, this would be my choice.  This is truly the king, forget that nonsense out of St. Louis.  The Floyds got it absolutely right with Alpha King, from the orange color, citrus and hops, huge flavor, yet easy drinkability. My first 20.  I keep trying other American Pale Ales, but always come back to Alpha King.

Bottle.   The orange and spice hits the second you pop the cap.  Hops and floral spice very pronounced in the smell.  Appears a bit red and quite filtered.  Hops just keep hitting the nose.  Nice bitter, full, warm finish that lingers with more hop notes.  3F¬ís flagship, indeed.  A great beer.

Coppery, orangey hue, fairly clear, decent head formation. Fairly mellow grapefruit aroma, fresh rose petals, pretty sweetish suggestions. Palate is predominantly hoppy grapefruit but it¬ís pretty well balanced, tea, mild orange and biscuity caramel. Pretty strong bitter finish. The hops are there in abundance but are well balanced, throwing themselves out every once in a while to catch your tastebuds by surpise. Very well put together.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2009 Orange amber color, full hop citrus aroma, hoppy grapefruit burst in your mouth with a wonderful malt hop blend aftertaste. This is the best pale ale out there and probaly one of the top 5 overall brews.

Excellently hopped, beautiful hoppy appearance and a good meal accompanyment. Grapefruit hops, green tea, some malts, some peachy melon and dark fruit taste in finish. Fresh medium clean mouthfeel. Thanks Joey Capps.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2005 Pours amber with a near-perfect creamy head. The citrusy hop aroma really doesn¬ít do the flavor justice. Very creamy for a pale ale, with just the right malt backbone to balance the initial hop blast. The most flavorful pale ale I¬íve found so far.

This one pours a nice dark red/amber color with nice sized white head. Has good head retention and leaves some lacing around the glass. Smell is dominated by the hops mainly citrus and there is some malt too it as well. The taste is all about the hops, which dominate the initial flavors. There is some malt to it and it has a nice bitter aftertaste, a very balanced taste. Has a nice think and creamy mouthfeel with a good amount of carbonation. A great pale ale that is very complex and makes for one of my favorite session beers.

Aroma is much more subtle then I expected, but plesant...  Hops, dried fruit, a lot of peach I catch too.  Body is an amber/brown, with a very thin head.  Taste is unlike any beer I¬íve had, it¬ís real hoppy, but it lets the sweetness chyme in from time to time.  With this beer you get your sweet tea, then hops, and a little bit of dark fruit.

A lot of expectation for this one!  Brought from my northern brother.  Very well defined aroma, almost a professional olfactory comment.  Sweet hops and mild carbonation make this worth the wait.  Well constructed Pale Ale!
Big citrus and piney sweetness on the nose.Hops were not pushing this over the hill and flavors were subtle.Nice.My friends wife loved it and is now a hophead.

Clear amber golden beer with a foamy off-white head. Orange, flower hop, nut and caramel in the fruity aroma. Bitter/flower hoppy flavor with sweet fruity notes and a long bitter finish. Dry. Nice and fresh!

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2006 I¬ím really excited to drink this beer right now.  I¬íve never been in more of a pale ale mood than I am this evening.  Great looking beer.  Darker and redder than most pales.  Sweet grapefruit, orange, and hop aroma.  Piney hop flavor.  Not nearly as much grapefruit taste as I had expected.  Very refreshing with just the right amount of carbonation.  A quite enjoyable rotgut.

bottle.  Huge grapefruit aroma right out of the blocks.  Medium white head that lingered briefly. Very pretty orange-red and completely clear(despite the bottle fermentation).  Huge grapefruit flavor. Not as bitter as I expected, but still a lip-purser for sure.  Very unbalanced of course, but too much emphasis on the grapefruit.  Could be better on tap?  Not a real "98%er" in my book.

Slightly hazy copper hue with a durable head and lacing and some yeast floating around-lovely dry hoppy grapefruit aroma. On the light side in body, it¬ís a hoppy sob alright but where¬ís the malt? Bitter hoppy up front, turned a bit fruity-grapefruit/orange with a note of caramel in the middle with a dry bitter finish. Tasty with a killer aroma but unbalanced.

Bottle:  dark amber with red highlights, light tan head, clear body.  This is one of the best hop aromas I have smelled.  Fresh, juicy hops, grapefruit, floral notes, grass, some caramel malty notes.  Taste doesn¬ít hide the fact that it¬ís been heavily laden with hops.  Initially biting and bitter, yet fresh and crisp, this beer attacks your taste buds.  Loads of hops, with some caramel, grain malt in the background somewhere.  One of the best in this style for sure.  Only negatives - slightly watery mouthfeel, could be more full bodied.  Also, I respect hops, but I¬íd like to see just a bit more malt backbone to go with the body.  Very good.

Orangey red with an off-white head.  Nose is candi sugar, grapefruity, rich malt, tart & tini candies.  Flavor is grainy/husky citrus hop, some fruitiness.  Well done on the malt, slightly past toasted.  Finish is grapefruity pine, earthy.  An awsome IPA

[GABF 2004] A clear orange beer with a small orange head. It has a great hoppy aroma with notes of oil. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel and loads of hops. The hops lends it grassy notes and a very hoppy dry finish and lots of bitterness. The body is surprisingly weak.
Amber/orange coloured. Hoppy and fruity aroma. Very refreshing. Grassy, dry and slightly light finish. A great thirst quencher.

Very strong hop aroma, citrus, herbs and tobacco, very good! Pours orange to amber body with a medium airy white head. Very nice hop flavor, very refreshing, but a bot too watery. Wish i had this beer as my everyday beer!

Bottled: Orange golden coloured. Light brown medium head. Well lasting. Flowers, herbs and hops in the nose. Goood. Is very well hopped in the flavour. Citric and flowery. Is a little thin in the body, but ends on a very nice long lasting sweet bitterness. Quite refreshing. Good one.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2004 An excellent american pale ale. Truly fabulous. Could be drunk in volumes. Tobbacco, copper. Treacly, sticky grey green, dull brown head. Notes of subtle apricot, brandy and an abundance of hops. Amariillos methinks.  Voluminously subtle and yet breathtakingly aromatic all at once.  All of these flavors translate into the palate. However they are not paled over by some rudely cantankerous tyrant malt, or hop or yeast. Much rather they lie down sweetly with one another and are committing indecent acts on my strongest muscle. These flavors come first. Next an ample hop punch cuts my cheeks in twain. Overwhelmingly bitter. However it retains an element of subtlety in that the malt is aromatic and sweet enough to carve the bitterness into perfection. This is one masterful brew. 
G-rat
Excellent.  Very hoppy.  Smooth and clear.  Very tasty.  One of the best pale ales I have ever had.

Wonderful citrus aroma - lemon/orange.  Creamy and rocky long-lasting head, with bubbles still on sides of glass after I¬ím finished.  Citrus hop flavor is again lemon/orange - crisp and clean with nice bitterness.  Medium body with palate starting off creamy, then a blossom of bitterness, followed by a slow bitterness fade that is still there long afterwards.

Copper Coloring Witih Good Head.  Aroma of Citrus and Hops.  As is the Flavor.  Fruity and Very Hoppy, Yet Not Extremely Over Powering.  A little Dry, but Not Enough Where You¬íre Looking for Another Beer Right Away.  Very Charactable Pale Ale.

Finally, after a long wait, I get to sample my first offering from Three Floyds. Deep copper/amber, with a small head. Lotsa bubbly. Smells are exquisite! Pine. grapefruit... citrus- lovely. taste is that of a lovely IPA, with the citrusy pines and undertones of soapy bitterness. Very nice!

Pours a dirty cedar with a white head that quickly fell.

Smells wonderfully hoppy. Citrus scents and loads of leather.

Tastes mainly of grapefruit hops with other tropical flavors. Well balanced and well hopped. The finish is full of lemons. 

Excellent Pale Ale.

Pours copper color with a big light tan head.  Big hop aroma of grapefruit, pine, and oranges with a light alcohol nose.  Flavor is mostly hops with citrus flavors and a good hop bitternes light malt helps keep it balanced.  Medium bodied with a crisp bitter finish.  This one sets the pale ale standard.
bottle. thick creamy offwhite head, golden-orange in color, definitely has a hoppy taste followed by citrus and ends with a slight bitterness.

Beautiful by hop dominated aroma with fruits and some cookie. Hazy, amber/orange color, beige almost creamy head, very good lace. Light sweet start, very fruity (mainly orange), very hoppy, after swallowing bitter, long lasting bitterness. Maybe a bit on the thin side. Great example of the style, lots of hops but not exaggerated, very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2005 Bottle:  Aroma is malty with grapefruit.  Pours a slightly hazy copper with a small white head that is gone quickly.  Okay lacing.  Flavor is rather malty.  Nice big hops in the finish.  Well balanced.

bottle. amber pour with a light tan head. citrus aroma.very hoppy up front but not overdone. this was very strong to be just a pale ale.sweet mango like flavor underneath everything that came out late in the glass. has a hop and pepper finish, and a buttery mouthfeel. Thanks to Tchrome for this.

Hops and malt, what more could you ask for.  Aroma of apple blossoms, pine, furit and caramel.  The aroma is full and carries throughout the glass.  The flavor is of carmel,  pine, pear and citrus.  All and all a top example of an APA.
This is one of the best pales i have ever had.  The bite is the finish is perfectly balanced by the bittersweet hops.  Excellent beer.  I would never pass on it.
Pours copper with a light tan head. Hoppy nose. Very floral hoppy taste with a dry mouthfeel.
great pale ale, deep amber color.  hoppy citrusy aroma.   great taste similar to the aroma.   22 oz bomber went great on a nice mild weathered labor day.  count this as one of my new tops.
The true king of beers. On tap at the Maproom, Chicago.  Hoppy and I love the dry bitter finish these types of beers leave. Oily and blood orange body.  All hail the king.

This beer pours a deep ruby and amber color...and wow were the hops and caramel sweetnesses flowing in this one. The aroma is all over the place hops and caramel malt...very fresh stuff here! This had a nice white sheathing head which died off very quickly. The flavor is slightly acetic with a wonderful malty finish and bitter hoppy front. Some orange and nectar with hints of syrup. This would be an awesome sticky staple for the summer. Dry, but not horribly dry finish.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 Nice drink for a hop-head.  A nice amber/orange color with an off-white head that lasts whether coming from tap or bottle.  Great citric hop aroma witha bitter, cirticy flavor to match.  A great pale ale.  I¬ím glad Chicago is near Munster.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Lawn, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a brilliant copper orange color, medium white head with a fair amount of lace. Beautiful hop aroma, with grapefruits exploding out of the glass firing pine needle shrapnel. Impeccably balanced, bittersweet, dry earthy finish, smooth and soft carbonation. After a few seconds this beer kicks in with a massive caramel and pine flavor burst. Nearly flawless. An outstanding pale ale, and I actually considered moving to Indiana for a minute.
brown/gold in color with a strong hoppy smell with a bit of pine.  Nice citrus flavor, but did not get the "quick, dry" finish in the commercial description

Deep amber gold, with fine white head, very rich color. Pine, flowers, carmel(light), peach, and other fruits. Full bodied, with lingering finish, and a dry bitter finish. Flesh fruit, pine, resin, faint malt flavors, while the malt so expertly supports the immense hops. Peach and citrus too make an entrance on the finish. Wow, thanks Brewso!

The best pale ale I¬íve ever had.
Very well balanced pale as well.
Hops are explosive and citrisy.
If you have not had this ale you are missing out,because it¬ís all the hype you¬íve read about.
There is nothing bad to say about this beer. Big malty taste with cascade hops fairly gushing across the mouth followed by a nice dry finish and a very slightly chewy aftertaste. A truly great beer.

The body is hazy amber with a 1 ¬Ω inch thick creamy white head with medium carbonation.  The aroma is citric with the fragrance of grapefruits and orange rinds.  The taste is crisp and refreshing grapefruit juice with a nice hop bite to it.  Mouthfeel is a bit thinner than an IPA, but is right on the money for an APA.  Nice sessionable beer with no noticeable faults as long as you can tolerate hops.  Very nice bonus in a box of trades, thanks to eyedrinkale.

12oz bottle  Nice pour, amber colored, nice head and lace.  citric piney hops blend in with carmelly sweet malts in the nose, in the flavor.  THis is a stellar pale ale, very big for the style, I think.  Not only one of the best pale ales I¬íve had, but one of my favorite beers period.  A bit strong to be a real session beer, but I could drink this all night long just the same.

Bottled...part of a trade with Brooklyn Boy. Poured a delicious deep amber-orange with a wonderful sand colored tight. sticky cap which goes to a surface covering clinging lace which lasts. Lively in the glass with a continuous stream of tiny effervessent bubbles coming from the glass base. Glorious hop aromas...floral, lime, grapefruits, pine and sweet malts. Best APA aroma yet. Dandy mouthful of sweet bready malts at the start then the peppery carbonation helps in literally shotgunning the tongue with alpha oils....like bittered grapefruit and key lime with a floral background...malts sit well in the background mid point....the finish is long with the drying effect dominated by the piney hops and a very subtle bubble gum taste... then the metalic aftertaste followed by a slow warming from the alcohol.....a very flavorful refreshing and satisfying ale. Thanks Edward...this brew is an American jewel.

Thanks Jason for this great ale.  This one has a big grapefruit nose and a copper/amber hue.   On the pour a big sticky off-white head prevails.  It¬ís abit more hoppy on the nose than I would¬íve guessed, but for me thats a good thing!  Pale malts, supporting a very well balanced medium bodied brew. Caramel, light bread...Big heady hops. Pine needles and resin dominate the finish. This brew is so that I¬ím gonna have to get a lot more of them.

Lively aroma full of Cascade hops with a little breadiness. Nice amber color, darker end of the spectrum. Taste is good and malty, with a ton of hop flavor.  Finely bitter towards the end, leaves a dry, clean bitterness in the mouth. Basically an IPA.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2005 WOW!  For some reason the word HOPS comes to mind! Nick Floyd¬ís love for Hops is evident in this pale ale.  Although the hops were dominent throughout the entire 12 fl. oz.  a mosaic of malts and citrus entangle the bitter flavor to create a well balanced mixture.  Who could ask for anything More!

This stuff is hop-heroin for the hophead.  The aroma comes at you miles away from the glass, a perfect floral and citrus delight.  The flavor is fantastic, just the right amount of malt and a shovelful of hops.  Between this and Dreadnaught, Three Floyds really know how to do it right when it comes to big hoppy brews.  Cheers!

Alpha King screams hops...and manages to do so without becoming obnoxious.  Nice orange/amber color and fair head.  Great citrus aroma let¬ís on to the smack of hops to follow.  Sort of  balls up on the tongue and rolls away.  It lives up to the reputation and that says a lot.

Toasted carmel, licorish, herbs, earthy hops, grass clipping, malt syrup, and a little honey.  Cloudy orage with a fine thin head.  Chewy malts, grassy hops, anise, alcohol. Finnishes very grainy and herbal. Thanks Pabobcat

Potent hop aroma - grapefruit, grass, oranges - all so fresh!  Just a hint of malt and a pleasant fruitiness add complexity to the aroma.  Clear amber color, off-white head.  Great hop flavor with some pleasant maltiness coming through in the middle.  Nice hoppy bittnerness right through to the finish.  Medium-full body.  Great APA!  Quite bitter and full for the style.  One of the best hop profiles I¬íve encountered in a beer.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2006 First time I found Three Floyds and boy am I glad I did. Pours a dark reddish hued amber with a small head. It has a hoppy/malty aroma. The taste is very clean and smooth with nice notes of malts finishing off with a nice hoppy taste. Can¬ít wait to find Three Floyds again

Clear copper color, small beige compact head, lots of sheeting lace - Alpha King "Gorgeous George the III" Pale Ale, yep...that¬íll do.

Mighty fine hopified wiffer for an aroma, highly sweet, softly resinous, calming citrus, slick pine, freshly floral; its got it all in the hop profile. Dreadnaughts little brother for a nose. A hop bouquet! Nicey nice. Yum.

Taste has a well rounded front, slight fruity malts with hop flavors of dulled citrusy stuff. Builds quickly from there with fresh floral tones, crisp yet green like a green bean, toasty just past midway, growing into lingering hop piney bitterness which is pretty full of good Ol¬í alpha acids to fade off and squeeze out any sweetness remaining. Quite juicy and resinous with a favorable drying of bitterness. Some slight toffee eeks its way onto the sides of the cheeks super later.

Feel is clean, slick, quick the whole way through, about medium body, nearing more lighter due to its remarkable cleanness - calming and smooth in the front, wafting hoppy finish of refined bitterness and light drying for its back.
A magnificent pale!

Pours a dark copper color with a small off-white head. Big citrus hop nose, very impressive, i smelled it from way back. Taste starts a bit sweet and malty with a faint caramel like thing goin on, then is nicely finished off by a good bitterness. Faint grapefruitiness in the aftertaste from all the citrus hops. I was really excited to try this brew and it lived up to all its hype.

Copper color with a slightly off white head.  Nose dominated by citrus.  Flavors echo the same thing.  Lots of big, juicy citrus flavors with a pleasant amount of carbonation and a nice, dry, clean finish.  Damn good, and deserves the praise it recieves.
Orange-amber with rapidly fading head. Huge aroma of citrus/hops. Nice hops bitterness with lots of grapefruit. Enough malt to keep it from being unbalanced.

Sampled on tap at Brewtopia ¬í04. Orange/amber color with a small white head. Strong hop aroma with hints of citrus and rosemary perhaps? Initial taste was slightly malty, then the hops dominate, in a great way. Great beer.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2005  Pours a nice orange/rustic hazy color, with a small-medium head. Aroma is Hops and citrus, similar to many a palie¬í. Flavor is overwhelmed by Hops, and is a bit dominating at times. A full flavor and bod¬í to it. Ending is all in da hops¬í!
Beautiful orange color. Nice citrus smells. Strong hops to taste, more than the malt, which goes against the description.  Seems lighter than most medium bodied beers. Great summer drink.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2004 Strong hops and citrus smell. Orange in color with little head. Has a strong hops taste that I did not feel was balanced by the malts. Nice and bitter with a dry finish. A fine example of a Pale Ale. A good refreshing brew in the summer heat.
Totally awesome.  My favorite pale ale.  awesome hops.  probably my favorite beer overall.

WOW!!!!!!  This is what an ale should taste like!!!  Although I don¬ít agree with the commercial description, I think this is alot more of a beer leaning to the hop and not that of of a balanced beer, but I¬ím not complaining! This beer will treat you well....very well.
Bottle: Poured a bright, lively cloudy orange with a moderate white head. Lots of lacing. Aroma dominated by grapefruit. Flavor sweet citrus, grapefruit, enough malt, nice bitterness. Excellent beer.

on tap.  great american pale ale.  the tap handle says "its not normal" and they are right.   very citrusy and hoppy.  extremely bitter but has enough of a malt balance.  excellent beer.  highly reccommended

Tasted in NYC.  Tasted at brewtopia 04.  Aroma is floral and spicy, very typical of an american IPA.  Appearance is copper with a sustained white head.  Well overhopped taste, dry a very slight hint of malt somewhere and overpowering bitterness.
On tap at Brewtopia.  Very hoppy.  Medium body. Lots of pine. Light color. Very piney. Citrusy. Nice beer.
Brewtopia¬í04.  Like other FFF, this one is piney in a big way.  Pine on flavor but dominated by cirtus.  This may be my favorite APA.  For sure, I¬íll have to get some more to sample.
On Tap Brewtopia ¬í04 pale light color,tasted some fruit,Can down this easily although i thnk it was a littile on the sweet side
Tap at Brewtopia. Pale clear orange with a nice head. Nice hoppy aroma. Flavor is well balanced. Malt comes through. Perfect bitterness. Easy drinking.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Draught somewhere in Chicago. This beer is a pleasure. Not much better than most other American Pale Ales from microbreweries. Nice complexity and balance. Something is missing can¬ít say what. Incredible fruity aroma.
