UPDATED: MAY 9, 2003 Had it in Cincinnati. Found it at Jungle Jim's (see Jim's web site). WoW, ZaP, ZiNg, PoW...the orangy/grapefruit hop bitter slaps you right in the taste buds and wakes them right up. Almost like a light IPA. A really good beer.
Nice maly, hop aroma.  Bitterness is balanced well by the malt perfectly. A refreshing pale ale.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2005 Nice copper hue with a frothy head. Weighty yet crisp on the tongue. Snappy hop flavors right off the bat. Resiny, piney and citrusy. Healthy amount of hoppy goodness to complement the big malt flavors. Re-Rate 6/28/02: Just tried this on tap and I was blown away; seemed better than the bottled version. The hops were amazingly pronounced... piney, zingy, and citrusy - wonderful beer! Surprising amount of malts to complement. Excellent beer.
Nice sharp hop flavor with a nice smooth malty texture to it.  Very smooth to drink, even when warm.  An excellent beer.
Bottle.  A hop filled floral and citrus delight - exceptionally smooth.  A really wonderful pale ale.

Re-rate: This beer is outstanding.  If you are looking for a beer that combines tasty hop bitterness with a rich malty flavor, this is it.
Original: Terrific American Pale Ale - very hoppy and a bit maltier than SNPA.  A pleasure to imbibe.
Nice blend of malt to hops flavor in this one. Good amber color below a little white head. Very tasty and recomended.

Nice hoppy flavor; no complaints about this one, all at a reasonable price. 
Re rate: Should be saught out on tap, where it possesses a more complex, very floral hop profile, is slightly less bitter, and has a strong, toffeeish sweetness.

Every bit as good as I had heard. At the Fireside Restaurant in Chicago, where I tried this tonight with my dinner, a draft pint of Alpha King goes for only $2.75 - bliss on the cheap! 6/10/2002 update: subsequent encounters have done nothing to change my extremely favorable impression of one of America¬ís very finest beers.

On tap.  Wonderful grapefruit aroma which hinted at the hops to come.  Color was a medium burnt amber.  Taste leaves a lot to be desired, in my opinion.  There was a huge malty sweetness to start, with a little tartness, then it finished with a huge hoppy presence.  My taste buds could just not take it.  It seemed as if the ingredients were acting against one another instead of in harmony.  I couldn¬ít finish this one.
From the citris aroma to the strong hoppy flavor, I very much enjoyed this APA.  It has beautiful color and leaves a nice, clean feeling in the mouth.  Well done.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2003 Far too hoppy for my taste.
Now this is a beer that seems to have everything.  A strong hop flavor, with just as much in the malt dept.  Great, deep amber hue with a pale white head.  Magnificent.

A real, full throttle pale ale. Sierra Nevada may have started it, but these guy¬ís have really brought it full circle. Cleaner and rounder than alot of the West Coast superstars. Excellent! - And good packaging doesn¬ít hurt either.
Very well done for a hoppy beer.  It is nice to have good hop characteristics with a just as strong malt profile.  Great, creamy head.  A really full mouthfeel, very enjoyable.  Three Floyds!

Alpha King was orangish-copper in color with a nice sized, pillowy, white head.   The nose was super hoppy, with definate floral notes.    The aroma suffered from a subdued but noticeable ¬ímustiness¬í.   Hops dominated the flavor profile making me question why this high-alpha ale isn¬ít considered an IPA.   With the abundance of hops came the usual citrus, grapefruit tastes and acidic bite.    Alpha King finished with a lasting bitter.     All and all, I liked it.
Very citrusy & floral aroma, dark copper color, kept a very nice head out of the bottle, lots of body, dry bity aftertaste, pretty strong bitterness & hoppiness, nice balance, very good APA
Fruity but pleasantly so and one of the better Pale ales. Well balanced with a nice head. I agree with indra that its¬í more of an IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2007 Massive and juicy hop aroma, citric, earthy, floral and piney, underpinning a bit of toasty caramel malt sweetness.  Light-medium amber color, very faintly hazy, with a fine, creamy head.  Begins with a brief glimpse of toasty malt sweetness, before turning substantially hoppy and fruity.  Hops dominate deep into the finish, but a modicum of malty sweetness resurfaces late.  One of the more hoppy Pale Ales one is likely to encounter and luckily the blend is chosen very well.  Instantly appealing.

Finally had a chance to try this on tap at my favorite pub, Ann Arbor¬ís ABC.  I was not disappointed.  It comes on poised and powerful with the hops and citrus (very distinct grapefruit) rivals GL Burning River as my favorite pale, and its similarly well malt founded and well balanced, shading towards the hops.  Too bad it¬ís better than ABC¬ís own pales.
As a recovering hop head sometimes to much hops is just to much hops.  A good beer, but to Cascade overdosed to be a great beer.

Man, what a good beer.  A nicely hopped APA and a fine beer for #200!!! Pours out to a reddish-copper color with a slight head.  Initial taste of citrus and caramel with a big dose of hops on the finish.  This reminds me of Sierra Nevada¬ís Pale with a heavier dose of hops.  A very fine beer.  Now, on to 300!!!
This is a serious Pale Ale!! As complex as it gets, with tremendous hop character. A great beer!
UPDATED: APR 16, 2005 Nice dark orange color with tiny floaters.  Huge pine aroma, pleasant bitterness that is matched by a great malt taste.  I¬ím saddened by the fact that I don¬ít have any left.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011  Dark, malty body. A blast of hops with considerable carmel malt kick. A giant pale ale, almost an IPA as it is very hopped up and high in ABV for the style. The malt is delicious and is balanced perfectly with the hops, with a metallic bitterness creeping in late.
UPDATED: SEP 13, 2007 Let¬ís see: Pretty Boy Floyd, Pink Floyd, and ... ? Anyway, these Floyds make a killer beer - lots of hops and malt, lots of flavor, gotta get more of this.
Nice hoppy ale.  A little fruity, nice finish.  Another great beer from Three Floyds.
great hoppy ale, need i say more?  enjoy!

Nice fruity scent.  Flavor is mighty hoppy, with very strong grapefruit tastes.  Hops give a crisp, dry finish.  Good malts to back up the hops, nice long finish.  Slightly thin, would prefer it a bit creamier in the palate, but still darn fine.

A bottle of this was my introduction to American Pale Ale.  This brew pours a hazy dark
amber with a large creamy/rocky off-white mostly lastining head that has amazing lacing. 
This brew has a stellar nose.  Strong, complex and balanced.  Heavy tones of grain, straw,
cereal and caramel combined with heavy flowery tones of grass, resin, and soapy
grapefruit.  The flavor is outstandingly balanced with something for everyone here.  You
like malt?  It¬ís in there...How about hops?  Ditto... How about a little citrus to suck on...
you get the picture.  The long finish is also a plus.  This brew has a medium body with a
smooth texture and a perfectly soft carbonation.  The finish is dry.  An outstanding
offering.   I can¬ít wait to get my hands on some more Three Floyds Brews.

Delicious!  This is one of the best named beers in the business, and this brew lives up to it‚Äôs name.  Golden amber with a reddish tinge, moderately full-bodied, great aroma, terrific flavor that kind of explodes in your mouth, with a long, dry rather than sweet, citrus dominated finish, very thirst quenching.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2003 (bottle - 10/7/03) Hazy copper body topped by small beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit.  Taste is grapefruit, medium sweet, fairly intense bitterness.  Still, the sweetness lends decent balance to the hops.  Medium body.  (draft - 7/2/03) Clear brown body with small off-white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet hoppy.  Taste is hoppy (pine/grapefruit) -- going for broke and taking no prisoners.  Medium body. (7/4/7/3/14)

Near perfect hopping (for me anyway) with a substantial fruity flavor 
- well Balanced in this respect.  The finish is dry, but not too dry.  This beer is much more complex than I expected.

Wow this beer looks appetizing in the glass, great burnt orange body and substantial head.  I happen to like grapefruit a lot, and the aroma is full of it, as well as other citrus tones.  There¬ís a substantial, adequate malt backbone to support the ample hopping.  Definitely not as subtle as some other good pale ales, but enjoyable just the same.  Leaves a great impression that makes me want to open another as soon as I finish the first.
Dumb Label, Great Hoppy Beer. :)
UPDATED: APR 10, 2003 nice aroma; typical 3floyds citrus/grapefruit-hop taste; super hoppy, yet very well balanced in the end - how did they do that?! I just LOVE this beer.
Good beer, nothing to special here though.  Not a fan of grapefruit, so take that into account.
An umcompromising beer completely dominated by the grapefruit aroma of American hop varieties. Very bitter, very tasty.
Extremely chunky and what a great flavor, wow! I like it. Cloudy, almost amber in color with aggressive but not overpowering hops. The malts are present and make this a well  balanced beer
A great pale ale. Someone once said to me they did not like pale ales because they all taste the same. He needs to get out more.
Wonderful statement of cascade hops, with a clean/bold statement.  Very drinkable, I can see why they did so well at the GABF !! A must try if you like Hoppy ales.
Very good
The Floyds are making life a lot more pleasant for all of us.  This is almost like grapefruit juice.
Overall a very nicely done and very hoppy ale.  This beer is what it is, but what it is, is a bit too much of a good thing.
Others comments say it all...Excellent!

Cloudy dark copper color with a fine white head and generous lace. Floral nose with nice malt undertones, the middle is a blend of malt and hops, with the finish being all ¬íHOPS¬í, POW right in the taste buds. Been a while since I sampled this above average Pale Ale. Medium body and light carbonation, a top 5 pale Ale on my master list and if your a Pale Ale fan, this is a must try beer. A certain rival to SNPA.

On tap at the Map Room, Chicago:  People keep mentioning the citrus on the nose, but what about the berries?  At first I thought I had mistakenly ordered a fruit beer, the rasp/blueberry profile was so strong.  That, and orange, and caramel malts, and a whole lot of other complex fragrances and tastes, and you have perhaps the best American Pale Ale there is.  NOT overrated, in my opinion.
A pale orange/copper.  Clear, minimal head. Aroma has a very cutrusy, hoppy and inviting quality. Huge malts, huge hops, fruity qualities all balanced superbly. Nice DRY finish.  A great APA!

Good beer, somewhat overrated in my opinion, but that probably has something to do with the fact that I can buy it at the local liquor store.  It would probably hold a more mythical place in my mind if it were one of the ¬íunavailable¬í beers that I had to travel to get.  That said a good take on the APA

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2003 Dances with the taste buds nicely, but lacks malt focus and balance.  I need more toast and caramel.  More like a dumb-downed Dreadnaught, with a tad more dry-hopping that really becomes more evident within the accompanying hop belches.  The citrus hop profile is profound in every regard.  This would more than suffice as an IPA.  Whatever.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: This runs circles around SNPA in my opinion.  Bigger malt, bigger hops and bigger mouthfeel.  This is supurbly malty (caramel flavors) for an APA and the hops are just big for an APA.  Very distinct citrus astringency and some bitterness.  Nice copper to bronze color with very minimal head.  My only complaint is the excessive yeast sediment my bottle contained, which made the beer appear muddy.
Very nice pale ale.  Citrus notes and a nice golden orange color.
Wow this is a great APA. Probably my favorite. Great malt backbone to complement 3F¬ís great hop flavoring. A great drinking experience!

The citrus is just a little too strong on what would otherwise be an excellent beer.  The overall impression and aftertaste is great, but it stings the tongue just a little.  Still, the strong hops really give it good flavor.

A solid malty beer with a pretty nice hop presence. I don¬ít think the hops are as good as in some beers but this is a pretty good beer. (Had another and am increasing my ratings, the hop taste was more evident and nice in the next sample)
Naturally hoppy, but minus a stinging on the tongue (hey I kinda like that =) ).  A great APA nonetheless.
JUST HAD A SIX PACK OF THIS LOVED IT.  VERY EASY TO DRINK .JUST THE RIGHT AMOUNT OF HOPS. ANY PALE ALE LOVER NEEDS TO TRY THIS.
A very interesting multi-faceted ale.

I really was not overly impressed on the first try,(I was spoiled by the Floyds bottle conditioned masterpieces when they were available). On second approach I found it refreshing and well rounded. The hops character has it all down to that dry, bitter finish.

Seemed maltier and slightly hoppier than Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, and while that¬ís normally a good thing, I think it was too much.  The sweetness was bleeding through the hop flavor and the hop flavor was strong up front and diminished quickly.  This isn¬ít what hopheads like to taste.
I agree with Kaya, I did drink it with him.  More british and maltier then a normal APA.  Kind of sweet and fruity.
Very British tasting.  Reminds me of Fullers ESB with more hops.
Complex hop notes.  An interesting beer for sure.
The hops really come to the fore in this one.  Mysterious other scents and flavors resembling something fruity.  Seems sweeter than Red Hook or Sierra Nevada.
Excellent IPA. Very hoppy, yet nice malt balance.

A must try for any hophead.
Intensely hoppy, but not as
well balanced as some of the
highly hopped beers.  Still, its
really good.
Good brew, I expected a little more hop in the aroma dept.  Still a great example of the AIPA style.
Nice beer. Big hop aroma and flavor.
With a name like Alpha King, how can you possibly go wrong??
